In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. The earth is spherical, surrounded by water. Both are stationary at the center in the heart of the celestial spheres, and its circumference is three hundred and sixty degrees. Each degree is fifty miles, and a mile is four thousand cubits. The inhabited part of it has a longitude from the Eternal Islands (Canary Islands) in the Ocean in the West to the Sila Islands in the Ocean in the East of one hundred and eighty degrees. The visible part of it is rugged for the settling of seas and the flow of rivers. The latitude of the inhabited world from its furthest point in the South to its furthest point in the North is eighty degrees. What lies beyond that in the South is uninhabitable due to the intensity of the sun's heat at the perihelion there. What lies beyond it in the North is uninhabitable due to the intensity of the cold. The total inhabited area is divided into nine sections: The inhabited area behind the Equator to the South, and the Seven Climes graduating from the Line. Then the ninth section is the inhabited area beyond that to the furthest habitation in the North; explaining the reasons would be lengthy. The inhabited area behind the Equator to the South has a width of sixteen degrees. The Surrounding Ocean does not appear in it from the far West nor in the South. It consists of ten parts. Part One: Contains among the Sudanese cities the city of Kaw (City of the Naked), who are neglected like beasts as reported, where the longitude is ten degrees and the latitude is four. And Zafqu, where the longitude is thirteen degrees and the latitude is ten. Other than that are shifting sands and obliterated paths. Part Two: Contains types similar to the previous one, including Za'nah, where longitude is twenty-four degrees and latitude is seven. And Barsanah, where longitude is twenty-seven degrees and latitude is seven. In it is the first of the Nile rivers descending from a latitude of sixteen degrees from the end of habitation, which is the end of Part Two. Part Three: From its beginning where longitude is thirty-six degrees and minutes to longitude thirty-nine degrees and twenty minutes, and latitude sixteen degrees, are the four sources of the Nile which are after the fifth part and at the end of the second part mentioned earlier. They spring from the flatlands. The other five sources are also in the third part, except they are from the Moon Mountain (Jabal al-Qamar) where longitude is forty-eight degrees to fifty-two degrees and five minutes. The latitude in all these ten sources does not depart from sixteen degrees. The first five (rivers) pour into the first western lake (Batihah) where longitude is forty-two degrees, latitude seventy [sic, likely meant 7 or relative to equator], and diameter five degrees. The second eastern lake is two degrees away from the first, and the center in latitude is the same, as is the diameter. Five rivers exit from each lake, just as they enter from the northern side, except that the second and third from the two lakes become one river shortly after, and all pour into the Great Lake located in the First Clime. In this first region of Sudan is Rafalah, which is between the first two rivers, and between it and the lake is one degree. And Kushah, on springs extending to the last of the rivers from the second lake where longitude is fifty-three degrees and latitude two degrees. Beneath it flows the Nile of Mogadishu coming out north of the Line. The settlements of al-Qamar are between the two lakes, and the settlements of Akar are to their north up to Lake Kura. Part Four: Contains the end of the Moon Mountain according to Ptolemy's view, where longitude is fifty-one degrees fifty minutes and latitude eleven degrees. In it are the settlements of al-Qamar (the Moon people) to whom the mountain is attributed. They are brothers of the Chinese. Famous among them in this part of the Sudanese cities is Damdamah, from which the Damdam emerged against the lands of Nubia and Abyssinia in the year 617 AH, coinciding with the emergence of the Tatars against the lands of the Persians; they are the Tatars of the Sudan. In it is Qaljur, to which the Qaljurian swords are attributed; near it is a mine of superior iron from which they are made. It is where longitude is fifty-five degrees sixty minutes and latitude two degrees thirty minutes. And Berbera, the base of the Berbers whose horses Imru' al-Qais mentioned. Their slaves are appreciated. Most of them have converted to Islam, so they became scarce in Islamic lands. This city is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees and latitude six and a half.

The Nile of Mogadishu continues to ascend in this part until latitude eleven degrees where longitude is sixty-six degrees, then it descends to the east of Berbera, leaving about a degree between them, then descends to the east of Mogadishu. In this part, among the cities of Berbera—and it is the first of their cities on the coast of the Indian Ocean—is Qarfuna, located at the first corner of the sea where longitude is sixty-four degrees thirty minutes and latitude twenty minutes. East of it, among their cities on a high bay, is Barmah, where longitude is sixty-six degrees and latitude one degree. East of it is Hafuni (Hafun), the mountain famous among travelers. It appears entering the land southward about one hundred miles, and enters the sea about one hundred and forty miles to the north curving east. On its visible side are seven heads which travelers count from a distance and share good news when they pass them and clear that cape. East of it, among the famous towns of Berbera on the sea, is Markah (Merca), where longitude is sixty-nine degrees thirty minutes and latitude one degree ten minutes. Its people are Muslims, and it is the capital of the Hawiyah which exceeds fifty villages. It is on the bank of a river that branches from the Nile of Mogadishu and pours out two stages east of the city. From it, a branch forms the Basin of Markah. East of that is the city of Islam famous in that region and frequently mentioned by travelers, which is Mogadishu, where longitude is seventy-two degrees and latitude two degrees. It is on the Indian Ocean and its anchorage is not safe from storms. Part Five: At its beginning, at twelve minutes of the fourth part and latitude two degrees, is the mouth of the Nile of Mogadishu. It crosses its land leaving about twelve miles between them and pours into the Indian Ocean. In appearance, it is smaller than the Nile of Egypt near Mogadishu, but it is deep, and things branch from it that weaken its water. Ibn Fatimah said: This Nile exits from Lake Kura under the Equator from Mount Maqsim, a twin to the Nile of Egypt, at longitude fifty-one degrees and latitude half a degree in the First Clime. It winds and straightens, and rivers branch from it making those regions like the Egyptian lands in sugar and bananas, and like India in bdellium, coconut, and betel nut; all that and more is irrigated by it. They harvest twice, once on it and once on rain. It pours out east of Mogadishu, and its length is about two thousand miles. East of this Nile is the end of the Berber lands and the beginning of the land of the Zanj (East Africa). In this Fifth Part, among the famous cities of the Zanj is Malindah (Malindi), where longitude is eighty-one and a half degrees and latitude two and a half degrees and twenty minutes on a bay. West of it is a large inlet into which a river descends from the Moon Mountain. On the banks of this inlet are many settlements of the Zanj, and in the south are settlements of al-Qamar. East of Malindi is al-Harrani, a mountain famous among travelers, entering the sea about one hundred miles heading north with an eastward tilt, and appearing on land heading south straight for about fifty miles. Among its wonders is that the land part contains an iron mine common to the land of the Zanj and traded elsewhere, while the sea part contains lodestone that attracts iron. In this city are the sorcerers of the Zanj, and the residence of their kings is in the city of Mombasa. Between them is about a degree, and it is on the sea. West of it is a large inlet entered by ships for about two days and extending about three hundred miles. In this part is the desert between the Zanj and Sofala. In it, among the cities of Sofala, is Batinah. It is on the tail of a great bay entering the sea from the Equator four degrees, and the width of its head by curvature is two degrees. The city is where longitude is eighty-seven degrees ten minutes and latitude two and a half degrees. West of it, inside the north and east, is Ajrad. It is a mountain extending into the sea about one hundred miles. The waves make terrifying sounds there. It is a long inlet into which a river pours coming from the Moon Mountain, which is east of it. The length of the inlet and river is a month. On it are forests and settlements. The sea descends from this city a distance of a month until its coast is at the Equator where the Dome of Arin (Azayn) is, which is the pan of the balance of the earth, and from it to every direction is ninety degrees.

Part Six: In it, on the Indian Ocean, are settlements of the Sofalans and less famous cities until their capital, Sayuna, is located upon it, where longitude is ninety-nine degrees and latitude two and a half degrees. It is on a large inlet into which a river descends from the Moon Mountain to its west into a large bay, while the city is to its east. Its length from the Equator is five and a half degrees. In this city is the King of the Sofalans, who are Zanj people who worship idols and stones, pouring fish oil over them. Most of their livelihood comes from gold and iron, and their clothing is leopard skins. Horses do not live among them, so their army consists of foot soldiers. Al-Masudi mentioned that the Zanj fight on cows just as the Nuba fight on camels. From the east of this city, the Gulf of al-Qamar enters from the Indian Ocean to the furthest habitation in the South. Its width there is about two hundred miles. On this course and what approximates it, it passes like an arc to the South and East until it hits the Mountain of Regret (Jabal al-Nadamah) which will be mentioned. East of Sayuna is the Multam Mountain, which is large, extending with the coast of the gulf about two hundred and sixty miles. Often ships driven by the north wind strike it. Travelers guard against it; if they go east of it, they are saved, but if they enter the gulf southward, they maneuver to exit via the south wind so that the waters and winds do not carry them to the Mountain of Regret and they perish. The settlements of al-Qamar in the south of this part are connected with the mountain attributed to them. Located in it are cities: The Island of al-Qamar (Madagascar/Comoros), long and wide, said to be four months in length and the wide part over twenty days. Layranah, Ibn Fatimah mentioned that he entered it and it belongs to Muslims like Mogadishu. Its people are gathered from various regions. It is a place of landing and takeoff. Its sheikhs who manage it flatter the ruler of the city of Malay to their east. Layranah is on the sea where longitude is one hundred and two degrees minus minutes, and latitude half a degree and two minutes. It is on a large inlet descending in Part Seven to its west. Fifty degrees from it is Malay, where a king of the kings of the island resides. He may be a sultan controlling the entire island or most of it, but that is rare due to the distances and the dispersion of opinions and sects. It is at the latitude of Layranah, and to its west is an inlet descending from the great river flowing down to Layranah.

Part Seven: In it ends the land of Sudan, connected from the far West to the Mountain of Regret, then the sea becomes inhabited due to what is in its east along the length of the Island of al-Qamar. The beginning of the Mountain of Regret is the start of this part, where longitude is one hundred and eighty degrees and a minute. It is said its height in the air is about three days, and it is mixed with dust color and redness. It extends with the beginning of habitation where latitude is sixteen degrees for about twenty days. About fourteen days of it are along the sea. Its end is where longitude is one hundred and seventeen and a half degrees. The Surrounding Ocean entering from the East and South strikes its southern corner, and to its north is the Gulf of al-Qamar. If a ship slips from the Indian Ocean and enters this gulf, and the waters and winds carry it until this mountain is seen, one regrets what they neglected in terms of caution and surrenders to fate; either breaking upon it or entering behind it, never to be heard of again nor knowing what happened to them. It is said there are whirlpools there that keep spinning the ship until it sinks. Travelers in the Indian Ocean call that place the Sea of Ruin and the Sea of Suhail (Canopus), because if they reach it, they see Suhail directly overhead. Below this mountain to its north on the Gulf of al-Qamar is the city of Daghutah, the last city of Sofala and the last habitation on the land connected to this sea. It is where longitude is one hundred and nine degrees and latitude twelve degrees. It has an inlet to its north into which a river descends from the Moon Mountain. It is said its source shares the source of the river of Sayuna. In this Seventh Part, among the cities of the Island of al-Qamar which are capitals for its kings, lies Dahmi. It is where longitude is one hundred and twelve and a half degrees and latitude three degrees. An inlet descends to its east, its substance from the Great River, and it curves entering the sea from it until it almost touches the Equator, until at the end of the arc is the city of Balbaq, also a capital of the island's kings. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and eighteen and a half degrees and latitude one degree. East of it is an island attributed to this city, its length about two degrees from west to east and its width nearing a degree. East of Balbaq is the great arced river, the river of Layranah, descending from the Mountain of Springs, a mountain eight stages long from west to east. Five small rivers descend from its springs to the arc of this great river, so it curves and pours into the river of Layranah and the sea of Balbaq. East of Balbaq is the island of Serendib (Ceylon/Sri Lanka), half in this part and the other half in the Eighth. Its southern half is behind the Equator and its northern half in the First Clime. It is famous. The location of its city where its king resides is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-four degrees and latitude one and a half degrees and minutes; its name is Aghna. It has other cities. Splitting it in half at the Equator is the great mountain named al-Rahun (Adam's Peak), which is very high. It is said Adam, peace be upon him, descended upon it from Paradise. In its ravines and valleys, precious types of ruby (yaqut) and diamond stone used to drill ruby are found. In its sea is a famous pearl fishery. It is circular in shape. It is said to be eighty farsakhs by the same. Indian spices are plentiful there. On the arc of its southern sea are the famous inlets (Aghbab) of Serendib towards the South. They are four carved ones; into each inlet pours one of the rivers of the Island of al-Qamar. The western inlet is in Part Seven, the next along the line of Part Eight, then the fourth from the end of the mentioned arc. Part Eight: The first capital of the Island of al-Qamar you encounter is the city of Khafura. It is where longitude is one hundred and thirty degrees and latitude one degree on the last bay to the east of the inlets of Serendib. The Greatest River descending from the mountain overlooking Qumari pours into its north. East of it is the capital Dimli, on the sea where longitude is one hundred and forty-three degrees and latitude half a degree. A river descends into its east from the Greatest River. In this part are two mountains; one south of Dimli from which a long river exits to the third inlet, and the other near the middle of the distance between the two capitals near the southern sea, from which three small rivers exit pouring into this long river.

Part Nine: Contains cities and settlements of the Island of al-Qamar that are not famous. The mentioned one is the ancient capital of the island, whose ruler may sometimes dominate most of it, which is Qamariyah. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-four degrees, on a great bay rising three degrees from the Equator and widening about that much. This city is attributed to the Qamar (people), who are the sons of Amur bin Japheth, sharing lineage with the Amur of China. They used to live with the Chinese in the eastern parts of the earth, then discord arose, and the Chinese expelled them to the islands. They remained there for a while, and the title of their king was Qamarun. Then discord arose in that island which will be mentioned, so those distant from power left for this Great Island, and their authority was in the city of Qamariyah. Then they multiplied and branched out into the mentioned capitals and became factions and kings of regions. Then they fought when they multiplied, and a great multitude left them and inhabited the South at the beginning of habitation along the length of the mountain attributed to them. Those who do not know call it the Mountain of the Moon (Qamar) with a vowel 'a' on the Qaf. In this large island, whose length is four months and the width of its widest part twenty days, are great rivers. The greatest is the River of Khafura. Due to its depth and width, large sea ships travel in it for cargo. Its length between its mouth and the eastern end of the island—and its mouth is below Khafura—is about two months. On its banks are large trees; from a single tree, they make the ship you know, rowed by a hundred men. It is hollowed out, and the table at which a hundred people sit. That is mentioned in books and famous on tongues. From this wood, they make houses on ships and anchor them with ropes. If one of them dislikes his neighbor, he moves to another neighbor. Likewise, if fire breaks out in his neighbor's house, he unties his house's ropes and escapes. In it is the great bird known as the Roc (Rukh); they claimed it covers a military detachment with its shadow and snatches elephant chicks with its talons to feed its young. They make bridges from its quills over their waters to cross, and from its hollow bases, water jars. They have cows they use for pulling; one calf is the size of three of our land's cows. Each of its horns holds a thousand "Mann" of oil. Their oil for lighting comes from the fat of great beasts they hunt in their sea. They have hemp (Hashish) from which they weave fine colored textiles brought to Iraq and Yemen. It has bananas, sugar, and coconuts from which they make ropes for their ships and stitch their planks. Most of what grows there is the Betel (Tanbul), which is like grapevines in its twisting and like laurel in its leaves. They use a leaf of it with a little lime and water, producing a good mood, intoxication, and fragrance they enjoy; it is the wine of the lands of India. Their appearances are more inclined to the Chinese than the Indians, as are their clothes and their worship of idols (Buddhas/Abdad) like the people of India and China. At the head of the city of Qamariyah, the mountain attributed to it rises about three degrees. Many rivers descend from it to the great River of Khafura. Its eastern tip pours into the end of the island from the east side, and its western tip below Khafura. The sea that passes along its southern length mixes from the South with the Surrounding Ocean. It is said no one enters it, neither from the islanders nor others. Whoever falls into it perishes in its whirlpools. Their travel is only in the Northern Indian Ocean and the seas of the eastern and western directions.

Part Ten: In it is the Island of al-Mujah (likely Muja/Ma-iTsu), its length from South to North is twelve days. Its location is at the beginning of the part, its width about two days, and its southern head is at the end of habitation. Its city is where longitude is one hundred and sixty-three degrees and latitude nine degrees. It is an independent kingdom. To its north is the Island of al-Mayd, separated by a strait half a degree wide. It is smaller than the first, counted among the islands of China mentioned in books. Around it are small islands called the Islands of al-Shamsiyah (Solar/Sun); their people are among the filthiest of God's creation, and they bring honey and wax to China. There ends the Indian Ocean and mixes with the Surrounding Ocean where longitude is one hundred and thirty-four degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude twelve degrees thirty minutes behind the Equator, according to what is reported from Ptolemy. The city of al-Mayd is where longitude is one hundred and sixty-three degrees and a minute and latitude four degrees. Travelers used to aim for it in ancient times, then diverted from it to the Island of Java. At the mixing of the two seas is the mouth of Khamdan, the greatest river of China. On its east and west in this part is the city of Khamdan, one of the most famous cities of China behind the Equator. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and sixty-eight degrees and latitude one degree. On its west is the city of Qaytaghur, one of the famous cities of China, its latitude behind the Equator is six degrees. Khamdan is two degrees longer (in longitude). China has settlements and cities east of this center, but they are not famous. At the mixing of the Indian Ocean with the Surrounding Ocean, an arm takes from it to the South. Separating it from the Ocean is the Great Mountain of Clouds (Jabal al-Sahab), a mountain constantly covered by clouds due to its height. It is said it was named so because black clouds emerge from the Island of Clouds beneath it, stirring up the sea with their winds and drowning what is upon it. The sea in this place at the end of Part Ten seems separate from the Indian Ocean and the Surrounding Ocean and is called the Sea of Waq Waq. In it are islands; first is the Island of Clouds, between its northern tip and the Equator is about five degrees. South of it is the Island of al-Dajjal (Antichrist), its length towards the South. The Island of Waq Waq is at the end of habitation of this island towards the East. Separating its sea from the Surrounding Ocean is the Mountain of the Big Head (Jabal al-Ras al-Kabir), which is large. Al-Masudi recounted that in it are trees from which grows a plant like the Abranj (?) and girls are born from it hanging by their hair. One of them cries "Waq Waq"; if their hair is cut and they are separated from the tree, they die. It is said gold is abundant in this island. These islands surround the Mountain of Conquest (Jabal al-Fath), inhabited by deformed blacks who cut off the road for people and eat them. None of the neighbors enter the islands of this sea. Talk about its inhabitants and the Island of al-Dajjal is like fables, so Glory be to the Creator. First Clime: Its inhabitants are black (Sudan). Its latitude is sixteen degrees and twenty-seven minutes. It consists of ten parts:

Part One: In it appears the Surrounding Ocean (Atlantic) as reported from Ptolemy where longitude is one degree and latitude ten minutes. From there are the Eternal Islands (Canary Islands) in the seas depicted in geography. They are six, occupying the entire latitudinal strip of the First Clime and a little of the Second. From these islands, Ptolemy took longitudes, just as he took latitudes from the Equator. They are not inhabited, but Alexander the Two-Horned (Dhul-Qarnayn) reached them and attempted to travel across (their sea) but could not achieve what he wanted, either due to vortices and thick fog or fear of getting lost and perishing in nothingness. Then he placed a lighthouse on each island to guide those who are lost and wrote on each one: No passage behind me. There is much to say about them. Ibn Fatimah said: The Islands of Happiness (Fortunate Isles) are between the Eternal Islands and the mainland, scattered in the First, Second, and Third Climes. They are twenty-four islands. Talk about them is like myths. The Surrounding Ocean gradually rises in this part until the mouth of the Nile that passes through Ghana is located where longitude is ten degrees twenty minutes and latitude fourteen degrees. In front of the Nile mouth in the Surrounding Ocean is the Island of Salt; its length from North to South is two degrees and a little, and its width half a degree. At its southern tip on the sea is the city of Awlil, which is free/open like the cities of the Indians, containing many types of reeds and plants. Its people live on fish and turtles, and their trade is salt; they go up with it in boats to the lands on the banks of the Nile. They said there is no salt pan in the lands of Sudan other than it. Next to this island is the Island of Ambergris; between them is a strait measuring half a degree. Between it and the mainland is less than that. Its length is two degrees and its width at the top three degrees. It is also called the Island of Turtles since there are many of them. The people of those lands hunt them, dry their meat, and travel with it. They also find much ambergris in this island. The first thing you encounter on the west of the Nile from the cities of Takrur is the city of Qalanbu, a famous port. In the time of Abu Ubayd al-Bakri, it belonged to the disbelievers. As for our time, no city on the bank of the Nile in the land of Takrur remains except that Islam has entered it, and all belong to the Sultan of Takrur. Its capital is on both sides of the Nile and is named Takrur, by which they are known. Their lineage is called Maghzawa. They are two sections: a section that became urbanized and inhabits cities, and a section roaming in the deserts. Most of their domains are on the northern side of the Nile, and they have little in the south; most of it is the domains of Lamlam, who are neglected disbelievers who eat people. The location of the city of Takrur is where longitude is seventeen degrees and latitude thirteen and a half degrees and minutes. Its ruler captures slaves from Lamlam, who are nomads. They have a city in books like a village called Muyah, containing the house of their Dakakir, which are idols, situated on the Surrounding Ocean where latitude is six degrees.

Part Two of the First Clime: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Barisa, one of the most famous lands of Takrur. If the authority of Takrur weakens, the ruler of Barisa becomes independent. Travelers frequent it. It is the last of the cities of Takrur on the north of the Nile, where longitude is twenty-two degrees and latitude three and a half degrees. The predominant clothing of the Takrur blacks and others is skins. If one of them is modest, the skin is tanned. Those who mix with Whites and specialize adopt clothing of wool and cotton, which is imported for them. Their predominant food is pulses (qataniya) and unfermented porridges. Bread is not found among them except as a novelty with kings who adopt the manners of Whites. Their horses are short and not fast. Their weapons are ebony clubs—ebony is plentiful on the Nile and used for firewood—and they have bows and arrows made of thorny reeds from which they make bowstrings. In their lands is the cotton tree. No one builds with gypsum and brick except a king or one permitted by him among the wealthy and elite. Their nomads are naked. The Muslims among them cover their private parts with bones or skins, while the disbelievers do not cover themselves. East and north of Barisa, the Lami River pours in, descending from the mountains south of the city of Lami. This city is like a village under the obedience of the disbelievers of Lamlam. Its people are Jews; their race is known in slavery in the Maghreb. The Lami Mountain extends from west to east for eight stages. From its western end, the mentioned Lami River exits, passing through their settlements until it pours into the Nile. From its eastern end, the Malal River exits and curves to pass the city of Malal, one of the cities of the neglected disbelievers. The latitude of the city of Lami is ten degrees, and its longitude aligns with the longitude of Barisa. The longitude of Malal is twenty-six degrees. Its river pours into the Nile from the direction of the city of Dirham, a city of the neglected disbelievers, located in the middle of the distance between Lami and Malal. East of what was mentioned is the River "al-Hu", one of the rivers mentioned by Ptolemy, descending from Mount al-Hu, which extends behind the Equator. The head of this mountain is where longitude is thirty-two degrees and latitude nine degrees behind the Line. It extends from there crossing the Line by two degrees and minutes. A branch exits from it with the Line, two degrees long. From its western head, the mentioned river exits, twisting north like the letter Nun (ن), then descends to the Nile where longitude at the city of Malal is two and a half degrees. On the banks of this river from its source to near its mouth are the domains of Namnam, brothers of Lamlam in lineage and similar in actions. East of it by miles is Mount Samaqdi, large and overlooking, containing drugs and plants beneficial to those lands. A multitude of neglected disbelieving blacks known as Samaqdi take refuge in it, and the city of Samaqdi is known by them. It is at the peak of this mountain where longitude is thirty degrees and latitude eight degrees. The city of Ghana on the banks of the Nile is located in that part where longitude is twenty-nine degrees and latitude ten degrees fifteen minutes. In it resides the Sultan of Ghana, a descendant of Al-Hussein bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. He has a large [...] containing a hole where he ties his horse, boasting of that over other kings of Sudan. He wages much jihad against the disbelievers, and his house is known for that. East of the city of Samaqdi is the Island of Gold (Jazirat al-Tibr). Its western head is where longitude is thirty-one degrees, and its eastern head is where longitude is thirty-six and a half degrees. Its center in latitude aligns with Ghana, and its position is two degrees. In this island, they find much gold dust (Tibr) glittering at night when the excess waters recede from its sand. On this island are famous cities, including the city of Samgharah. On this northern arm at the end of this part is the most famous city of gold in this part after Ghana, which is Ghiyaru. It is on a bay exiting from the south of the island's Nile where longitude is thirty-four degrees and latitude fifteen degrees. South of the Nile of Ghana are the previously mentioned domains of Namnam, and north of it are the domains of Wangara (Wanqarah), who are the blacks of the land, and Islam has spread among them.

Part Three of the First Clime: The first thing you encounter is Mount Thala. Its southern head is in Lake Kuri (Lake Chad) from which the Nile exits, and from its northern head the Nile of Ghana exits. To its east is the land of Kawkaw (Gao), named after the city of the land's ruler. He is one of the disbelieving Sudan. Mount Kawkaw is proverbial. It faces the Muslims of Ghana from its west and the Muslims of Kanem from its east. The city of Kawkaw is east of the river attributed to it, where longitude is forty-four degrees and latitude ten degrees fifteen minutes. The source of the river of Kawkaw, branching west from the Nile, is from Mount Maquris (?). It is one of the mountains mentioned by Ptolemy; its northern limit is where longitude is forty-three degrees thirty-five minutes, and the latitude exits from the First Clime to the Second. It connects to Mount Badi, which connects to Lake Kuri from which the Nile exits. It has been said that the river of Kawkaw draws its substance from Lake Kuri, and that much water sinks from it into this mountain, then the river of Kawkaw exits from it north of it, aligning with the Nile of Ghana until it sinks into sands in the Second Part aligning with the middle of the Island of Gold. On its two banks are the domains of Kawkaw, who are naked and neglected. At its western end are the domains of Na'amah, black Berbers of the Kawkaw type. Between Kawkaw and the city of Badi, from whose south the Nile of Ghana exits, and Kawkaw are four degrees. Its exit is from where longitude is forty-eight degrees and latitude six and a half degrees. Ibn Fatimah said: Thus, the distance of its flow from Lake Kuri to the Surrounding Ocean, according to its meanderings, is about three thousand miles. In this Third Part is Lake Kuri, from which the Nile of Egypt, the Nile of Mogadishu, and the Nile of Ghana exit. The descent of the lake rivers to it at the touching of the Equator has been mentioned. Its ascent above the Line revolves around half a degree, increasing or decreasing slightly. Its length is a thousand miles. Its eastern head is where longitude is fifty-one degrees, and its western end is with the line of the Third Part. Its width at the head is nine and a half degrees, then it proceeds gradually as drawn until the width of its middle is four hundred and fifty miles, and the width of its tail is three hundred and sixty miles.

Ibn Fatimah said: I have not seen anyone who saw its (south) side; rather, the Kanemites and their neighbors whom we met on the northern side described it. It is surrounded on all sides by tyrannical nations of disbelieving Sudan who eat people, and no religion reminds them of the inhabitants of the northern side. Among them is Badi. Their city is known by them, and from beneath it exits the Nile of Ghana. Their city is around it. Neighboring it from the western side are the Jabi, who file their teeth. If one of them dies, they give him to their neighbors (to eat), and their neighbors do the same with them. On the south of the lake are the Ankarar, and on its east are the Kuri, to whom the lake is attributed. East of the city of Badi, belonging to the Muslim Kanem, is the city of Jajah. It is the seat of a separate kingdom with cities and lands, currently belonging to the Sultan of Kanem. It is described as fertile with abundant goods, containing peacocks, parrots, spotted chickens, and piebald sheep the size of small donkeys with forms different from our rams. Giraffes are plentiful in the land of Jajah. East of its city, on the corner of the lake, is al-Maghza (The Place of Raid?), where the arsenal of Kanem is located. He often raids from there in his fleet the lands of the disbelievers on the sides of this lake, intercepting their boats, killing and taking captives. The location of the city of Jajah is where longitude is forty-eight degrees twenty minutes and latitude seven degrees, aligned with the corner of the lake where longitude is fifty-one degrees. Among the famous cities of Kanem is Manan, latitude thirteen degrees. East and south of it is the capital of Kanem, Jimi, where longitude is fifty-three degrees and nine minutes. In it is the Sultan of Kanem, famous for Jihad and charitable acts, Muhammadi, a descendant of Sayf ibn Dhi Yazan. The capital of his disbelieving ancestors before they converted was the city of Manan. Then his fourth grandfather converted at the hands of Islamic jurists in the land of Kanem. This Sultan has there the likes of the Sultanate of Tajuh, the Kingdom of Kawar, and the Kingdom of Fezzan. God has supported him and increased his offspring and armies. Clothes are brought to him from the Tunisian capital. He has jurists with him. In the direction of Jimi at the end of this part, he has al-Rudayni, containing Sabin belonging to him and Samtanzah. It is on the west of the Nile coming to Egypt. Between it and Jimi is forty miles. Their fruits do not resemble our fruits; pomegranates and peaches are found abundantly among them. They have cultivated sugar cane, which grew slightly well there, but only the Sultan exploits it, as well as grapes and wheat. The exit of the Egyptian Nile in this part is from Lake Kuri where longitude is fifty-one degrees and latitude six degrees. At its outburst from the lake is the city of Kuri belonging to the Sudan who eat people, located north of it. Its width is at Mount Maqsim extending from the first southeastern corner of the lake. From under this mountain also exits the Nile of Mogadishu near the Equator and from behind the Line. They mentioned that in Lake Kuri is Mount Luratus, located in this Third Part. Ptolemy mentioned that it begins where longitude is forty-three degrees and latitude three degrees twenty minutes, and ends where longitude is thirty-eight degrees forty-five minutes and latitude one. It is also called the Mountain of Gold. The Sudan claim that the gold found in the lands of the Nile during its flood is from the mines of this mountain. No one can approach it due to the abundance of snakes and deadly beasts. Its coastal sides are full of crocodiles and hippopotamuses (horses of the Nile). It is said that the hippopotamus is not hunted in this lake, but rather in the Nile of Ghana and the Nile of Nubia. East of Mount Maquris, separating Kanem and Kawkaw, are the domains of Kanem and their followers among the Berbers who converted at the hands of the Sultan of Kanem. They are his slaves; he raids with them and benefits from their camels that filled those regions in the domains of Manan. East of Manan are the domains of the Zaghawa, mostly Muslims under the obedience of the Kanemi. North of Manan and the domains of Kanem are the domains of the Kawar. Their famous city is located in the Third Clime; they are Muslims under the obedience of the Kanemi.

Part Four of the First Clime: The Western Nile passes from its beginning for three degrees in the land of Bantah, who are black disbelievers separating Kanem and Nubia. Then it dives into the sands where the latitude is nine degrees. It passes underground, according to their claim, winding from South to North, appearing only where longitude is fifty-eight degrees and latitude eleven degrees. It curves like a bow with its back to the East. To its west lies the capital of Nubia, Dongola (Dunqulah), where longitude is fifty-eight degrees and minutes and latitude four degrees fifteen minutes. South of it, among the cities of Nubia, is Nuwabah, after which they are named. It is where longitude is fifty-eight degrees thirty minutes and latitude nine degrees. South and west of it are the domains of the Zanj of Nubia whose capital is Kushah behind the Line. The Nubians are Christians. West and north of Dongola, among their cities mentioned in books, is Alwa, located east and north of the Nile. Between it and Dongola is one hundred and seventy miles, where longitude is fifty-seven degrees and latitude sixteen degrees minus minutes. West of Alwa, the Nile bends greatly, returning to the West until it enters the Third Part from which it exited, ending at half a degree, then descends from there to the Second Clime. On its banks are settlements of Nubia. Between its southern east and Tajuh, the capital of the Zaghawa, is one hundred miles. The location of this city is where longitude is fifty-five degrees and latitude fourteen degrees. Its people have converted to Islam and entered the obedience of the Kanemi. South of it is the city of Zaghawa where longitude is fifty-four degrees and latitude eleven and a half degrees. The domains of the Tajuh and Zaghawa extend in the distance between the arc of the Nile from South to North. They are one race, but sovereignty, good appearance, and morals are with the Tajuh. They are disbelievers rebellious against the Kanemi, frequenting the deserts and mountains in the First and Second Climes. Ibn Fatimah mentioned that the kings of Kanem and Tajuh fled with their capitals away from the Nile only because of mosquitoes, for they abound near the Nile and their harm is severe on humans and horses. They have springs in the sands and waters drawn from the Nile during the days of flood.

In this Fourth Part, among the cities of Abyssinia (Habasha) mentioned in books is Hanbiyah, where longitude is fifty-eight degrees and latitude three degrees. East of it is the land of Kazlah. They are famous in the lands of Abyssinia, and their race is desired. The Abyssinians generally are the best race of the Sudan, and the eunuchs of kings and notables are from them. They are Christians, and among them on the coast are Muslims. The land of Kazlah is from the beginning of the Equator neighboring the Zanj of Abyssinia to the south of Mount Muris, from whose gold and silver mines they claimed the people of Hanbiyah and those regions live. It is four days from Hanbiyah. In its east and north, it starts from there and passes eastward deviating to the North until it cuts the Nile of Abyssinia and ends at their sea. East and south of Kazlah is Lake Hawaras, attributed to a nation of Abyssinian Zanj, naked and wild. It is said gold and tin (Raṣāṣ Qal'ī) are plentiful in their land. Ibn Fatimah said: It is reported from Ptolemy that the center of this lake is on the Equator where longitude is sixty-two degrees and its radius from every side to the center is two degrees. The Nile of Abyssinia exits from it, resembling the Nile of Egypt in its increase during the days of river deficiency and in the presence of crocodiles and hippopotamuses. That is where longitude is sixty-one degrees and latitude two degrees. On its east next to the lake, among their cities mentioned in books, is al-Naja'ah. It passes to the North, so upon it where longitude is sixty-two degrees and latitude six degrees is Maraqatah. North of it is the Mountain of Mines previously mentioned. The city is east of the Nile. North of the mountain is the land of its sorcerers from the Abyssinian races mentioned, and their settlements extend along this Nile on both sides. East of it, among the famous cities of Abyssinia, is Kalghur. It is a gathering place for them from every direction, and a meeting point for those wanting the sea, the Nile, or the wilderness. Its location is where longitude is sixty-three and latitude eleven degrees. North of its sorcerers from the Nile to the sea is the land of Khasah. They are disparaged among the Abyssinian races. It is famous about them that they castrate whoever falls into their hands and give human males as their dowries, boasting of that. East of them to the sea is Samhar, a land where the long Samhari spears (Qana) are found. A strange thing about them is that if they rub against each other, fire sparks from them, burning all or a group of them depending on proximity and wind assistance. Gazelles are plentiful in the land of Samhar. From their skins, they strap onto horses instead of saddles and ride them. Their fighting is with the mentioned Samhari spears, and they are skilled in stabbing and playing with them. They claim that people like Turks, white with hair, reach them from the South and fight them. If this is true, the climes in the South are connected like the climes in the North; discussion on that is lengthy. In their land is the rhinoceros (Karkadann); it has two horns on its forehead, one longer than the other. It is a harmful animal hunted by a horseman running behind it and striking its legs with a sword so it falls. If he does not guard against it, the rhinoceros falls on him and kills him with his horse. They eat its meat. Also on their Nile are lions and elephants. East of Kalghur with a deviation to the North is the city of Najbah, to which the Najibiyah camels are attributed. That is where longitude is sixty-five degrees and latitude twelve degrees. West of it is Mount Khamahin; this stone is found there. It was precious to the Persians; they made seals from it and medicated with water if rubbed in it due to the heat of the Khamahin. It is called mineral sandalwood and enters the category of sandalwood in treating hot ailments. The length of this mountain is one hundred miles from South to North with a curve as it passes north to the East. The first city of Abyssinia you encounter on the Indian Ocean from its western coast, bordering the land of Berbera mentioned before, behind the Equator, is the city of Bata. It is famous on the tongues of Abyssinians in our lands. It is two degrees from the Line, and its longitude is sixty-four and a half degrees. North of it, among their cities at one hundred miles, is Baqsali on a bay entering the West about fifty miles. North of it is Manqubah, which is the mountain of the continuous inlet to the East where longitude is sixty-five degrees and latitude eight degrees thirty minutes. At its two ends, Mount Maquris enters the sea. North of it, among the famous cities of Abyssinia, is the land of Zayla (Zeila). Its people are Muslims who frequent Hajj and travel to the coast of Aden and Zabid. It is a place of landing and takeoff. From it, Abyssinian slaves are distributed to the coastal Islamic lands. Its location is on a corner of the sea where the latitude of its western and northern ends terminates, where longitude is sixty-six degrees and latitude eleven degrees minus minutes. Mentioned in books among the islands of this sea near the coast is the Island of Qanbalu. Between it and Baqsali is two and a half degrees.

Its southern tip is aligned with it, and its length is close to its width, about two degrees. Between its northeastern corner and Aden is four and a half degrees. It was inhabited but is now a ruin where ships that take precaution shelter, needing water and firewood. It was mentioned that the end of the Indian Ocean where the mentioned Abyssinian cities are located is entirely, near the coasts, connected reefs over which water splashes up to Bab al-Mandab. Only small boats travel there, and perhaps winds overcome them and break them on those rocks. The width of the tail of the Indian Ocean from Bab al-Mandab to Berbera is eight courses (Majra). Mount Mandab is the separator between the Great Indian Ocean and the Sea of Qulzum (Red Sea) which exits from it. It is small, extending twelve miles from East to West with a deviation to the North. The sea narrows there so a man can see his companion on the other shore. They say it is the measure of two hundred arrows. Travelers call this place Bab al-Mandab, estimating its length with the mountain. It is located where longitude is sixty-eight and a half degrees and latitude eleven degrees and minutes. Ships must pass through it entering and exiting. Some travelers recounted that a large ship took precaution in the fog early in the morning and exited west of Mount Mandab between those reefs, so God saved it, and its safety was considered a rare tale. The Sea of Qulzum, from south to north, when leaving Bab al-Mandab, begins to increase in width slightly, until its width at 'Awan—between it and Tihama of Yemen—is about sixty miles. It is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees and latitude thirteen and a half degrees. It is famous, and its inhabitants are Muslim Abyssinians. It has piebald cows of preserved lineage belonging to its owner, and they patrol on them out of jealousy. If the weather is clear, al-Janah appears from it, a high mountain in the sea. From there to the Island of Dahlak are small islands belonging to the ruler of Yemen and the ruler of Dahlak. The largest and most famous of these islands is Kamaran Island. It is inhabited, belonging to the ruler of Yemen at the end of Part Four in terms of latitude, closer to the mainland of Zabid. East and north of 'Awan on the coast of Yemen in this part, among the famous ports, is Ghalafiqah, the port of Zabid; between them is forty miles. The location of Zabid, the capital of Tihama of Yemen, is where longitude is sixty-seven degrees forty minutes and latitude fifteen and a half degrees. Between Bab al-Mandab and the city of Aden, the famous port of Yemen in the East and West, is three stages of plain and mountain. It is east of it where longitude is seventy degrees and latitude twelve degrees. The sea gradually enters south from Bab al-Mandab to Aden. An inlet enters from its west surrounding much of it so it remains like an island. Ships from Berbera and ships fearing the storm anchor there, but not large ones, as Aden's anchorage is not safe when the sea rages. Mountains extend from its north, and among them lies the ancient capital of Yemen, Sana'a. That is east and north of Aden, where longitude is seventy-one and a half degrees and latitude fourteen and a half degrees. Between it and Aden is the city of Jibla, built by the Sulayhids, the callers of the Ubaydi (Fatimid) mission in Yemen. It is on two rivers; one descends from Mount al-Mudaykhirah, the high mountain north of Sana'a, passes its west and south, then passes its mountain, mixes with the other river, and they pour into the east of Abyan, a famous small town between it and Aden, two small stages. In the mentioned mountains, Yemeni agate (Carnelian), Wars plant, and Cassia fistula are found. On the mountains extending from South to North in this part lies al-Dumluwah, proverbial for its impregnability and fortification; it is north of Aden. North of al-Dumluwah lies al-Juwa, a famous small town on the main mountain road. Al-Mansur ibn Rasul, ruler of Yemen, often stayed there and built a garden and royal buildings. North of it, where longitude is seventy and latitude fourteen and a half degrees, lies Ta'izz, the capital of Yemen in later times. At the top of its mountain is the stronghold that cannot be aspired to, named Sabir. A small stage north of it is al-Janad, famous for unhealthiness (Wakham); no stranger drinks its water without perishing. In its mountains are many monkeys. Part Five of the First Clime:

The first thing you encounter in it are the mountains of Hadramawt, extending from North to South. They have cities of obscure names because they have little luck/prosperity, and riders do not frequent them on land nor ship owners at sea. Its most famous coastal city in books is Las'a, where longitude is seventy-two degrees ten minutes and latitude twelve degrees; between them is forty miles. Between Las'a and Aden is an extended transverse mountain lengthening travel on land; its distance from the sea to the north of Las'a is eighty miles. The capital of Hadramawt is Tarim, in the mountains north of Las'a; between them is ninety miles. North of Tarim, among its cities mentioned in books, is Shanwah, noted for abundant dates; between them is about ninety miles. Sixty miles east of each is al-Khuzaymah. In the East is Zafar, which was the capital of the Tubba's (Himyarite kings), then fell into ruin. It is where longitude is seventy-three degrees and latitude fifteen degrees. Then on the coast, among the cities of al-Shihr—the land of Ambergris and Frankincense—you meet the city of Mirbat. It is on a bay entering North so this city is at longitude seventy-four degrees and latitude fourteen and a half degrees. East of it on the mentioned bay is the modern Zafar (Dhofar), now the capital of the land of al-Shihr and its famous port. Horses of Arabia are brought to it and from it carried to the land of India. Its ruler, Ibn al-Nahun, has taxes on them. It is said that in the land of this city are many Indian drugs like coconut, betel, betel nut, and Amba (Mango), which is like melon with different tastes found in it. The wasteland between it and Qalhat is not traversed due to emptiness and predatory leopards. This large bay is called the Bay of Hashish (Grass); it enters the land from the sea limit about one hundred miles and extends from west to east about three hundred miles. Ships do not exit it except with a land wind. Travelers from India to Aden often fear falling into it. North of this bay are the sands of al-Ahqaf. There lies the grave of Hud, peace be upon him. North of these sands and cities are the Frankincense Mountains extending from West to East. There is no famous city there; rather, its inhabitants are people from Mahra, like wild beasts in appearance and speech. The Mahri camels are attributed to them. They feed them small fish coming out of their sea called al-Wazaf. Inside this part are Martan and Hartan, two islands. The first is the eastern one, inhabited by people speaking the language of 'Ad. South of it is Socotra, a famous island to which the preferred Socotran Aloe is attributed. It is slanted from South to North eastward, its length about one hundred and eighty miles. Between it and al-Ahqaf is about two hundred miles. Its inhabitants are Christians from the remnants of the Greeks who commit piracy at sea on ships. In it is a spring of water said to increase intellect. At the end of the Bay of Hashish to the East is the great high mountain known in books as the Head of the Skull (Ras al-Jumjumah). That place is also known as Ghubb al-Qamar. Ships of Mogadishu aim for this Head and guide themselves by it, as do others. It is said there is also a round mountain there in the shape of the moon below this great mountain. This bay, the mountain enters from it into the sea about one hundred miles and likewise into the land. At its tip are two branches for which sailors call it the Two-Horned (Dhul-Qarnayn). East of the Western Peninsula there is no habitation or mentioned place until you meet in the beginning of Oman its current capital, Qalhat. Its location is where longitude is ninety-nine degrees sixty minutes, and latitude is at the end of the First Clime. In this sea lie the Islands of al-Mand, known for abundant coconut. The greatest is the Island of Kilwa (Kilwa Kisiwani); this is how travelers know it now. They are many islands mentioned by Ptolemy who called them the Island of al-Mand. They are brothers of Hind and Sindh, but were not granted the luck of fame as Hind and Sindh were. Ibn Fatimah mentioned that the Zanj overcame them and drove many of them out to the mainland of Sindh, keeping the rest as subjects.

In this island, among the cities famous in books, are three located on three rivers. The first is Kilwa, containing the ruler of these islands; from it is the takeoff and to it is the landing. It is in the west and south of the island, where longitude is eighty-four and a half degrees, and latitude seven degrees fifty minutes. In the southeast side is the city of al-Mand, and in the northwest is the city of Kank. The circumference of the island is one thousand four hundred miles. It approximates a square shape and has inlets from the sea. West of it are small islands of obscure names. Among its islands mentioned in books is the Island of al-Qatrabah west of it; its length from West to East is one hundred and sixty miles and its width about sixty miles. Its people are a nation on the route to India and the Persian Sea route who constantly intercept ships. The sea between it and the Island of Kilwa is a course and a third. South of it is the Island of Monkeys; it is round with mountains and ravines overrun by monkeys. The people of the neighboring island use tricks to hunt them and carry them to lands to sell. Below this island about one hundred and sixty miles, at the southwest corner of Kilwa Island, between it and the sea is about two courses. South of it, among the islands of Kilwa, is the Island of Karmadah; its circumference is about three hundred and thirty miles. Its people are black pirates with their ships. East of it is the Island of the Volcano (al-Burkan); in it is a mountain where fire never ceases burning at night and smoke rises by day, like the volcano of Sicily. Its inhabitants are Zanj, and its circumference is about three hundred miles. Following these islands adjacent to Kilwa are the Islands of al-Zanij (Zabaj/Zanj?), famous on the tongues of travelers. The greatest is the Island of Sarbazah (Srivijaya/Sumatra?); its length from North to South is four hundred miles, and its width at each end, South and North, is about one hundred and sixty miles. It has inlets from the sea. Its city Sarbazah is in its center; a bay from the sea enters it, and it is on a river. Its location is where longitude is eighty-eight and a half degrees and latitude three degrees forty minutes. It has other unmentioned cities. After the Islands of al-Zabaj is the Island of Anfujah. Its ruler has equipment and numbers with which he dominates most times and seizes the Islands of al-Zabaj because of it. In the southern side is the city of Anjabah. Al-Bayhaqi said: "Most of the livelihood of the people of these islands is from bananas." The length of the Island of Anfujah is about one hundred and seventy miles and its width revolves around ninety miles. The width of the strait between it and the Island of Sarbazah is half a course. South and east of Sarbazah are countless small islands of al-Zabaj. Most are inhabited by blacks. Few of these islands fall into this Fifth Part. At its end is the Equator, and the Dome of Arin (Uzin), previously mentioned. Part Six: All of it is sea containing the Diba Islands (Maldives/Laccadives). They are many, the largest being the Island of Duwaybi, known by that on the tongues of travelers. Its city is where longitude is ninety-two degrees and latitude fifteen degrees twenty minutes. The length of the island from West to East is two hundred and twenty miles. Its width revolves around one hundred and forty miles. Most inhabitants of this island are descendants of Arabs; they are Muslims. Travelers to India land with them and buy sugar cane from them. Most of their cane is black in color. Some of these islands fall into the Second Clime. Most of the large island falls into it. Between it and the mainland of Sindh is about a course and a half. Part Seven: Most of it contains the Coconut Islands counted as part of the work of Serendib. They are many, and none are mentioned in books except the Island of Balq. It was mentioned behind the Line, just as the Island of Serendib was mentioned sharing between what is south of the Equator and north of it. Located on the northern coast of this part, among the cities of India famous on the tongues of travelers, is Somnath. It is from the lands of Gujarat, also known as the lands of al-Lar. Its location is in an inlet in the sea, so ships from Aden land there often because it is not in a bay (shallow/dangerous). It has a large bay whose substance descends from the large mountain north of it to its east. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and twenty degrees and latitude fifteen degrees. East of it, at the end of the First Clime by a degree in longitude, is the city of Tana (Thana). It is the last of the famous cities of al-Lar on the tongues of merchants. The people of this Indian coast are all disbelievers who worship idols (Abdad). Muslims live with them, and their ships travel to them. Most of what they worship is the idol of Somnath; it is venerated by Indians who travel to it from regions. It has a white building visible to ships at sea from afar. Most of what grows in the land of al-Lar is Brazilwood (Baqjam), and from it Lac (Lakk) is brought, which is the gum of their trees.

Part Eight: The first thing you encounter from the beginning of its line, where latitude is fifteen degrees, among the famous cities of Pepper in the land of Malabar, is the city of Saymur. It is on a bay and an inlet to its west and inside it to the South. The most famous on the tongues of travelers in this sea is Faknur (Bakanur). It is on an inlet to its east where longitude is one hundred and twenty-nine degrees and latitude thirteen degrees minus two minutes. In its direction regarding latitude is Manjarur (Mangalore); between them in longitude is two degrees, and it has an inlet to its west. About two courses from Manjarur is the Ghat, from which ships descend, for if they fall into its paths they get lost and find no way out unless God facilitates it for them. They are mountains in the sea where the path is from a mile to fifty miles, and its end is blocked with no escape; stories about it are strange. It is from the direction of this city mentioned in the Second Clime. East of Manjarur in a direction intended by ships is Kawlam (Quilon). It is the last of the Pepper lands and famous on the tongues of travelers; ginger is often attributed to it. It is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-four degrees, and latitude twelve degrees. From it to the Island of Ceylon (Saylan) is two courses. This island is long and wide. Ibn Fatimah said: The investigation regarding it states its length is six hundred miles and its width approximates that, so its circumference is over two thousand miles. It has cavities from the sea and unrenowned cities. Mentioned in books is al-Ramin, by which it was known in ancient times. Famous on the tongues of travelers is Saylan; to it, Ceylonese Oud is attributed, though not of the highest quality. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-nine degrees twenty minutes, and latitude seven and a half degrees. Both cities are on an inlet descending from a mountain in its northwestern corner; between them is two hundred and fifty miles. In this island is the Rhinoceros. In its outskirts are the Naked Ones who leap onto trees due to their lightness. Ptolemy called it the Island of the Naked. South of it are the Islands of al-Najbalus (Nicobar?); they are several, the largest being three. Their people are deformed naked blacks who intercept travelers, and among them are those who eat people. They neighbor the Equator, and the width of the sea between them and the Island of Ceylon is about two courses.

Part Nine: The first Indian Islands you meet is the Island of Nakwarah (Nicobar). It is among the islands famous on the tongues of travelers; its length is about one hundred miles and its width half that. Between it and the sea where the land of Barqali is, is about half a course. Between it and the beginning of this part is a degree. South of it is the Island of Andaman; between them is about two courses, and it is of similar size. In all of them, elephants are found and ivory is prepared from them. East of these two islands, with the entry to the West from the line of the Second Clime, are two cities of the cities of al-Ramin on a bay of the sea; the bay between them is where longitude is one hundred and forty-nine degrees. East and south of that are the Islands of al-Mahraj (Maharaja/Srivijaya). They are many and mentioned in books. Good gold is found in them. Their ruler is one of the richest kings of India and has the most elephants. His large island, containing the city of al-Mahraj, is two hundred miles long and nearly one hundred miles wide. The city is at its western end where longitude is one hundred and fifty-one degrees and latitude twelve and a half degrees. East of the city is an inlet with its source from a mountain to its north. It is said this king's palace is on a wide stream whose bottom is paved with silver and bounded at both ends so nothing placed in it exits. The custom of every king among them since owning these islands is that the king throws a brick of gold every year. When he dies, the bricks are counted, the length of his reign is known, one brick is returned, and the rest is spent on the soldiers during this incumbent king's reign. The single brick has a place and the others have a place. If they want to know how many kings ruled them, they count the single bricks with a rod. They do not remove them from their place; rather, it is in a spot where the sun shines, so that gold glitters through the water. There are gems of ruby and emerald and large pearls, with which he competes with kings and boasts over them. It is mentioned that the place is the treasury of these stores. They said: It is not known that this island has transferred from one lineage to another; they boast of that over their neighbors. Al-Mahraj is a title they inherit. South of the Island of al-Mahraj is the Island of al-Jawah (Java) the Large, famous, intended by ships. Most of what is in it is Indian spices and its people are famous for good conduct with travelers. Its western beginning is where longitude is one hundred and forty-four degrees. In that corner, among its cities famous on the tongues of merchants, is Lamri (Lamuri), and the latitude there is five degrees. South of it in the southwestern corner is the city of Fansur, to which Fansuri Camphor is attributed. It aligns with the other in longitude, and its latitude is one and a half degrees. The Camphor Mountains extend from the city to near the end of the island from west to east. In the middle of the island on the Camphor Mountains is its capital, the city of al-Jawah. In it is the ruler of the island and the adjacent islands attributed to it. To this city is attributed the black, solid Javanese Oud that sinks in water as if it were a pebble; it is said to be the root of the Oud tree. The location of this city is where longitude is one hundred and forty-nine degrees twenty minutes and latitude three degrees. In the southeast corner is the city of Kalah (Kedah/Klang?), famous on the tongues of travelers. To it is attributed the preferred Kalahi (tin/lead) in its rods and paints. It is said they make their ships from that, so there is nothing like them in the Indian Ocean. This city is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-four degrees twelve minutes. In the northeast side is the city of Malayur, famous and intended for landing and takeoff. Its longitude approximates the longitude of Kalah, and its latitude approximates the latitude of Lamri. Every city mentioned in this island is on an inlet. The length of this island is eight hundred miles from West to East, and its width revolves around three hundred and forty miles. When ships overlooking China depart from it, two ends appear to the right and left; the width of the sea between them is about two miles. The water there is not deep; that place is called al-Bintan. There are small islands from which black thieves emerge with poisoned arrows and aggressive boats; they take loot but do not take people. Some trustworthy travelers said: We had two ships; the goods were in one and I in the other. God saved the ship I was in until He brought me to China. He said: I saw there a white bondwoman containing [...] from the land, so I marveled at her being there with those disbelievers. If travelers exit al-Bintan, they give good news of safety. One overlooking al-Bintan encounters the Islands of Qamarun. In the largest of them is the King's city, east of the city of al-Jawah. The city's name is Qamarun. Their lineage was mentioned in the Island of al-Qamar. This island is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-eight degrees

and latitude six degrees. It has many small islands to its west. The length of the largest is about four hundred miles and its width revolves around one hundred miles. West of its small islands are islands annexed to Java containing Indian spices and Kalahi tin (lead). Among them is the Island of the Volcano mentioned before. And among them are the Islands of the Abyss whose bottom cannot be reached. After the northern Islands of Qamarun are the Camphor Mountains; they are innumerable, extending into the sea. Ships travel from them to China. They belong to Qamarun, but the owners of China have conquered them or what is near their coast. The trees in it are like willow trees in their leaves, but a single tree shades a hundred men. Camphor is its gum. It is said they tap the tree and pieces of camphor flow from it, then the tree dies afterwards. One who traveled among these mountains said: I saw them at night like stars in the sky illuminating from them. I asked about it and was told: In every mountain of them is a temple (Buddha/Bud) having people who worship God in it, and they revive the night with lamps for the wayfarers. [Repetition of text from "six degrees..." due to source error].

Part Ten: The first thing you encounter in it are the Islands of China. The first, from the side of the Chinese coast to the northern direction, is Sandarfulat (Campa ports/Pulo Condore?), one of the islands mentioned in books. Between it and the Chinese coast is less than two courses. Its length is about two hundred miles. Its widest part is its northern head, about one hundred and fifty miles. South of it is the Island of al-Sanf (Champa), famous in books, to which the noblest Oud (Agarwood) is attributed. It is said to be like wax in which writing can be imprinted, and it is white. The kings of China do not leave it for others. The length of this island from West to East is about two hundred miles, and the width is less than that. The city of al-Sanf is where longitude is one hundred and sixty-two degrees and latitude six degrees. West of it is the Island of Qamar (Khmer?), to which Qamari Oud is attributed; it is inferior to Sanfi and superior to others. The width of the sea between them is less than a course. It is close to the Island of al-Sanf in length and width. The city of Qamar's longitude is one hundred and sixty-six degrees and latitude two degrees. East of these three islands are the small Islands of China; they are many, extending from the North to the end of habitation in the South. The end of the Indian Ocean known as the Green Sea is east of these islands. The longitude there is about one hundred and sixty-seven and a half degrees. Between this Green Sea and the Black Surrounding Ocean (Pacific/unknown) remains land. In its west along the east of the sea passes Khamdan, which is one of the world's great rivers with abundant water. There is no river in China longer or wider than it. Its source is from the Great Mountain separating China and the Turks along the line of the Fourth Clime. Its mouth is where the Indian Ocean mixes with the Surrounding Ocean at the end of habitation in the South. Its distance is about three thousand miles. On it are a large number of cities. Located on it in this Tenth Part is the city of Qantu (Canton/Guangzhou?), where longitude is sixty-nine degrees [sic, likely 169] and latitude eleven degrees. South of it on its east also is the city of Susah; between them is sixteen stages. They are close in longitude; Susah is further east where latitude is two degrees. Three large rivers pour from the rivers of China into the Surrounding Ocean east of Khamdan. Located in the Surrounding Ocean at the far end of this part are the Sila Islands (Korea/Japan). They are like the Eternal Islands in the Surrounding Ocean; there is no habitation behind them. But these are inhabited, possessing fertility and bounties. The last of them to the East is the Island of Sanji, which has the idols indicating "No passage behind me." Its eastern end is where longitude is one hundred and eighty degrees. South of these islands is the Island of Silver. Ptolemy mentioned it and its river. It is said its land has much silver. Beside it at the furthest habitation in the East is the Island of Ruby (Yaqut). The Great Mountain mentioned by Ptolemy encircles it from inside. It is said to be like Mount Rahun in Serendib, where varieties of ruby are found. The end of this part is with the Equator. Second Clime: Inhabitants of what neighbors the First Clime are black, and what neighbors the Third Clime are brown. Its width is twenty-four degrees thirty-one minutes from the Equator, and its breadth (extent) is eight degrees four minutes. Part One: Located in it is the sixth island of the Eternal Islands and four of the Islands of Happiness. The ascent of the Surrounding Ocean in it eastward ends where longitude is ten degrees. Then the Gulf of Tunny (Tuna) ascends from the Second Clime three degrees; its width is less than two degrees. It is called the Green Gulf because it contains reefs and much green grass (seaweed), and in it is the school of Tunny. It enters once into the Sea of the Romans (Mediterranean); people claim it makes pilgrimage to a known stone in the islands of the sea then returns. The people of the coasts of the Berber lands and Andalusia live off it; they dry it and preserve it as jerked meat, carrying it to lands where it sells for the highest price during the time of grapes and figs. Ibn Fatimah mentioned that he rode the Surrounding Ocean once at Nul Lamta. The ship was breached, so he fell into fog and reefs. The sailors got lost and did not know where they were until they left the large ship and took provisions in the small boat. They dragged it over the grass and at times rowed with oars until they ended up after a while at the bottom of this gulf. They witnessed the Tunny in it and its abundance, which amazed them, as well as white birds. They did not reach land until provisions were nearly exhausted. When they ended up under the Shining Mountain (Jabal al-Lamma'), the Berbers of Gudala signaled them not to approach the mountain. They did not know the reason, so they took north away from it until they exited its limit.

When they went out to the coast, they did not understand the language of Gudala until a person came who understood both languages. He asked them about their straying, and they informed him. The people of the boat asked about their warning against the Shining Mountain. They said: It is all deadly, lethal snakes. The stranger sees it shining with stones of beautiful colors and is deceived into approaching it, then its snakes destroy him. They gave them the good news of safety and bought the boat from them. They traveled with them to the city of Taghira, the capital of Gudala, where longitude is eleven degrees and latitude twenty degrees. They stayed with them drinking she-camel milk and eating dried camel meat until their departure to Nul was arranged, so they left with them. He said: Their land, despite being desert and sand, has good sugar cane due to the five rivers descending from the Shining Mountain. Ptolemy mentioned them and reported that the middle river is known as the River of Snakes. They are plentiful near the Shining Mountain and the connecting mountains. God sent them as a punishment on the people of those regions, but they turned them into a blessing, as they prefer eating them over chicken. Connected in this part to the Shining Mountain is the Mountain of Lamtuna, where the Sultanate of the Veiled Ones (Almoravids) was. It extends where longitude is fifteen degrees and latitude three degrees from the line of the Second Clime, passing east taking to the North until it exceeds the Second Clime. In its west is their capital Azqi. Its longitude is fourteen and a half degrees and minutes, and its latitude twenty-two degrees. From it, one enters the Desert of the Lamt (Oryx/Antelope) which is between these lands and the lands of Sudan. Al-Bakri mentioned that this city is in the mountain; it is a fortress with palm trees. From this animal, the Lamt, the impregnable Lamt shields are made and tanned in the city of Kawkadam. They subsist on she-camel milk. This city is north and west of Azqi; between them is eight days. Between it and the Line from which the Third Clime exits is a degree and a half. It belongs to the Muslim Massufa. Their mountain to its east connects to the Shining Mountain, which takes to the North until it connects to Mount Gazula. This mountain is long, from the Surrounding Ocean until it ends where longitude is twelve degrees and latitude is with the line of the Third Clime. In its south is the capital of Gazula, the city of Taghawost. Between it and the line of the Third is a degree. Between it and the Surrounding Ocean is Gazula. West of it is the city of Lamta Nul. It is where longitude is seven and a half degrees. Between it and the line of the Third Clime is half a degree. It has a large famous river descending from Mount Lamta east of it by two stages, and from its south and west until it crosses the line of the Third Clime and descends into the Surrounding Ocean. Between it and Lamta Nul is three stages. The sea continues after ascending east; whenever it takes north from the five rivers, it descends west until it is below Nul where the line of the Third Clime is at longitude six degrees. The end of this part in the desert is the Fortress of Salt (Hisn al-Milh), built on mineral salt. From it, travelers take salt to the lands of Sudan. Between it and the capital of Lamtuna, Azqi, is seven days. Between it and the line of the Second Clime is three and a half degrees. Part Two: Ibn Fatimah said: In its position, there is no water, pasture, or habitation, but flowing sands and misleading, obliterated paths. Most of what is in it is the Lamt (oryx); it is patient against thirst and resembles the gazelle but is thicker. The first thing you meet in this part is the Desert of Nisar (Sir?) which travelers cross between Sijilmasa and Ghana. It is long and wide; they endure intense thirst and glowing heat in it. Perhaps a southern wind blows and dries the water in the skins. So they return to the water in the bellies of camels; they place muzzles on their mouths so they eat nothing. If the wind dries their water, they slaughter them camel by camel and drink what is in their bellies. There is no mentioned city in this part other than Awdaghust. Its inhabitants are a mix of Muslim Berbers, and leadership belongs to Sanhaja. This city and its ruler have prominence in Al-Bakri's book "Al-Masalik wa al-Mamalik". It is with the line of the Second Clime where longitude is twenty-two degrees. At its latitude is the city of Zafun, belonging to disbelieving Sudan. Its ruler has a house among the kings of Sudan. Mount al-Kaf extends in this desert from east of Lamtuna until it aligns with Awdaghust, then curves South, leaving five stages between it and Zafun. They guide themselves by it in those deserts, except they do not approach it due to its many snakes. On its northern back is Mount Mizab, which is high. The people of Warglan take refuge in it if oppression from those in power befalls them. Between them is four days.

Part Three: Ibn Fatimah said: The beginnings of this part follow the rule of deserts, flowing sands, and lack of water, running the course of the part before it, until you meet the edge of Mount Maquris from which the River Kawkaw exits entering the First Clime. Then the land of Kawar; they are Muslim Sudan and their capital is named Kawar. It is now under the obedience of the Sultan of Kanem. Its location is where longitude is forty-five degrees and latitude twenty degrees and minutes. West of it by two stages is the famous Lake Kawar. Its length is twelve miles and its width three miles. It is sweet and deep; in it is the Buri fish (Mullet) which they salt and carry to the lands. East of Kawar by a stage is Lake al-Sul. Its length is twenty miles and width four miles. It is sweet, shallow, in which appears fish with many spines. A spring supplies it coming from the south from a small mountain. Conflict often occurs between the inhabitants of Kawar, the desert Berbers, and the Arabs of Fezzan over these two lakes, as these factions constantly graze their directions. North and west of Kawar, among their cities mentioned on the main road, is Qasr Isa (Fortress of Isa), four stages from it. West of it on that course is al-Qasbah. It has palms and pasture; alum (shabb) is found in its land and carried to the lands. Kawar has cities and settlements other than these but they are obscure. They have domains in the Second Clime and in the north of the First. They have adopted the manners of Whites in wearing wool, cotton, and cloaks. The great Mount Luniya extends south of these cities to near the bend of the Egyptian Nile.
