Therefore, it is said that a branch of the Nile water sinks at it and exits after a long distance in Mount Maquris mentioned before, from which the River Kawkaw exited; others said otherwise. North of this mountain extending from West to East is the land of Barkami. They are Sudan, people of well-being (peaceful/prosperous). They have valleys between mountains with palms, waters, and vegetables. Those of them loyal to the land of Kanem are Muslims. Those loyal to the land of Nubia are Christians. Those loyal to Zaghawa are idolaters. Mount Luniya overlooking them going to the land of Kawar has small rivers descending from it in which travelers find mercy. Ibn Fatimah said: It is said they are from the seepage of the Nile sinking into the mountain. South of Mount Luniya are the domains of the disbelieving Zaghawa; they are called Sha'wah. North of Kawar is Mount Gharghah extending from West to East; between it and the line of the Third Clime is a stage. They recounted that in it are large ants the size of sparrows. East of Kawar with a tilt to the North are the domains of Sandaratah. They are veiled Muslim Berbers, but they give inheritance to the sister's son, following a custom they had before Islam. At the western tip of Mount Luniya between mountains and valleys is the city of Tadmakka. It is known to travelers and mentioned in books. Its people are Muslim Berbers who trade frequently and travel to the land of Sudan; they are under the obedience of Kanem. Its location is south of the mountain and north of the line of the Second Clime where longitude is forty-four degrees and minutes. At the end of this part on the eastern side are the Southern Oases. Most are wastelands containing islands of palms in the sands and waters, mostly not fresh. Part Four: The first thing you meet in its west is the island of the Egyptian Nile. On its two sides are settlements of Nubia until in the middle is the Island of Bilaq (Philae/Bulaq? likely Philae given context), containing the city of Bilaq famous among travelers. It is on this eastern arm, and below it pours the Nile of Abyssinia.

Its location is where longitude is fifty-five degrees twenty minutes, and latitude nineteen degrees. Then the Nile flows east until the Mountain of the Cataracts (Janadil) is located east where longitude is fifty-six degrees twenty minutes and latitude twenty-two and a half degrees. From its north begins the barrier passing west of the Egyptian Nile until it crosses Fayoum. To the Mountain of the Cataracts is the limit for Nubian ships descending north and Egyptian ships ascending south, because it is high from the south side, and the water descends from it with a terrifying drop. There are large jagged rocks there that prevent ships from crossing. Then the Nile twists North, so on its east is the city of Aswan, the first city of Upper Egypt (Sa'id) of the Egyptian lands, where longitude is fifty-seven degrees and latitude twenty-three degrees. The Nile flows east from it then twists like the letter Nun (ن) on the line of the Third Clime. In the direction of Aswan to the East is the road to Hijaz. Whoever takes east goes on the Wadih (Clear Path). There the road of Qus meets the road of Aswan. It was known as al-Wadih because the road becomes clear there, free of the entangled mountains found in the road of Qus. It is where longitude is sixty-one degrees and latitude close to Aswan. Most pilgrims take the Upper Road inclining to the South. West of it is al-Allaqi, the city of the King of the Beja, where longitude is sixty-three degrees and latitude twenty degrees three minutes. The Beja are blacks; among them are Muslims, Christians, and idolaters. They are the ones who guide pilgrims and merchants in those deserts on their camels. They are famous for honesty. Fear on this road comes from the raids of the Nubians on reddish camels. Mount al-Allaqi is famous; good gold is found in its valleys. Located from it is 'Aydhab, the famous port where longitude is sixty-four and a half degrees and latitude twenty-one degrees twenty minutes. The width of the sea from it to Jeddah is two degrees. Jeddah is tilted in latitude to the North by minutes. Mecca, may Allah honor and glorify it, is to its east tilted slightly South, where longitude is sixty-seven degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude twenty-one degrees thirty-one minutes. East of it is Ta'if, to which Ta'ifi leather is attributed. Between them is a degree in longitude. Ta'if is wider (higher latitude) by minutes. Lemons and grapes are brought from it to Mecca. At the end of the part where longitude is seventy-one degrees seventy-six minutes [sic] and latitude twenty-one degrees twenty-one minutes is al-Yamamah, the capital of its lands in ancient times. Near it is Hajar, which became its capital in early Islam. Then the capital of the lands became the city of Hadramawt (unlikely context, possibly error in text or referring to a different settlement); it is north of the city (Medina? or the city just mentioned) by two stages. Between al-Yamamah and Tihama is the land of Najd, inhabited in tents by the foot soldiers of the Arabs. Between Najd and Tihama are the Sarawat (mountains), extending from south Yemen to north Hijaz, with many plantings, settled by the eloquent Arabs. East of Jeddah and south of it on the coast of the sea, among the mentioned lands of Yemen, is al-Sirrain; between them is three stages. East and south of it, among the mentioned ports of Yemen, is Haly; between them is two stages. East and south of it, among the mentioned ports, is 'Athr. West of it in the sea is the Island of Dahlak, famous on the tongues of merchants. Its length is about eighty miles, and between it and the mainland of Yemen is about thirty miles. It belongs to Muslim Abyssinians; its ruler flatters the ruler of Yemen and taxes ships. East of 'Athr is Sa'dah, the city of leather (Barid/post? likely leather/hides); between them is four stages. Between it and the line of the Second Clime is a degree. Around the Island of Dahlak south and north are islands, inhabited and empty, returning to its ruler. Perhaps he fights over them with the ruler of the Island of Suakin. He is of the Beja (Buhar?), a Muslim, having taxes on ships. Ships divert to him from the mainland of the Arabs, Hijaz, and Yemen because that is easier for them. Suakin is very small, less than a mile. Between it and the Abyssinian mainland is a strait crossed by swimming. Between Suakin and 'Aydhab by sea is about seven stages. West of Suakin on the Nile of Abyssinia is the land of al-Bakah, brothers of the Abyssinians on this Nile.

Part Five: The first thing you encounter in its west is Najran, located at the end of the mountains of Yemen, a capital for its governors, where longitude is seventy-five degrees and latitude seventeen degrees. Near it is a city called Jarash to which many people are attributed. In Najran are the People of the Ditch (Ashab al-Ukhdud) mentioned in the Great Quran. East of it, where longitude is seventy-six and a half degrees and latitude seventeen degrees, is the city of Marib, famous in the time of the Tubba's. It is the last of the mountains of Hadramawt. In it was the Dam mentioned in the Quran. East of that are the wastelands between Hadramawt, al-Yamamah, and Oman; no one can traverse them due to shifting sands and thirst. Suhar is located there; it was the city of Oman in ancient times, where longitude is eighty-one degrees and latitude nineteen degrees fifty-six minutes. Between it and the shifting sands is Mount Nizwa, extending from South to North inhabited by the Kharijites (Ibadi). Their city in it is named Nizwa, where longitude is seventy-eight and a half degrees and latitude nineteen and a half degrees. Between Qalhat, the current capital of Oman mentioned at the end of the First Clime's latitude, and Suhar is Muscat (al-Masqat). It is a guard post on a great bay of the Persian Sea where longitude is seventy-nine degrees fifty minutes and latitude eighteen degrees sixty minutes. Between it and Suhar in the sea is al-Dardur (The Whirlpool), where the three mountains called Kusayr, 'Uwayr, and a third in which there is no good. The water spins there; if a ship falls into it, it breaks it on those mountains. It is at the mouth of the Persian Sea from the Indian Ocean. This mouth is wide; its width from Suhar to the coast of India is about two hundred and eighty miles. Hajar, the capital of the lands of Bahrain in ancient times, is located on the coast of this sea in a bay larger than the Bay of Muscat, where longitude is seventy-eight degrees forty minutes and latitude twenty-two degrees thirty minutes. Its dates are proverbial for abundance. The Qarmatians destroyed it and built the city of al-Ahsa. Between it and al-Yamamah are the domains of Banu 'Amir; no dignity remains with them for any Arab in the lands of al-Yamamah and Bahrain. From them are now the kings of the two regions. The Persian Sea does not occupy the rest of this part except the amount of the land of al-Mand. They are brothers of Sindh and Hind; their business is highway robbery and bloodshed. Their lands are between the Indian Ocean and the Gulf of Sindh entering from the Persian Sea in Part Six. The amount of land opening between the two seas from South to North is one hundred and sixty miles. It has a city named al-Mand on the bay of the Gulf of Sindh, where longitude is thirty-five and a half degrees and latitude twenty degrees thirty minutes. Part Six: On its Indian Ocean coast are the Islands of the Diba (Maldives). The largest was mentioned previously. The most famous on the coast of this part among the ports of India intended by merchants from Aden and elsewhere is the city of al-Qusa (?). It is a drainage for ships making it easy to land and takeoff. It is counted in the lands of Gujarat. To it is attributed the Qusi Lac, which is abundant in the lands of Gujarat; it is the gum of trees there. Its people are disbelievers worshipping idol statues, and Muslims live with them. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and seven degrees and latitude seventeen degrees ten minutes. Located in this part among the cities of Sindh mentioned in books is Qandabil, where the Mand shop. It is between the end of the Gulf of Sindh and the Indian Ocean in the wilderness, where longitude is ninety-three degrees forty minutes, and latitude on the alignment of Suhar is nineteen degrees fifty-six minutes. East of it are the Mountains of Bamboo (Khayzuran). In the valleys of these mountains is Teak (Saj) carried to Persia and Iraq by sea, and Indian Canes carried to regions. East of it is the mouth of the rivers of Multan, which is the seat of a kingdom of the kingdoms of Sindh on the western river among them, where longitude is one hundred and four degrees and latitude with the line of the Third Clime. Located in an inlet from the land in the Gulf of Sindh is the famous city of Daybul, from which Daybuli goods are brought. It is the largest and most famous port of Sindh. Its location is where longitude is ninety-two degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude twenty-four degrees thirty-one minutes.

Part Seven: In its coastal south of the Indian lands of Gujarat lies Cambay (Kanbaya). It is famous, intended by merchants of India. Muslims reside there and have mosques. It is on the first line of the Second Clime where longitude is one hundred and seventeen degrees. It has a salty inlet entered by small ships. The large anchorage is half a stage from it. East of it is Somnath, previously mentioned. The sea after it enters into the First Clime. North of it is the city of Nahrawala (Anhilwara), capital of Gujarat, where longitude is one hundred and seventeen degrees and latitude nineteen degrees forty minutes. East and north of it is Gwalior (Jaliyor?), capital of the 'Adisi of the kings of India. It is famous among Muslim merchants passing from Cambay to Delhi. It is where longitude is one hundred and nineteen degrees and latitude twenty-one degrees forty-four minutes. In the South and North of this part are large settlements of India with obscure names. In its west and north are the Mountains of al-Ghushm (The Oppressors?), Indians who do not practice good policy with merchants, so no Muslim enters them nor does anyone other than their religion dwell with them; they are like wild beasts. Part Eight: In it lies the land of Malabar from which pepper is brought. Its famous port enters into the First Clime. In it lies the capital of the lands of the Maknunat (Hidden Ones?), Aknuni (?). Mountains and waters surround it. It belongs to Indian disbelievers, where longitude is one hundred and thirty-five and a half degrees and latitude twenty-three and a half degrees. It is east of the great River Ganges (Kank), venerated by Indians, and west of the River Soliyan. A large number of waters and rivers descend to its lands, all pouring into these two rivers. As for the River Ganges, it pours into the Indian Ocean. West of it is Tarkhinah, the port of the Maknunat, famous among merchants frequenting those lands. It is with the line of the Second Clime where longitude aligns with Aknun. As for the River Soliyan, it pours west of the city of Ma'bar, famous on tongues. It is the capital of the Soliyan (Cholas). From it, clothes whose bleaching is proverbial are brought. It is where longitude is one hundred and forty-two degrees and latitude seventeen degrees twenty-five minutes. North of it, with the line of the Third Clime, are mountains connected to the lands of Ballhara, the King of Kings of India. The end of this part is the capital of Barqali, where longitude is one hundred and forty-three and a half degrees and latitude twenty degrees twenty minutes. South of it is a long salty inlet; its length from the Indian Ocean is about two and a half courses, its width thirty miles, and its minimum ten. Part Nine: In its west is the land of Barqali. East of it is the Inlet of Fufal (Betel Nut); it is fresh, long, and wide, entered by large travelers' ships. Its length from the Indian Ocean is about four courses. Its origin is from a large lake with the Third Clime between the mountains of Ballhara. On its east by the sea is the capital Fufal, famous on the tongues of travelers by sea to India. It belongs to Indian disbelievers, where longitude is one hundred and forty-six degrees and latitude with the line of the Second Clime. East of it are the mountains of Qaqula having lands and cities; the mentioned one is Qaqula. It is where longitude is one hundred and fifty degrees and latitude twenty-one degrees fifty minutes. It has a river descending from a mountain in its north passing its east and pouring into the great River Taragha. East of the land of Qaqula is the Great Mountain extending from the line of the Fourth Clime to the Indian Ocean, separating it from the land of al-Hanbah. Famous among them is the capital of al-Hanbah, east of the great River Taragha. East of it is the Mountain of China separating it from the land of al-Hanbah. From there, rivers and mountains extend in China; they are twelve rivers and twelve mountains, a river between every two mountains. The first to be located in this Ninth Part is the River Zaytun (Quanzhou). At its head is the port of Zaytun, famous on the tongues of merchants arriving at the Chinese lands. Ships enter it from the China Sea about fifteen miles. It is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-four degrees and latitude seventeen degrees and minutes. On the River Luqin, the fourth river of China, is the city of Luqin (Hanoi/Long Bien?). It is famous among Chinese ports, located in an inlet on the sea where longitude is fifty-nine degrees fifty minutes [sic, likely 159] and latitude close to the line of the Second Clime. East of it is the greatest River Khamdan. On it at the end of this part is the city of Khanfu (Canton/Hangzhou?), mentioned in books, located on its east near the line of the Second Clime.

Part Ten: In it lie the remaining rivers and mountains of China as depicted in geography. East of China is the mountain separating them from Sin-Sin (China of China/Outer China). The appearances of the people of China incline towards the appearances of the Khalat (mixed breed), between Turks and Indians. Their clothing is average. Among their customs is revealing their chests. Their Sultan is called the Baghbur (Son of Heaven), and his capital is the city of Tajah in the Third Clime. His subjects are enclosed by mountains and fortresses, so no one enters from their side nor exits without permission. It is said all roads in China are paved with stones, with farms on the right and left. Most of it is rice; they claim a worm eats it which frankincense kills, therefore much [...] is carried to their lands. Chinese Rhubarb is plentiful in this land. It is said they have turnips with which they cook meat while green. Elephants are many among them; they carry their loads on them. Most of their buildings are of camphor wood and pine. They place beautiful paints and exquisite carvings of the Kalahi type in them, as well as their ships. The name of the ship among them is the Zuw (Junk?); it is large, having a storehouse for goods between the person and beneath him. They transact with large ingots of gold and silver. They have copper coins (Fulus) for small amounts. Their language is difficult, while the language of the Indians is sweeter. Their ships in this era have started reaching Aden. At the end of this part from the land of Sin-Sin are obscure cities. At the end of the inhabited world in it is the Island of the Alawites. The Umayyads had sent them to the King of China and told him they were criminals requiring exile. When they appeared before him, they told him they were from the House of Prophecy. He said: Carry them to the island at the end of Sin-Sin; it has many deadly vipers. If it is as they claimed, they will not harm them; if they kill them, I will be relieved of them. So God protected them from them, and they inhabited that island and multiplied. Al-Bayhaqi said: From them are most of the Sharifs (Nobles) of the non-Arabs who tie braids in their heads as a sign of those snakes from which God saved them. Third Clime: Its inhabitants are brown. Its latitude from the Equator is thirty degrees twelve minutes, and its extent is six degrees minus nineteen minutes.

Part One: The Surrounding Ocean ends in it at six degrees. There at its beginning is the mouth of the River Nul. On it are many settlements of Lamta; it is famous. North of it, among the famous ports, is Samtamat. It is a fortress on a cape protruding into the sea, cut off from the mainland by water. Longitude is six and latitude twenty-six and a quarter degrees. Sailors say between it and the river mouth is fifty miles. North of it pours the River Masat; on it is the famous Ribat (fortress/monastery) where the righteous take refuge. Between the two places is sixty miles. From the mouth of this river to the mouth of the River Sus, where sugar cane grows, is twelve miles. Between it and Agadir al-Tarf—the edge of the great Mount Daran entering the sea—is six miles. From there to the mouth of the river [...] is sixty miles; it is in the land of Hahah. From it, salt is shipped to those coasts south and north. From this river to the mouth of the River Amgaddul (Mogador) is forty miles; it is also in the land of Hahah. There is a small island with a mile between it and the river; there is a winter anchorage for ships. From this river to the mouth of the River Tansift, which passes north of Marrakesh, is eighteen miles. There is the port of Aghmat. Between it and the port of Marrakesh, now famous as the city of Safi (Asfi), is thirty-two miles. It is the end of the Clime on an entering bay; longitude there is seven degrees and latitude thirty degrees. North of the city is a cape entering the sea for forty miles called Kansuli, which ships guard against. Located in it is the city of al-Sus, named Taroudant, on the river from the northern side, where longitude is eight degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees twenty minutes. It has many obscure settlements. Its river, the River Masat, and the River Nul all come from the South and East from Mount Lamta connected to Mount Gazula in the Second Clime. It passes in this Third Clime to Sijilmasa. South of it is Mount Sartah; they are like Saltah, tribes of the veiled Berbers. It exits from the Second Clime east of Daran to west of Sijilmasa. West of it by two stages is the city of Draa... Its location is where longitude is eleven degrees six minutes and latitude twenty-five degrees ten minutes. Its famous river to its west descends from red hills at Mount Daran. It is a journey of seven days in continuous settlements. Most of what grows on it is Henna carried to the Maghreb regions until what remains of it sinks into the desert of the Second Clime. East of Draa is the city of Sijilmasa, a famous provincial capital where longitude is thirteen degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude twenty-six degrees twenty-four minutes. Its river comes from the South and East, its source from Mount Azru, which has many snakes, and from its springs. It divides from there into two parts, then the two parts meet and connect on its west and east. It has eight gates; wherever you exit from it, you see the river, palm trees, and other trees. This river pours into the River Ziz, which runs with it and the river of Sijilmasa to it for five days in settlements and bounties. Then the River Ziz pours into the River Moulouya, which pours into the Sea of the Romans (Mediterranean). Connected to Mount Azru are the mountains of Sanhaja; they are many, cohesive, and winding. This tribe is the largest of the Berber tribes; in every land, there is a multitude of them. They mention their origin is from the Arabs of Yemen, and Arabism is apparent among them. Among their mountains is their capital, the city of Takla, where longitude is twelve degrees and latitude thirty degrees. Connected from its west to the Surrounding Ocean is the great famous Mount Daran (High Atlas), where the land of the Masmuda lies; they are known as the Almohads who ruled the Berbers. First in it from the East is the land of Haskurah, then west of it the land of Hazrajah, then the land of Harghah, the tribe of the Mahdi (Ibn Tumart). Most of them claim they are from the descendants of Al-Hussein bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. West of them is the land of Hintatah, the tribe of Sheikh Abu Hafs, the greatest of the Almohad sheikhs; the authority of Ifriqiya is now in his progeny. They attribute themselves to Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. West of them is the land of Tinmal, the fortress which no creature has a way against due to its being cut off by cliffs and abysses from all sides. No one crosses to it except on a bridge lifted during war. West of it is Kadmiwah and the land of Janfisah. West of it is the land of Hahah, distinguished by white honey and large good oxen, just as Tinmal is distinguished by oil preferred in all the Maghreb. West of it is the land of Ragragah, distinguished by a tree whose oil was preferred over what is pressed from olives, and its scent is fragrant. In it, cloths of utmost fineness and softness are made, with which the women of the capital wrap themselves. In it is the River Shafshawah, having large good pomegranates. This land is connected to the Surrounding Ocean. North of Mount Daran is Aghmat...

...which was the metropolis of the country before the building of Marrakesh. It has waters and many fruits. North of it with a slight tilt to the West by about fifteen miles is the metropolis of the Maghreb, Marrakesh. Yusuf bin Tashfin, the ruler of the Veiled Ones (Almoravids), built it in a desert land and brought water to it. People multiplied orchards in it. Its unhealthiness (Wakham) has increased, and a stranger hardly escapes fever there, especially the Veiled Ones. Four miles from it is the River Tansift descending from Mount Daran, passing its east and north. On it are mills, and canals exit from it irrigating the orchards and pouring into the beautiful River Nafis, on whose banks are vineyards with preferred grapes, many orchards, and preferred settlements. At its mouth in the Surrounding Ocean is the old port of Aghmat. The latitude of Marrakesh is disputed; it was said thirty-one degrees, but the correct is twenty-nine degrees. [Repetition of previous text regarding Marrakesh...]. Part Two: Connected to desolate deserts. Located in it among the mentioned lands is a land and its city called Warglan (Ouargla), where longitude is twenty and a half degrees and latitude twenty-four and a half degrees ten minutes. It is a land of palms and slaves; from it, slaves enter the Central Maghreb and Ifriqiya. Travel from it in the desert to the land of Sudan is frequent. East of it is the land of Righ (Oued Righ), its length about five days. It is a land of palms, citrons, and waters springing on the surface of the earth; the water rises like an arrow for a long span and flows into the farms. The name of its capital is Tamariyah, where longitude is twenty-three degrees. East of it is the city of Biskra, capital of the land of Zab. It is a land of palms and crops; from it, types of dates are brought to the capitals Tunis and Bejaia. It is where longitude is twenty-four degrees twenty-five minutes and latitude twenty-seven and a half degrees. North of it is the city of Msila (Al-Masila), which is modern, built by the Ubaydis (Fatimids) on the River Sahar, one of the grand rivers. It passes its west and its waters sink into the desert sands. It is where longitude is twenty-three degrees forty minutes and latitude twenty-nine degrees forty-five minutes. The lands around it are domains of the Arabs of Riyah. Deserts extend in its east until Mount Rahubah, extending from West to East. Ptolemy mentioned its western head is where longitude is thirty degrees fifty minutes and latitude twenty-six degrees and minutes. A river exits from it sinking in its north where the Sabkha (swampy/saline) land is, which is like soap. Often those who took south from the land of Jarid (Date Palms) perished there if ignorant of it. Its border is from the land of Nafzawah to the desert. At the end of this part, from the land of Jarid—which is the land of dates—lies the city of Gafsa. It is a capital famous for palms. Pistachios are hardly found in the Maghreb except there. It has fragrant fruits with many properties. From it, oil of violet and vinegar of squill are brought.

Part Three: The first thing you meet in its west from the land of Jarid is the land of Qastiliya. Its capital is Tozeur. It has palms and citrons; its river comes from above it and irrigates its orchards. It and its lands are islands in the middle of sands, and deserts surround it. It has preferred flax, nabk, and alfalfa. In that and in the scarcity of rain, it resembles the Egyptian lands. Its location is where longitude is thirty-six degrees six minutes, and latitude twenty-nine degrees eight minutes. East of it is the land of Nafzawah; its capital is Turrah where longitude is thirty-seven degrees twenty minutes and latitude twenty-nine degrees. It is also from the land of Jarid. Clear glass and woolen textiles carried to Alexandria and the lands of the Romans (Durub) are brought from it. Ghadames, to which preferred leather is attributed, is situated where longitude is thirty-nine degrees and minutes and latitude twenty-nine degrees ten minutes. They are fortresses on the main road passing to the land of Kanem. East of it is Waddan; they are islands of palms and waters. The first is where longitude is forty-one degrees and latitude twenty-seven degrees fifty minutes. The traveler on the long exhausting road used to take refuge there. East of it is the land of Fezzan; they are also islands of palms and waters, having more cities and settlements than Waddan. All are now in the obedience of the King of Kanem. The capital of Fezzan is the city of Zuwaylah where longitude is forty-three degrees and latitude twenty-seven degrees forty minutes. South of Fezzan and Waddan are the domains of Azkan; they are Muslim Berbers, the most skilled of God's creation in sand geomancy. South of it, to the west of the line of the Third Clime, is Mount Tanta. It is large, extending from East to West about six stages. In its north are springs descending from it, and below them meadows where much grass grows, frequented by Berbers and Bedouins, and war occurs over it. At its bottom is a mine of good iron. North of Zuwaylah is the city of Sirte. It is one of the ancient capitals mentioned in books and on the tongues of passersby. The Arabs destroyed it, and nothing remained but castles inhabited by their followers. Likewise, its regions have castles on the road belonging to Arab carpenters/cultivators who farm around them. The location of this city is where longitude is forty-three and a half degrees and latitude thirty degrees. It is on the coast of the Sea of the Strait (Mediterranean). West of it is the Gulf of Radaqiya, called Gulf of Radiq, not Daqiq. Between Sirte and Ajdabiya, the sea enters to the North in the Fourth Clime. The city of Ajdabiya is located there where longitude is forty-four degrees and latitude with the line of the First [sic, likely Fourth] Clime. Between it and the sea is miles. From it to Fayoum are scattered domains of Arabs and Berbers. Al-Mu'izz built cisterns for rainwater there when he decided to conquer Egypt from Kairouan, as the road through it is shorter, while the coast is a detour. South of the road to Alexandria is Awjila. It is an island in those sands and a settlement in those deserts containing water and palms. It is under the protection of Hayt. It is where longitude is forty-eight degrees fifty-two minutes. In the direction of its latitude is the city of Santariyah (Siwa?) where longitude is forty-five degrees sixty minutes. It is also an island of palms and waters in deserts. Mountains surround it, and Bedouins overlook its directions; the fact that it belongs to the Egyptian Sultanate restrains them from it. In it are pomegranates that are bitter at first then become sweet when ripe. In its land are trees of palm and almond grains brought to Alexandria, at which onlookers marvel. It is deadly with epidemic to its people, let alone strangers. Between the sea and it, at the Small Aqaba, is eight stages. East and south of it are the Northern Oases; they are islands of palms and waters like the previous type. Alum and vitriol are brought from them. North of it is the land of Fayoum; it is not entered except from the desert. The mountain encircles it, extending between it and its lake. The diameter of all that is about a day. Its city where the governor resides is located where longitude is fifty-three degrees and latitude twenty-eight degrees eight minutes. The River of Joseph (Bahr Yusuf), peace be upon him, divides it into two halves and passes through it until it pours into the lake famous for abundant birds and fish. It is said that Joseph, peace be upon him, managed Fayoum and placed in it on that water he brought out from the Nile [...] according to the number of days of the year. It has abundant crops, sugar, flax, and fruits. At the end of this part lies the capital of the Egyptian lands, Cairo (al-Qahira), built by Jawhar, the slave of Al-Mu'izz the Ubaydi (Fatimid), east of the Nile. South of it by a mile is the city of Fustat, laid out by Amr bin al-As, where longitude is fifty-three degrees fifty minutes and latitude twenty-nine degrees fifty-five minutes.

Part Four: In it lies the descent of al-Manha, which is the River of Joseph (Bahr Yusuf) peace be upon him, which he managed from the Nile at the peak of al-Suryan on the western side. The location of that is where longitude is fifty-six degrees forty minutes and latitude twenty-seven degrees fifty-six minutes. The river passes westward aligning with the island of the Nile until al-Lahun, where longitude is fifty-four and a half degrees and close to the previous latitude. It is a dam in which river gates were made, dug as a precaution for the increase of the Fayoum river water. If it exceeds the sufficient amount, the excess is vented from those gates into that dug river. East of the exit of al-Manha is the city of Asyut. In its direction is the Mountain of Birds (Jabal al-Tayr). Its story is that birds make pilgrimage to it every year, and one of them descends and hangs in a niche there, famous. Asyut has an island; opium used in medicine is not found except in it, being one of its plants. East of it is Mount al-Taylamun entering the Nile; the water is disturbed because of it in the narrow place, a severe disturbance ships guard against. South of it and south of the previously mentioned lands is Mount Jalut (Goliath). It extends from above the Oases until it aligns with al-Lahun. It is said there are many treasure demands in it, and books are written about it by those occupied with that. It was attributed to Jalut according to their claim, because when he fled from Palestine where the Jalut before him was killed, he stayed in this mountain, and from it entered with his child and people to the Maghreb. South of this mountain is al-Lazward (Lapis Lazuli); they claimed there is a mine for it there, but extracting it was prevented due to the interruption of habitation. The city of Akhmim falls in this part on the east of the Nile where longitude is fifty-five and a half degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees thirty-five minutes. The city of Qus is located where longitude is fifty-seven degrees thirty minutes and latitude twenty-six degrees. It is east of the Nile. North of it and east of Akhmim is the high Mount al-Zift which appears from al-Tur on the eastern mainland. Al-Qusayr, the famous port of Qus on the Sea of Qulzum (Red Sea), is located where longitude is fifty-nine degrees, and the latitude is close to Qus. The beginning of the Sea of Qulzum is in this part, which is its end, where longitude is fifty-five degrees and latitude thirty degrees. From there, the ships of pilgrims and Yemeni merchants travel. The sea there is narrow like a river, then it starts widening to the South and East until its width at Bahr al-Ghazal is about seventy miles. The sea enters the Fourth Clime, as does the longitude. Eilat is on its inlet. Then the sea spreads to the Third Clime, so the watering places of the Egyptian pilgrims are on its coast. Near it lies the city of Midian, the Ruin mentioned in books, where longitude is sixty-one and latitude twenty-seven degrees fifty-two minutes. Between it and the sea is about fifty miles. In its valley is the path of the Hijazi caravan. The width of the sea at its coast is about a course. Above that place is the alignment of al-Qusayr from the western side. South of Midian and east of it, among the famous stations and mentioned ports, is al-Hawra. It was a place of landing and takeoff destroyed by the Arabs. It is where longitude is sixty-three degrees twenty minutes and latitude twenty-seven degrees forty-two minutes. South and west of it are the Islands of al-Ghul. They are small, exceeding a hundred islands. Naked blacks take refuge there, speaking a closed, heavy language. They have boats suitable for them and houses of reeds and grass. Their only livelihood is fish; they catch it and place it in seawater exposed to the sun. They salt that, then dry it and carry it as jerked meat to al-Tur and Suez, selling it to the Christians of Karak and Shawbak for raisins, oil, olives, and the like. Located in this part where longitude is sixty-four degrees fifty-six minutes and latitude twenty-seven degrees is the city of Khaybar, famous for the habitation of Jews. Its people are blacks who mention they are Muslims who were slaves of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. The doctrine of the Jews is apparent in them. Between it and the Prophet's City (Medina) is Yanbu. It has springs, vegetables, and a fortress. It is the residence of the Banu al-Hasan, may Allah be pleased with him. Its location is where longitude is sixty-four degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees. It has a port on the Sea of Hijaz a stage away from it, where pilgrims intending for Medina land.

The location of the Prophet's City (Medina), upon its inhabitant be the best prayers and peace, is where longitude is sixty-five degrees twenty minutes and latitude twenty-five degrees thirty-one minutes. East of it are al-'Awali, which are part of the Sarawat mountains extending from the beginning of Yemen to Karak in the Levant. East and north of it lie the Mountains of Tayy, which are three, passed by the pilgrims of Kufa. The western one, the first, is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees and latitude at its southern head is twenty-eight degrees forty minutes. From there to the end of the Fourth Part are the domains of the clans of Tayy, which remain in Hijaz to our era. Part Five: The first thing you meet in it are the domains of Khafajah, who are the Arabs of Iraq in our era. Their raids are continuous on the lands that came under the administration of the Tatars. Whenever they pursued them, they entered the deserts in Hijaz. Then to its east are the domains of Banu 'Amir, Arabs of al-Yamamah and Bahrain. The city of Bahrain, capital of its famous lands, is located on the Persian Sea, where longitude is seventy-nine degrees and latitude twenty-five degrees thirty-one minutes. The sea enters the land from its two sides, and for that, it was known by this name (Two Seas). East of it is the Island of Awal (Bahrain Island), elongated from the beginning of the line of the Third Clime to where latitude is twenty-six degrees. It is narrow; its widest part is ten miles. Between it and Bahrain is about sixty miles. It has many remnants of the Qarmatians, and it was their center. North of it with the line of the Fourth Clime is the Island of Kharak (Kharg), famous for pearl diving. It is south of Jannabah, one of the cities of Fars. The center of this island is in the line of the Fourth Clime where longitude is seventy-eight degrees. It is one of the small islands not reaching twenty miles. East and south of it is the Island of Qays (Kish), famous among travelers. It has pearl diving, elites, and wealthy people, and from it come people of virtue. Its size is twelve miles, and its center is where longitude is eighty-three degrees and latitude twenty-seven degrees. East of it is the port of Kerman, famous on the tongues of travelers, which is the city of Hormuz on a salty inlet entered by ships from the Persian Sea. Its location is where longitude is eighty-four degrees and latitude twenty-eight degrees twenty minutes. Located in this part among the ports of Makran is Tiz, where longitude is eighty-six degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees twenty minutes. East of it, among the ports of Makran, is Kir. Between them on the coast is eighty miles. Then the city of Qanbali, where longitude is eighty-seven degrees fifty-five minutes and latitude twenty-four degrees forty-two minutes. The capital of Makran, the city of Firuz, is located where longitude is eighty-seven degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees sixty minutes. Part Six: The first thing you meet in it are the marshes of the Zutt. They are a nation of the commoners of Sindh; their nomads are proverbial for their weakness. Their homes are in huts like the foot soldiers of the Berbers on rivers and ponds originating from the River al-Birun. East of them is the city of al-Birun, to which Abu Rayhan al-Biruni, the master of ancient and modern sciences and student of Ibn Sina, is attributed. This city is one of the ports of the land of Sindh on their salty gulf exiting from the Persian Sea. The river attributed to it is east of it, pouring into the gulf; its source is from the mountains of Kabul connected to the mountains of Tukharistan, which are there the source of some rivers like Jayhun (Oxus) flowing north. The location of al-Birun is where longitude is seventy-one degrees fifty-two minutes. The gulf passes descending to the Second Clime where the city of Daybul is, mentioned previously. Then it stops with the line of the Third Clime, and the Great Mehran (Indus) pours into it there near Daybul. East of that, where longitude is ninety-five and a half degrees and latitude twenty-four degrees forty-two minutes, is the capital of Sindh, al-Mansura. The river is south of it, and a branch of Mehran surrounds it returning to it, so it becomes an island because of that. North of it lies the capital of Kabulistan, Kabul, to which the Kabul Myrobalan (Halilaj) is attributed. In its mountains are Indian drugs. It was one of the frontiers of Muslims facing India, and it has ended up with Sindh in the administration of the Tatars.

Its location is where longitude is one hundred degrees and latitude twenty-eight degrees. It has great cities and settlements. West of it is the Great City of Ghazna, where the throne of the Sultanate of Mahmud bin Sabuktegin, owner of the famous expeditions against the Indians, was. Then the Ghurid Sultans were there, who conquered many of the capitals of India. Remnants of their kingdoms remain until now in the city of Delhi; the Tatars could not overcome them. Islam is strong in their possession. Ghazna mentioned is located where longitude is ninety-two degrees fifty-one minutes and latitude twenty-eight degrees fifty-four minutes. It has obscure cities. Part Seven: The first thing you meet from the line of the Fourth Clime is the city of Qandabar (Gandhara/Kandahar?), one of the capitals of India, where longitude is one hundred and ten degrees. It is said to be one of the Alexandrias built by Alexander in the regions. When Muslims conquered it after Kabul, it became a frontier facing India. It is on the river attributed to it descending from the mountains attributed to it in its west. The river passes south of it, and an arm of it embraces it so it remains in the middle of the water. The small river descends into the big river which descends into Mehran. On the River Sindh in this part, and the mountains of the disbelieving Indians on its southern side and in its north, are obscure lands belonging to Muslims. The disbelieving Indians living under protection (Dhimma) were added to Qandabar. East of that are lands of disbelieving India until entering the lands of Hindustan conquered by Ghiyath al-Din al-Ghuri, ruler of Ghazna, and his brother Shihab al-Din. The first of the famous thrones of kings is Yafun (Badayun?). It has a deputy of authority from the Sultan of Delhi. It is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-three degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees fifteen minutes. It has obscure lands. Its subjects are disbelieving Indians and the soldiers are Muslim Turks. The waters of these lands are ponds of rainwater they call Balahat. Part Eight: The first thing you meet in it is the land of Hasi (Hansi), whose capital is in the Fourth Clime. East of it is the capital of Ballhara, King of Kings of India, the city of Qannauj, which Sultan Mahmud raided and frequented over a march of three months. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-one degrees fifty minutes and latitude twenty-nine degrees. It is between two arms of the River Ganges, venerated by Indians, becoming an island by them. On the sides of this river, in its descent from there to the Indian Ocean, are castles of the Brahmins that are not seen (impregnable?). They are the worshippers of India attributed to Brahman, the first of their wise men and sultans for whom the kingdoms and religions of India gathered. They do not see fit to eat what has a soul. Idols are with them. One among them becomes immortal in this world because he purified and spiritualized himself and deserved that. They have supernatural feats in this regard. Their worship revolves around the dancing of bondmaids and their playing in the temples. Whoever wants to draw near to them burns himself or enters the mentioned River Ganges. There are bamboo trees of extreme height and men arranged with drawn swords and upright daggers. Some devotees tie their head to the end of a bamboo then bend their neck, so the head comes down and the bamboo rises on the river bank. Another throws himself from a high place onto those swords and daggers and is cut up. Another drowns himself in the river. They claim this river is from Paradise, and that if filth is placed in it, its atmosphere darkens and its corners fill with winds, rains, and thunderbolts. Sultan Mahmud tested that at the 'Awzak pass and found it true. Seek that in the Yamini History authored by Abu Nasr al-Utbi regarding his expedition. Famous among the cities on this river in this part is 'Aws. It is on its west on the main road taken by Muslim merchants on the coast of the Maknunat to Delhi. Its inhabitants are disbelieving Indians but they have a policy regarding the passage of merchants over them. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-three degrees and latitude twenty-seven and a half degrees. From the east of this river to the end of this part are the mountains of Ballhara, containing many obscure Indian lands. This kingdom is to them the greatest of Indian kingdoms, and all their kings submit to its ruler. In it are many elephants and rhinoceroses that cut off roads so only groups traverse them. It is said that pepper grows in its watercourses where no one reaches it, and floods take it, so it is picked up and dried.

Part Nine: Passes in the mountains of Ballhara to where longitude is one hundred and forty-nine degrees, then enters Qaqula, whose capital was previously mentioned. Its mountains in this part connect from its west to the mountain separating it from the land of al-Hanbah. East of this mountain lies the city of Atragha. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-five degrees and latitude twenty-seven degrees forty minutes. It consists of four cities on the river attributed to it and on the two arms exiting from it. The source of this river is from the large mountain in its west near the line of the Fourth Clime where longitude is fifty-two degrees. It passes from there to the South, and on its sides are settlements of al-Hanbah until it pours into the Indian Ocean. In the city of Atragha is the king of these lands named al-Hanbah. South of Atragha is the mountain attributed to it, extending until it connects to the Mountain of China. Mountains branch from it containing many Indian drugs and many elephants. North of this mountain and east of Atragha is the Lake of the Four Cities; it is large and round. Its center is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-six degrees and latitude twenty-six and a half degrees. Its length equals its width, two degrees. The Great Gate of China, constructed with masonry, is located with the Large Mountain where longitude is sixty degrees [sic, likely 160] and its latitude with the line of the Fourth Clime. East of it at the end of the part with the line of the Fourth Clime is the capital of China, the city of Tajah, containing the Baghbur, their great king. From the Large Mountain north of it descends Khamdan, the largest river of China. The city becomes an island between its arms. Two rivers descend from it; a river passes in this part to the South until it pours into the Indian Ocean, and the greatest branch takes East in Part Ten. Part Ten: The first thing you meet in it in the land of China is the River Khamdan flowing East, then pouring into a large lake into which small rivers pour from the Mountain of China. Then the Great River Khamdan exits from its south, having grown large, passing in the Third Clime and beyond to the end behind the Equator, in the deserts surrounding this lake near and far from the settlements of China. Its obscure cities are many. Mentioned here is Siniyah, the ancient capital where the Sultan used to be. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and sixty-seven degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees and minutes. It is on the east of a river descending from the Mountain of China, on which are many settlements. In this city, Chinese pottery is made; clay is brought for it from a land with much silver in eastern China. It is said its maker does not benefit from it; only his heir benefits. East of this city is the Mountain of Sin-Sin separating it from China. East of this mountain, from Sin-Sin of obscure names, is what has been neglected in books and on tongues. The Capital is located there, the city of Manzi (Hangzhou/Lin'an?), which the Tatars could not overcome by trickery nor siege, where longitude is one hundred and ninety-six degrees thirty minutes and latitude twenty-six degrees. It is on a continuous river descending from the mentioned mountain passing east and widening greatly, then mixing at the end of habitation with the Surrounding Ocean. Many rivers descend to it from the Great Northern Mountain, on which are settlements of Sin-Sin. Manzi silk is the ultimate in goodness. Fourth Clime: Ibn Fatimah said: It is to them the most moderate of climes and best in animals and plants. Explanation of this is lengthy. It is the middle of the Seven Climes, and the best of matters is the middle. Its inhabitants are between whiteness, redness, brownness, and yellowness. Since the Third Clime is to its south and the Fifth Clime to its north, moderation is judged for them and a resemblance to the Fourth appears in them. The width of this Fourth Clime is thirty-six degrees, and its extent from its south to its north is six degrees nineteen minutes.

Part One: Located in it are the four Islands of Happiness as drawn. The Surrounding Ocean in it ends ascending eastward where longitude is six degrees. There, at its beginning, is the mouth of the River Nul. On it are many settlements of Lamta; it is famous. North of it, among the famous ports, is Samtamat. It is a fortress on a cape protruding into the sea, cut off from the mainland by water. Longitude is six and latitude twenty-six and a quarter degrees. Sailors say between it and the river mouth is fifty miles. North of it pours the River Masat; on it is the famous Ribat (fortress/monastery) where the righteous take refuge. Between the two places is sixty miles. From the mouth of this river to the mouth of the River Sus, where sugar cane grows, is twelve miles. Between it and Agadir al-Tarf—the edge of the great Mount Daran entering the sea—is six miles. From there to the mouth of the river [...] is sixty miles; it is in the land of Hahah. From it, salt is shipped to those coasts south and north. From this river to the mouth of the River Amgaddul (Mogador) is forty miles; it is also in the land of Hahah. There is a small island with a mile between it and the river; there is a winter anchorage for ships. From this river to the mouth of the River Tansift, which passes north of Marrakesh, is eighteen miles. There is the port of Aghmat. Between it and the port of Marrakesh, now famous as the city of Safi (Asfi), is thirty-two miles. It is the end of the Clime on an entering bay; longitude there is seven degrees and latitude thirty degrees. North of the city is a cape entering the sea for forty miles called Kansuli, which ships guard against. Located in it is the city of al-Sus, named Taroudant, on the river from the northern side, where longitude is eight degrees and latitude twenty-six degrees twenty minutes. It has many obscure settlements. Its river, the River Masat, and the River Nul all come from the South and East from Mount Lamta connected to Mount Gazula in the Second Clime. It passes in this Third Clime to Sijilmasa. South of it is Mount Sartah; they are like Saltah, tribes of the veiled Berbers. It exits from the Second Clime east of Daran to west of Sijilmasa. West of it by two stages is the city of Draa... Its location is where longitude is eleven degrees six minutes and latitude twenty-five degrees ten minutes. Its famous river to its west descends from red hills at Mount Daran. It is a journey of seven days in continuous settlements. Most of what grows on it is Henna carried to the Maghreb regions until what remains of it sinks into the desert of the Second Clime. East of Draa is the city of Sijilmasa, a famous provincial capital where longitude is thirteen degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude twenty-six degrees twenty-four minutes. Its river comes from the South and East, its source from Mount Azru, which has many snakes, and from its springs. It divides from there into two parts, then the two parts meet and connect on its west and east. It has eight gates; wherever you exit from it, you see the river, palm trees, and other trees. This river pours into the River Ziz, which runs with it and the river of Sijilmasa to it for five days in settlements and bounties. Then the River Ziz pours into the River Moulouya, which pours into the Sea of the Romans (Mediterranean). Connected to Mount Azru are the mountains of Sanhaja; they are many, cohesive, and winding. This tribe is the largest of the Berber tribes; in every land, there is a multitude of them. They mention their origin is from the Arabs of Yemen, and Arabism is apparent among them. Among their mountains is their capital, the city of Takla, where longitude is twelve degrees and latitude thirty degrees. Connected from its west to the Surrounding Ocean is the great famous Mount Daran (High Atlas), where the land of the Masmuda lies; they are known as the Almohads who ruled the Berbers. First in it from the East is the land of Haskurah, then west of it the land of Hazrajah, then the land of Harghah, the tribe of the Mahdi (Ibn Tumart). Most of them claim they are from the descendants of Al-Hussein bin Ali, may Allah be pleased with them. West of them is the land of Hintatah, the tribe of Sheikh Abu Hafs, the greatest of the Almohad sheikhs; the authority of Ifriqiya is now in his progeny. They attribute themselves to Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. West of them is the land of Tinmal, the fortress which no creature has a way against due to its being cut off by cliffs and abysses from all sides. No one crosses to it except on a bridge lifted during war. West of it is Kadmiwah and the land of Janfisah. West of it is the land of Hahah, distinguished by white honey and large good oxen, just as Tinmal is distinguished by oil preferred in all the Maghreb. West of it is the land of Ragragah, distinguished by a tree whose oil was preferred over what is pressed from olives, and its scent is fragrant. In it, cloths of utmost fineness and softness are made, with which the women of the capital wrap themselves. In it is the River Shafshawah, having large good pomegranates. This land is connected to the Surrounding Ocean. North of Mount Daran is Aghmat...

Its location is where its southern half is in the Fourth Clime and the northern half is in the Fifth Clime, and its longitude is close to Tangier. Opposite Ksar al-Majaz from Andalusia is Tarifa. In front of it in the sea is a small island known to travelers as the Island of Tarifa (Isla de las Palomas), just as we say the Green Island (Algeciras). But it is in front of Ceuta on the Andalusian mainland; however, in its direction is a green island known by it. In front of this city to its south is the famous Mountain of Conquest (Jabal al-Fath) from which Andalusia was conquered. This is how people know it. Its name in books is Jabal Tariq (Gibraltar). He is the freedman of Musa bin Nusayr, conqueror of Andalusia. This mountain appears in the sea from Ceuta, being high in the sea. Between it and the Green Island (Algeciras) is the famous harbor where ships of Ceuta and others anchor, for the storm has no way against them. The sea from east of Ceuta comes south, passing close to the line of the Fifth Clime by the Island of Andalusia. The first thing you meet in the Mainland (North Africa) after Ceuta is Mount Ghomara, high and wide, containing nations counted only by Allah Almighty. From it, cedar wood is carried, from which fleets are constructed, known in royal buildings and carried to the horizons. Between it and Ceuta is twenty-six miles, and to the River Law descending from it ten miles; it is large, entered by ships sailing in it to the city of Badis (Velez de la Gomera). It is one of the most famous ports of Ghomara, and that coast is known as the Rif. From Badis to Al-Mazamma is like what is between Badis and Ceuta, one hundred miles. It is a famous port. From it to the city of Melilla is one hundred miles. On its east at ten miles pours the great famous River Moulouya, into which the River Ziz descends, and into which the River Sijilmasa descends. Thus, its distance from the source of Sijilmasa in the South is about one hundred miles. From it to Archgul (Rachgoun), the port of Tlemcen and where the river into which the great River Yisser pours, is seventy miles. From it to the port of Honaine is twelve miles. From it to the famous port of Oran is eighty miles. It is the last port of this part of the Mainland cities. Its harbor is famous, safe in terror (storms). Opposite the city of Badis from the Andalusian mainland is Malaga. It is with the line of the Fifth Clime, and the width of the sea between them is a degree. From it, Malaga figs and almonds are carried to regions. Opposite Al-Mazamma is the port of Almunecar; it is with the mentioned Line on the coast of Granada; the width of the sea there is a course. Opposite Archgul is the city of Almeria, famous for having the Arsenal of Andalusia and its Diwan. It is also with the mentioned Line. In it, and in Malaga and Murcia, silk clothes embroidered with gold of strange craftsmanship are made. The width of the sea there is two degrees. The famous Tlemcen is located where longitude is fourteen degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees forty-two minutes. Between it and Archgul is twenty miles. Between it and Honaine is thirty miles. It is now the capital of Banu Abd al-Wad of Zenata. From it, woolen clothes preferred over their kind made in the rest of the Maghreb are carried. From it are carried bits, horses, saddles, and related items. Andalusians say it is like one of the cities of Andalusia due to its waters, orchards, and abundance of its industries. West of it with a deviation to the South lies the city of Rabat where longitude is twelve degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees minus ten minutes. West of it is the city of Fez where longitude is ten degrees sixty minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees. It is one of the distinct cities of the Maghreb filled with bounties and strange industries. It is said there are springs in it numbering the days of the year. Its river coming from the meadow in its east irrigates it and pours into the River Sebou passing its north. East of Fez is Mount Madyun extending south, where Madyun burnouses that rain does not penetrate are made. This mountain mixes from its south with Mount Daran and from its north with the mountains of Taza and mountains of Ghomara. From the mountains south of Fez, the River Sabak descends. From them and south of this river, the River Umm Rabi' descends. From the mountains north of Fez, the River Yisser descends. All pour into the Surrounding Ocean as drawn. North of Fez is the famous city of Meknes, abundant in olives. Descending from the mountains of Ghomara in its east is the River Fulful, passing its south and pouring into the River Sebou. Between it and Fez is forty miles. West of it with a deviation to the North is the city of Ksar (Alcazarquivir), known as Ksar Abd al-Karim and Ksar Kutama, who are nomads. The location of this city is where longitude is eight and a half degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees forty minutes. It is on the north of the river attributed to it. Between it and Ceuta is four days. Between River Salé and River Sebou are mountains...

...of Fazaz. They are Berbers having famous production in horses. They have a fortress in this mountain where they store their food and ploughs in those regions. In that direction is a silver mine, and its brother is the Raqid mine south of Daran. East of Mount Madyun are the mountains of Madgharah; they are from the tribe of Abd al-Mu'min. It is the highest of these mountains where longitude is thirteen degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees. It follows the great River Moulouya previously mentioned. East of the mountains of Madgharah are the mountains of Yisser, from which the previously mentioned River Yisser springs. Connected to it from its east is Mount Ouarsenis (Wansharis) where royal carpets are made; it belongs to Banu Tujin of Zenata, extending near the line of the Third Clime. From it springs the great famous River Chelif (Ash-Shalif), exiting this part to the Second and pouring out at Mostaganem. It is like the Nile, increasing during days of river deficiency. On it are the domains of Maghzawa of Zenata.

Part Two: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Tenes, famous for abundant wheat. From it, it is carried in ships to the coasts of Andalusia and elsewhere. It is now the capital of Maghzawa of Zenata. Its location is where longitude is eighteen degrees twelve minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees twenty minutes. It has a river coming from its south pouring into the sea to its east; between it and the sea is two miles. East of it is Mostaganem, one of the ports of Maghzawa; between them is sixty miles. East of it pours the River Chelif previously mentioned. The width of the sea there to the coast of Denia in Andalusia is about three and a half courses. East of it is the city of Algiers (Al-Jaza'ir). It is a famous port under the administration of Bejaia, where longitude is twenty degrees eighteen minutes and latitude thirty-three and a half degrees. East of it is Dellys (Tadallas) at fifty miles from it; it is a famous port. East of it is the capital of the Central West, Bejaia (Bougie), where longitude is twenty-two degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees fifteen minutes. It has a river of utmost beauty with orchards and parks on its banks, where ship owners recreate. It pours into the sea to its east; its source is from the direction of Shaqra in the southern desert. The width of the sea at Bejaia to the direction of Tortosa in Andalusia is three courses. On the coast east of Bejaia are the Mountains of Mercy (Jibal al-Rahmah); ships endure severe terror in its sea. Its inhabitants are rebellious Berbers; their land is fortified containing cotton and figs. East of it is Collo (Al-Qull). It is a famous port on the coast of Constantine of the Air (Qusantinah al-Hawa); between them is forty miles. The location of Constantine is to its south, where longitude is twenty-six degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees twenty-two minutes. It has a river pouring into its great eastern trench; a terrifying echo is heard from it circling from the top of the city to the bottom of the trench like the tail of a star due to the distance. This city is at the end of the Sultanate of Bejaia. The first of the Sultanate of Ifriqiya on the sea is the city of Bone (Annaba), where longitude is twenty-eight degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees fifty minutes. It has a medium river pouring into the sea to its west. East of it is Marsa al-Kharaz (La Calle/El Kala), distinguished by coral. In front of it in the sea in this part is Sardinia, the famous island where coral is found. It is a petrified tree in the sea coming out white and soft; if the air hits it, it turns red and hard. The city of this port is where longitude is twenty-nine degrees and minutes, and latitude approximates the latitude of Bone. East of it, among the mentioned ports, is Tabarka, from where wood and good Persian reed are carried to the Tunisian capital. East of it is the city of Bizerte (Binzart), where longitude is thirty degrees sixty minutes and latitude thirty-three and a half degrees. It has a river with a lighthouse pouring into its east. It has a sweet lake in its south and a salty lake in its east; each pours into the other for six months, so neither the sweet spoils with the salt nor the salt improves with the sweet. It is widely known that fish exit these two lakes at the beginning of every month as a known species, and the first species disappears until the year turns. East of it is Ras al-Jabal (Cape of the Mountain), where the safe anchorage is in winter. Ships resort to it from the port of Tunis if there is terror (storm) or repair is intended. Between this mountain and Tunis pours the River Medjerda, famous in Ifriqiya; it is called al-Mafza' at its mouth. The Capital named Tunis is located where longitude is thirty-two degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees thirty-one minutes. It is on a salty lake entered by small ships with cargo from large ships anchoring in its harbor. Between the shore of the lake at Tunis and its mouth at the sea is ten miles, and its circumference is twenty-four miles. This city is now the capital of Ifriqiya, and most lands of the Maghreb are subordinate to it. East of it is Kelibia (Iqlibiyah), a fortress on the sea; between them is about ninety miles. The sea turns from its east to its south where the city of Hammamet is at the head of that inlet, near Tunis by land, but a large detour by sea. East of Kelibia at sixty miles in the sea is the Island of Pantelleria (Qawsarah), from which dried figs and cotton are brought, and it has mastic. It belongs to Muslims under a pact with the Franks of Sicily; between them is a course. Most of Sicily is in the Fifth Clime. East of Hammamet on the coast is the city of Sousse (Susa). From it, Muslims conquered the Island of Sicily. It is where longitude is thirty-four degrees and minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees forty minutes. East of it in an inlet to the South is the city of Mahdia, built by Ubayd Allah al-Mahdi and made the capital of Ifriqiya. It is elongated into the sea...

...which surrounds it in more than one place, narrow like Ceuta. Its location is where longitude is thirty-four degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees. East of it is the city of Sfax. In front of it is the Short (shallow water) which large ships do not enter; its length from Kaboudia to east of Sfax is about eighty miles. At its end in the North in the Great Sea is the Island of Kerkennah, where fine [...] is made, and it has raisins superior to the Djerbian; it belongs to Muslims, located thirty miles from Sfax. Sfax is located where longitude is thirty-five degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees sixty minutes. East and south of it, with the end of the Second Part and end of the Third Clime, is the city of Gabes, which is in Ifriqiya like Damascus in the Levant. Two rivers descend to it from the mountain in its south, piercing its Ghouta (oasis/garden), and its streams branch over it. It is distinguished among the lands of Ifriqiya by bananas; it has abundant good fresh dates, tiger nuts (Hab 'Aziz), and Henna. Between it and the sea is three miles, and medium ships enter its river. The Great Mountain extends from it East and West being in its south, striking in its direction Mount Dammar, in the direction of Gafsa Mount Aures, and in the direction of Kairouan Mount Ousselat. It is fertile in all these places; sultanate monies are collected from it. The city of Kairouan is located south of this mountain where longitude is thirty-three degrees and latitude thirty-one degrees. It is in the desert suitable for Arab camels. It was the capital of Ifriqiya in early Islam and is now subordinate to Tunis. Connected to Mount Ousselat are mountains inhabited by varieties of Berber subjects. South of it is the desert, and north of it are domains of 'Awf of the Arabs and domains of Nafzawa and Hawwara of the Berbers. In the direction of Beja at fifty miles from Tunis are domains of Hudhayl; they are reckoned horsemen in Ifriqiya. Then connects to that the famous Mount Aures where al-Kahinah (The Priestess) was. Its inhabitants are people of villainy and disobedience who do not enter under the obedience of a sultan due to the impregnability of their wide long mountain, and due to what they have of tricks, foot soldiers, and weapons. It has abundant goods; its people are Kharijites, mostly from Lawata, a large multitude included in the subjects. Between this mountain and the city of Bone are domains for the Arabs. From the border of Constantine to Bejaia are domains of Riyah. From west of Bejaia to Tlemcen are domains of Rahibah, connected to the Mountains of Ouarsenis previously mentioned. In the First Part is the mountain of Banu Rashid, who are of Zenata, having known production in horses. In this part branch the mountains of Sanhaja, Zwawa, and others, mentioning which would be lengthy.

Part Three: The first thing you meet in it is the Island of Djerba, famous for oil, raisins, fresh dates, apples, and beautiful woolen wraps. It is east of Gabes. Between it and the mainland is a narrow strait crossed by boats. Between this strait and Gabes is a stage. The length of this island is a stage, and its inhabitants are Kharijites (Ibadi). North of it is the Island of Lampedusa; it is empty, ships resort to it and water from it. North of it lies Sicily. East and south of Djerba, the sea recedes to the North until the famous city of Tripoli (Tarabulus) is located on it where longitude is thirty-eight degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees twenty minutes. East of it by two stages is Mount Nafusa, connected to Mount Dammar and connected mountains until Mount Daran which enters the Surrounding Ocean. Its length is six days and width three days. In it are cities, settlements, a large multitude, waters, and fertility. From it, Tripoli is supplied with varieties of goods, even vegetables and fruits. In it are olives, oil, raisins, and dates. Mountains connect to it until it cuts off east of the city of Leptis (Labdah) the Ruin. The ruins of this city of marble and Heraclean stones testify to its former state. It is on the sea where longitude is thirty-nine degrees thirty minutes, and latitude close to the latitude of Tripoli. The domains of Dhiyab are from the border of Gabes to Bir al-Sidra of Barqa. After Leptis, the sea begins entering to the South. On its coast there are settlements for clans of Hawwara under the protection of Dhiyab. In summary, once you leave Tripoli, you do not meet a city with a bath or baker until you reach Alexandria. At the end of the sea's ascent to the South is Qasr Ahmad, the last border of Ifriqiya where longitude is forty-one degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude with the line of the Fourth Clime. At its latitude are the castles of Misrata, extending twelve miles on olives and palms. Its people are of Hawwara under the protection of Dhiyab. They have a passion for carrying horses to Alexandria. Pilgrims find aid from them on that arduous road. The first thing you meet from the border of Barqa is the Gulf of Radiq mentioned, and what follows has been mentioned in the Third Clime. East of it is Bir al-Sidra, the first of the domains of the Arabs to the Small Aqaba of the land of Alexandria. Located in the land inlet between the Gulf of Radiq and Ras al-Tin is Tolmeita (Ptolemais). It is a famous port there, containing a castle with Jews under Arab protection.

Its location is where longitude is forty-four degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees ten minutes. From it, ships carry sulfur, honey, wheat, and barley. In the East is the city of Barqa, which was the capital of the Barqan lands, destroyed by the Arabs. It is called today the City of al-Marj. Between it and Tolmeita is ten miles. The fertility of Barqa containing trees and goods is in the inlet to its south; its distance is about ten stages from West to East. Whoever protects it from the Arabs of Hayt has the power. From its mountains descends the River Derna and pours into the Salt Sea. I did not see in all the lands of Barqa a river other than it. South of it is the desolate desert. Derna is located where longitude is forty-six degrees and latitude thirty-five degrees seventeen minutes. It was one of the mentioned cities of Barqa, destroyed by the Arabs. It is now counted among the Arab castles to which Jews and their agents resort. On its coast is Ras Awthan (Cape of Idols), where sailors congratulate themselves. It is located in the corner where longitude is forty-four degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees fifty-two minutes. East of it is the famous Hilal (Crescent), a mountain appearing from afar in the sea to the right of the Island of Crete located in the Fifth Clime. Between it and Ras Awthan is two stages. East of Derna is the famous Ras al-Tin (Cape of Figs). It is in the eastern corner, just as Ras Awthan is in the western corner. Its location is where longitude is thirty-five degrees minus minutes. From there, the sea takes forty-six degrees forty-seven minutes [sic, likely describing curvature] and latitude ascending to the South. South of it, among famous ports, is al-Qurashi, then Tobruk (Tabruq). It was the capital of the land in the days of the Romans. The land was known as Pentapolis (Antabulus). The Arabs named it Barqa when they saw the abundance of stones mixed with sand. Tobruk has a harbor that rarely has an equal on this sea; winds have no way against it, as if it were a basin hollowed in stone. Remnants of this city's walls indicate its antiquity. It is where longitude is forty-seven degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees fifty minutes. In its direction is the course known as al-Bantan. East of that, among castles famous to the Arabs, are Lakk and Qumar. East of them is the Great Aqaba, the first of the Egyptian lands. There is Marsa al-Muslim (Port of the Muslim), one of the mentioned ports. The Aqaba is where longitude is forty-nine degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees. There is the famous Hawwara Inlet, an inlet in the sea. North of it is the famous Port of Churches (Marsa al-Kana'is). From there are domains of Hawwara, then domains of [...] to the end of the Lake. The famous Alexandria, the link between the Indian Ocean and the Sea of the Romans, lies where longitude is fifty-one degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees thirty-one minutes. It has two seas like Ceuta and Mahdia. Except that Alexandria is separated at its ends by the Cape protruding in front of it. In it is the famous Lighthouse (Pharos) by which ships guide themselves by day and by its light at night. Its height in our time is eighty-four fathoms. The height of the minaret of Seville is thirty-five fathoms. The height of the minaret of Marrakesh is thirty-six fathoms. The height of Pompey's Pillar (Amud al-Sawari) in Alexandria is one hundred cubits and its circumference forty spans. Alexandria has a canal in its south into which water enters from the Nile during the flood days, so ships come to it from all Egyptian coasts with varieties of crops and goods. If this canal is disabled, the lake in its east operates. It is salty; sea water enters it between Alexandria and Rosetta, and ships travel in it to the lands on the Nile. Forty miles from Alexandria is Tarujah. It is in the South with a tilt to the West. Arabs of Beheira and Arabs of Barqa shop there, and it is famous for that. Taruji grapes are of utmost goodness and appearance. It is said there was a city west of it where the people of Egypt met Al-Mu'izz the Ubaydi when he came from Ifriqiya, then it was ruined by strife. East and south of Alexandria at fifty miles is Damanhur, the capital of Beheira. It has a canal from the canal of Alexandria. Arabs of Beheira shop there most. Rosetta (Rashid) lies on the west of the Nile at its mouth in the sea, where longitude is fifty-two degrees four minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees sixty minutes. East of it is Lake Nastaruh (Burullus?). No lake in the Egyptian lands yields more revenue than it; it reached twenty-five thousand Egyptian Dinars in our time, while other Egyptian lakes guarantee seventy thousand Dinars. East of it is the Ribat of al-Burlus. From it, the sea turns South, so famous Damietta is located on the mouth...

...of the Eastern Nile where longitude is fifty-four degrees, being in the end of the Third Part, and latitude thirty-one degrees twenty minutes. Mahalla, capital of al-Gharbiya, lies where longitude is fifty-three degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees six minutes. Al-Mansura, built in our time as a fortress on the canal of Ashmun branching from the Eastern Nile which pours into Lake Tinnis, lies where longitude is fifty-three and a half degrees and latitude thirty-one degrees minus minutes. [Repetition of previous text]. Part Four: The first thing you meet in it is Lake Tinnis east of Damietta. The city of Tinnis, to which high-quality clothes are attributed, lies inside this lake on an island where longitude is fifty-four degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees thirty minutes. East of this lake on the Salt Sea is Farama the Ruin, where longitude is fifty-four degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees. Remaining between the Sea of the Romans—which is the Sea of Coral—and the Indian Ocean—which is the Sea of Pearls—is an isthmus about seventy miles. Amr bin al-As wanted to pierce what is between the two seas from the direction of al-Qulzum in a place now known as the Tail of the Crocodile (Dhanab al-Timsah), but Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him, forbade him lest pilgrims be snatched at the Sanctuary. East of Farama is Al-Arish; it was a formidable city on the sand road, where longitude is fifty-six and a half degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees thirty minutes. East of it is Gaza, called Gaza of Hashim. They claim the grandfather of the Prophet, peace be upon him, is buried there. It is said Imam al-Shafi'i, may Allah be pleased with him, is from there. It is where longitude is fifty-seven degrees and minutes. From there the sea twists to the West and North, so Ascalon (Asqalan) is in an inlet where longitude is fifty-five degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees fifty minutes. It is on the sea, while Gaza has sand dunes between it and the sea. After Ascalon is Jaffa, one of the famous ports, where longitude is fifty-six degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees. Then on the coast is Caesarea where longitude is fifty-seven degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees fifteen minutes. Then lies the city of Acre ('Akka), the stirrup of the Franks and gathering place of their merchants and pilgrims, where longitude is fifty-eight degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees twenty minutes. Tyre (Sur), which cannot be aspired to by siege from land, lies where longitude is fifty-nine degrees seventeen minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees forty minutes. The Franks dug around it until they wanted it to be [surrounded by] the sea. Beirut, the port of Damascus, lies where longitude is fifty-nine degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees. Tripoli lies on the sea where longitude is sixty-one degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees. Latakia lies on the sea where longitude is sixty-one degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees thirty-one minutes. Famous Antioch lies where longitude is sixty-one degrees thirty-five minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees ten minutes. Between it and the sea is al-Suwaydiyah (Saint Simeon) at the mouth of the Orontes River (al-'Asi) descending from the direction of Baalbek, passing north of Homs, Hama, and Shaizar, then east and north of Antioch to the Sea of the Romans.
