Then it twists to the North, forming the Gulf of Armenians. Famous cities on it lie in the first latitude of this part. First is al-Massisah (Mopsuestia) on the River Sayhan where longitude is fifty-nine degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees; between it and the sea is twelve miles. North of it is Adana north of the River Sayhan; between the two cities is twenty miles, and likewise between Adana and the sea. North of it is the capital of the land of Sis: Tarsus. It is on both sides of its river, which pours into the sea at twelve miles. Between it and Adana is twenty miles. It is where longitude is fifty-eight degrees and latitude thirty-six degrees seventeen minutes. Sis is a city created by Ibn Leo (Levon), King of the Armenians, and he made it the capital of his kingdom.

It is where the Round Mountain is, and the sea is a bowshot away from it. The first southern landmarks in Part Four is al-Tih (Wilderness of Wandering), spanning four stages, left by the Egyptian caravan on its left when travelling from al-Qulzum to al-Tur. Mount al-Tur (Sinai) on the Sea of Qulzum is east of Bahr al-Ghazal where longitude is fifty-seven degrees twenty minutes. Eilat lies at the head of its inlet exiting from the Sea of Qulzum, where longitude is fifty-eight degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty degrees fifty minutes. It was a Jewish capital, then ruined. North of it is the arduous Aqaba attributed to it; the rider travels from its beginning to its end a full stage. North of it lies Shawbak where longitude is fifty-seven degrees and latitude thirty-one degrees. Famous Karak lies north of it where longitude is fifty-six degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-one and a half degrees. There in Mu'tah is the grave of Ja'far al-Tayyar and his companions; it has a valley with water and orchards. Jerusalem (al-Quds) lies where longitude is fifty-six degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees. Between it and Karak is the Dead Sea, tilting east from it. No living thing exists in it. In it is found the place of [...] and in interpretations, it is the homes of the people of Lot which were swallowed by the earth. The known Jordan River exits Lake Tiberias and passes through the Ghor until it pours into this Dead Sea. People say it has an outlet to the Sea of Qulzum. Tiberias, which was the capital of Jund al-Urdunn, lies where longitude is fifty-seven degrees forty-five minutes. In its direction is the lake attributed to it, between it and Acre and Tyre. A river descends to it from Lake Qadush above it, and the Jordan River exits from it. In Tiberias are hot springs sufficing its people from baths. The city was ruined by the conflict of the two religions over it. It is now, with Ascalon, Jaffa, and Caesarea, in Muslim possession. Mount 'Amil extends east and south of the coast until near Tyre. On it is al-Shaqif (Beaufort Castle), regained for Muslims in our time. Its subjects were under Frankish rule, then returned to Muslim rule and entered the soldiers' fiefs. East and south of it is Mount 'Awf; its people were rebels, so Usama built the fortress of Ajloun over them until they entered obedience. East and south of it is Mount al-Salt; its people were also rebels, so al-Mu'azzam built the fortress of al-Salt over them until they entered obedience. Between it and Ajloun is two stages, likewise between it and Karak. The Ghor (Jordan Valley) is long; sugar cane and bananas grow well in it. Its end is Jericho at the beginning of the Dead Sea; it was a city of the Giants (Jabbarin) and is now formidable. Between this Ghor and the coast is the Ghor of Beisan. Whoever takes the left road travels over Nablus, whose mountain is a pilgrimage and Qibla for the Samaritans, and Mount al-Sharah south of al-Balqa. Behind it is wilderness, inhabited now by farmers. In the direction of [...] from which the Abbasids emerged to the Caliphate in Iraq. In that southern line is al-Azraq, a fortress built by al-Mu'azzam at the edge of the wilderness containing the road to Hijaz. On the right of the road are al-Ula and Tabuk, and on the left the road of Tayma. North of al-Azraq is Bosra, capital of Hauran, four stages from Damascus. East of it in the southern line is Salkhad, capital of the mountain of Banu Hilal. The capital of the Levant, Damascus, lies where longitude is sixty degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees. In astrolabes it is thirty-three degrees like Baghdad and Tunis. The abundance of snow in it is only from the mountains in their directions where snow never leaves. It is said the gardens of the world are four: Samarkand, Shi'b Bawwan, the Ubulla (canal), and the Ghouta of Damascus. Abu Bakr al-Khwarizmi said: The Ghouta surpasses these three and all gardens of the world. Baalbek lies west and north of it, forty miles away. In it are great monuments of long trellis stones. Snow is abundant there. It is known as al-Salihin. Snowy mountains extend towards Homs. Between it and the sea is Mount al-Khayt inhabited by permissivist (Ibahiya) folks; they often sell Muslims to Franks if they pass by them. Connected to them towards Wadi al-Taym is [...] famous, a stage from Damascus. Mount Sikkin extends, where the Ismaili mission spreads and their fortresses Masyaf and al-Khaf al-Hawani are, between Homs and Hama towards the sea. At its edge towards Baalbek and Homs is Crac des Chevaliers (Hisn al-Akrad), said to produce intoxicating wine. West of Crac des Chevaliers is [...] conquered by Muslims. Connected to the Ismaili mountain, and on their doctrine, is Mount Summaq of the work of Aleppo. It is full of Ismailis. Towards the sea, appearing standing like a wall over Jableh and Latakia, is the Nusayri Mountain.

They are attributed to Nusayr, the freedman of Ali, may Allah be pleased with him. They claim the sun stopped for Ali, may Allah sanctify his soul, as it stopped for Joshua, and the skull spoke to him as it spoke to Christ; they went to extremes in deifying him. Their doctrine is common in the Island of 'Ana at the edge of Jazira (Mesopotamia) bordering Iraq. In the Nusayri mountain to the north: Sahyun (Saone), famous for pleasure (Mut'ah), is nearby. The location of Homs, a capital of the Junds of the Levant, is where longitude is sixty-one degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees. Hama is a stage from Homs, one of the pleasantest cities of the Levant. The Orontes River is north of it, having waterwheels (Norias) and gardens; boats frequent it between orchards. Then from it to Ma'arrat (al-Nu'man) is a stage. It is famous for abundant olives, figs, and pistachios. In it is a column moved by a child so it tilts, due to engineering beneath it. In it is the grave of Joshua peace be upon him. Outside it is the Monastery of Simon (Deir Sim'an) under the grave of Umar bin Abd al-Aziz, exposed to the sky as he bequeathed. In the South is Khanasir where he resided during his Caliphate; it is a desert city. Likewise Salamiyah, whose people frequent Hama. From it Abdullah al-Mahdi emerged and established his mission in the Maghreb, then his sons succeeded in the Caliphate over Egypt and the Levant until Sultan Salah al-Din bin Ayyub removed their state. From Ma'arrat to Qinnasrin is a large stage. It was the capital of a Jund of the Levant, then weakened by Aleppo's strength and ruined by the Franks' entry and seizure of its regions. It is now a village; below it the River Quwayq pours into a large lake. The hill of Qinnasrin overlooks it. The plain extends from there to Aleppo, a small stage. This famous city, which grew huge with the Hamdanid state in it, then the Arab and non-Arab states that succeeded over it until the Tatars entered it in our time, destroyed it, and inhabited its people's homes, lies where longitude is sixty-three degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees thirty minutes. It is south and east of the River Quwayq, which comes from the direction of Azaz, a famous fortress north of Aleppo. This city has regions of utmost beauty, goodness, and fertility. Most of its soil is red, pleasing the soul. Mostly cotton is grown there, carried in ships to Ceuta spreading through the Maghreb lands. Its land is fertile with large pistachios. One of the pleasantest dwellings in its region is al-Bab, more beautiful than an eye sees or a soul finds rest in. There is the fountain mentioned by Imru' al-Qais in his poetry, and the valley described wondrously by al-Manari. In this place is a city, though not famous; it has a bath, cloth merchants, and perfumers. It is a good stage from Aleppo on the Euphrates road. In the northern direction is the River al-Jawz, one of the best rivers of the world, most abundant in goods and thickest in shade.

In that direction is the fortress of Tell Bashir, a good stage from Aleppo containing waters and orchards. It is distinguished by the known spring and the thatch which has no equal; they cannot transport it to Aleppo because it turns into water on the way. Between Aleppo and Antioch is Harim, a fortress of much provision, distinguished by pomegranates whose inside shows from the outside with no seed and much water. It is a good stage from Aleppo. East of al-Bab previously mentioned, between Aleppo and the Euphrates, is the city of Manbij. Al-Rashid asked Abd al-Malik bin Salih about its night; he was told it is all a dawn (pleasant). Abu Firas al-Hamdani has poetry on its parks and places of pleasure. It has flowing water, and most of its trees are mulberry for raising silkworms. It is where longitude is sixty-three degrees forty-five minutes and latitude thirty-five degrees thirty minutes. Between it and the Euphrates at Qal'at Najm and the bridge is twenty-five miles. This fortress is in the clouds, described by al-Fadil with wonderful description. That place used to be called Manbij, then became known as Qal'at Najm. It is built by Sultan Mahmud bin Zanki, may God have mercy on him. He often garrisoned there and raided the Franks who dominated the frontiers of the Levant and Jazira during the strife. We crossed this bridge to Harran. Above it by a good stage is the fortress of Bidayah crossed to Saruj, upon whose mention al-Hariri built his Maqamat. It has many waters and orchards, containing preferred pomegranates, pears, peaches, and quinces. Between it and Harran is a stage, sometimes done in two. The first thing you meet in this Fourth Part of the Euphrates descending from the bridge of Manbij to the East and South is the city of Balis, famous for wealthy merchants. The desert is between it and Aleppo, and often Arabs intercept its people. It is on the western Levantine side. East and south of it on the eastern Jazira side is the city of Raqqa, known as al-Bayda (The White) for the whiteness of its sand and wall. It is the capital of the abodes of the land of Jazira (Mesopotamia), where longitude is sixty-six degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees. Located is the island of Qarqisiya (Circesium), between the Euphrates and the Khabur descending from Ras al-Ayn, where longitude is sixty-six degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-five degrees twenty minutes. Below it is the city of al-Rahbah, having many fruits on the west of the Euphrates on the Levantine side. It is the port of Palmyra (Tadmur), a stage away in the desert. It has great large monuments. Arab poets claim the Jinn built it for Solomon son of David, peace be upon them. It has a mosque of a single rock like a cavity in a cut mountain; the roof of that mosque and everything in it is made from it. It is a land of olives and palms, containing much Saltwort (Ghasul). Located is the Island of 'Ana in the middle of the Euphrates, where longitude is sixty-seven degrees twenty minutes. It is from the land of Jazira. Christianity dominates its people. Its heat is mentioned in poems. Below it in the middle of the Euphrates is al-Hadithah where longitude is sixty-seven degrees and minutes. Located is the city of Hit on the west of the Euphrates; it is also a city of Jazira and the limit ends there, where longitude is sixty-eight degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees. It is a town of bounties and palms. Located is the city of al-Anbar on the eastern side of the Euphrates. It is the first city of Iraq from the direction of Jazira, where longitude is sixty-nine degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees twenty minutes. Located is the famous city of Kufa on an arm of the Euphrates in its west, where longitude is sixty-nine degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees fifty minutes.

It is Islamic, built in the time of Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. It is said the water of the Flood overflowed from a place near it. It is a town of palms and contains Iraqi violets. The city of Wasit lies on the bank of the Tigris where longitude is sixty-two degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees twenty minutes. In this part lie the marshes (Bata'ih) of Kufa from the overflow of Euphrates waters, where Bedouins and highwaymen take refuge. Located in this Fourth Part among the cities of Jazira is ancient Harran, where longitude is sixty-five degrees and latitude thirty-six degrees. It is on the main road to Mosul from Aleppo. Located is Ras al-Ayn where longitude is sixty-six degrees fifty-five minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees thirty minutes. Below it are many waters and orchards; from its springs, the Khabur gathers. Outside it is a lake of extreme depth; dinars are thrown into it to measure how they descend to its bottom, and divers descend after them to pick them up. It has abundant water lilies of various delightful colors. Located at the end of the latitude of the Fourth Clime is the city of Nusaybin, capital of Diyar Rabi'a, where longitude is sixty-seven degrees fifty minutes. It is distinguished by white roses whose rosewater pervades the world and is preferred over all other types. No red roses are found in it or within the borders. It is shielded in the North by the Large Mountain, from which descends the River Hirmas passing its wall, with many orchards on it, then pouring into the River Sayhan (likely Khabur tributary). Between Ras al-Ayn on the mountain is Mardin; its fortress cannot be aspired to. The Hamdanids used to call it the Ash-grey Falcon (al-Baz al-Ashhab). It has much goat hair (Mar'az) from which cloaks are carried to lands. Between it and Nusaybin is the Abode of the King of Persia (Dara?); it is now a village on a river on whose banks are many pomegranates and other things. South of Nusaybin is the city of Sinjar, one of the best cities. Its mountain is one of the most fertile, containing walnuts and almonds broken by the palm of the hand. From it, many pomegranate seeds, dried figs, and [...] made from grapes are brought. Inside it is a flowing spring exiting to the exterior, added to what becomes a river from it. The river of Nusaybin is added to it, and all pour into the famous Tharthar on which was the city of al-Hadr, now a ruin. In the forests of this river are many lions. It pours into the deserts. The location of Sinjar is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-five degrees forty minutes. The city of Mosul, capital of the land of Jazira, lies west of the Tigris where longitude is sixty-nine degrees and latitude thirty-five degrees thirty minutes. In front of it on the eastern side is Nineveh, city of Jonah peace be upon him, on a hill back; it is a ruin. There is the Hill of Repentance (Tell al-Tawbah). This city is one of the best lands in view regarding its waters, orchards, and streets on the Tigris. Its people have distinctiveness. It has many industries, especially inlaid copper vessels carried from it to kings, as well as silk clothes woven there. South and east of it on the eastern side is the mouth of the Lesser Zab near the ruined city of Ashur (Assur), mentioned in the Torah; the Assyrian kings who destroyed Jerusalem were there. After it, the Greater Zab pours from the eastern side; on it are orchards from which pomegranates are brought via Tigris to Baghdad. Tikrit, the last city of Jazira adjacent to Iraq, lies west of the Tigris where longitude is seventy-two and a half degrees. Between it and Mosul for caravans is six days, in a land where naphtha is made as if it were a piece of Hell. Near Mosul is a depression with hot water having a royal structure where people benefit. South and east of it is the Ishaqi River, dug in the days of al-Mutawakkil by Ishaq bin Ibrahim, chief of his police. It is the beginning of the Sawad (fertile lands) of Iraq; from there trees begin, and Tigris waters exit in which the land of Iraq swims. At it ends the Fourth Part. The city of Erbil (Irbil), capital of the land of Shahrazur, is located where longitude is sixty-nine degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees twenty minutes.

Part Five: The first thing you meet on the bank of the Tigris are the cities of Iraq. They are fourteen. Al-Zawra' (The Oblique) is one of them; it is the city of Al-Mansur on the western side of the Sarat River and Isa River descending from the Euphrates to the Tigris. The city where the Caliphate was in our time is on the eastern side. The length of its bowstring on the Tigris is two miles, and it has two bridges. Most buildings of Baghdad are of reed, baked brick, lime, and gypsum; its air spoils them, so hardly a glance falls upon them in all its buildings (they decay fast). Marble cracks from the heat. The cheapest thing there is dates, brought from Basra, and rice and sugar cane brought from the Marshes. The regions of Wasit contain Wasiti apples, Raziqi grapes, village bitter oranges, Yaqubi lemons, Baghdadi paper, and Wasiti pens. Ships ascend to it with goods of India on the Tigris. Its location is where longitude is seventy-three degrees and latitude thirty-three degrees nine minutes. The Isa River descends from the Euphrates and pours into the Tigris between the Village and al-Rishlah (?). It is one of the large rivers exiting the Euphrates, irrigating estates numbering the days of the months. Similar to it are the River of the King (Nahr al-Malik) and the River of the Nile. From the Tigris exit these waters in the land of Iraq: al-Qatul on the eastern side of Surra Man Ra'a (Samarra), and al-Nahrawan descends from Shahrazur to Baghdad. If a traveler goes from it to Ctesiphon (al-Mada'in), he crosses this river on a large bridge, and its mouth is in the Tigris. Al-Mada'in, which belonged to the Chosroes, is a stage from Baghdad. The Iwan (Arch) remains on the eastern side, made of brick and bitumen. People of Iraq often use bitumen in their buildings, especially in baths and water places. From al-Mada'in, the Tigris twists and goes west until Wasit is located in the Fourth Part, as mentioned. Then lie the Marshes of Wasit and Basra from rivers exiting the Tigris below Wasit in this part. They are eighty farsakhs by the same. They appeared during the days the Persians were busy fighting the Arabs in early Islam, becoming a secluded province, perhaps having a rebel king. Its capital is al-Jamid. The largest river pouring into it is the Euphrates. Most of its people are Chaldeans, on the religion of Seth peace be upon him; they call them Sabians. From the Chaldeans was Abu Ishaq al-Sabi the scribe; he has a work on that. The city of Basra, built in the Caliphate of Umar, lies where longitude is seventy-four degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees. It is on a river called al-Fayd (?) with its east and the Island of al-Ubulla—one of the world's parks—between this river, the Ma'qil River, the Ubulla River, and the Tigris. If the tide rises from the Persian Sea, it does not drink from these waters. They mention it ascends six days. Basra occupies a length of seven days from the source to the source (ayn to ayn), meaning from 'Abbas to Abadan. Abadan lies on the Persian River, which surrounds it leaving little between it and the mainland, where longitude is seventy-five degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees five minutes. The Tigris pours into the Persian Sea. South and east of Abadan are al-Khashabat (The Wooden Stakes); they are markers in the sea ships reach, warning of reefs that usually occur from the Tigris mouth. At night, lights are raised on these markers for ships. East of al-Khashabat is the mouth of the Tigris of Ahvaz, where longitude is seventy-seven degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees minus ten minutes. East of that is Mahruban, a port of Fars, where longitude is seventy-seven degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty degrees forty minutes. East of it is Jannabah, a port of Fars, to which Abu Sa'id al-Jannabi the Qarmatian, owner of heinous deeds, is attributed. Its location is where longitude is seventy-eight degrees twenty minutes. East of it is the most famous port of Fars, Siraf, where longitude is seventy-nine degrees and latitude thirty degrees thirty minutes. Its people are the most knowledgeable of sea leadership, and its buildings are of teak wood. Located in this part among the cities of Fars is its ancient capital, Istakhr (Persepolis), where longitude is seventy-nine degrees and a minute and latitude thirty-two degrees. In it were the treasuries of the Chosroes and the Diwan of Fars. That moved in Islam to Shiraz, built in the time of al-Hajjaj. It is where longitude is seventy-nine degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees thirty-one minutes. Its ruler now has a magnificent army and a house for pearls, some coming from its fishery, so the lands remain between fear and desire in security and health. Jur (Firuzabad), one of the capitals of the districts of Fars, lies where longitude is ninety-eight degrees [sic, likely 78] and latitude thirty-one degrees thirty minutes. To it is attributed the Juri rose...

...which is high quality like the Nusaybi. The city of Ahvaz, the ancient capital of Khuzestan, lies where longitude is seventy-five degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees; it is described with intense fever. From it to Askar Mukram is ten farsakhs. It is a famous city of Khuzestan surrounded by the Tigris of Ahvaz and the Masruqan River. It has Askar sugar and dragging scorpions whose victim does not survive. Thus it was said: As soon as its sugar rises, its scorpions sting. From it to the North and East is the city of Shushtar, capital of Khuzestan in our time. It was called Shtar. To it are attributed Shtari silk clothes. Between it and Askar Mukram is a stage. From it descend the waters of Isfahan gathering to the Tigris of Ahvaz. Between it and Isfahan is Mount al-Lawz (Almond Mountain), its length about six days, containing a multitude of Kurds and a king called Hrarast (?). Isfahan, one of the capitals of Persian Iraq known in books as al-Jibal, lies where longitude is seventy-five degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-four minutes. It consists of twelve quarters, each like a city; the described ones are Shahristan and al-Yahudiyyah. Zandrud, a beautiful river, passes these quarters. This city has healthy air such that three apples were presented to its governor, each from a year, and he could not distinguish the old from the new. It is said its grass is saffron, its soil is kohl, and its flies are bees. Isfahani honey is the ultimate, as are its roses. Nahavand, a famous city of al-Jibal, lies where longitude is seventy-three degrees thirty-one minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees. Hamadan, capital of Persian Iraq, lies where longitude is thirty-four degrees [sic, likely 74] and latitude thirty-six degrees thirty-one minutes; it is the end of the latitude of the Fourth Clime. Nuditund (?) lies where longitude is seventy-five degrees thirty-one minutes; it is in Mount Damavand veiled by clouds; there is no mountain in Persian Iraq higher than it. The fortress city of Gerdkuh, famous among Ismaili strongholds, lies where longitude is fifty-nine degrees [sic, likely 79] and latitude thirty-six degrees. It is the Quhistan mountain between Khurasan, Fars, and Kerman. In this part is the capital of Kerman in our time, Kawashir (Bardasir?), where longitude is eighty-four degrees and latitude thirty degrees twenty minutes. Among ancient capitals of Kerman is al-Shirjan, where longitude is eighty-four degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees. Likewise the city of Jiroft, where longitude is eighty-five and a half degrees and latitude thirty-two degrees ten minutes. In its mountains is Kerman iron from which Kerman swords are made. Located in this part among the capitals of Khurasan is the city of Herat, where longitude is eighty-seven degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-five and a half degrees. West of it is the capital of Quhistan where longitude is eighty-four degrees and latitude thirty-five degrees ten minutes. East of it with the South are the mountains of Ghur; their capital is the city of Firuzkuh, where longitude is eighty-nine degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees. [Note: The Arabic text repeats the paragraph starting from "Juri rose..." to the end. Translation covers the unique content].

Part Six: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Bamiyan. It is a capital for its regions, surrounded by mountains and waters. From its mountain descend some rivers of Jayhun (Oxus). The location of Bamiyan is where longitude is seventy degrees five minutes and latitude thirty-four degrees. The most famous, largest, and longest flowing of Jayhun's rivers is River [...], descending from the mountains of Khatan (?), where longitude is ninety-seven degrees and latitude thirty degrees three minutes. Many springs descend to it from that mountain and from the mountains of Kabulistan of the Third Clime. When it passes the mountain of Bamiyan, rivers with obscure names descend to it, then they all gather near the end of the latitude of the Fourth Clime. Its main column, Jayhun, descends to the Fifth. East of Mount Ghur and Bamiyan, and west of Kabulistan, lie the lands of Sijistan (Seistan). Its ancient capital is Zaranj, where longitude is seventy-four degrees seven minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees six minutes. The Indian River Sindh, exiting from the east of the Ghur mountains, traverses the lands of Sijistan from west to east. The city of Bust lies on it to its north, where longitude is ninety-three degrees and latitude thirty degrees. Then the river passes until it ends where longitude is ninety-five degrees to the South. Zaranj is to its north by about twenty miles; a stream reaches it from the river splitting it, utilized by its people for the Mosque and other things. Then the river twists West. At the place of its twisting, on a cut-off mountain of extreme impregnability, is the stronghold of al-Taq, which cannot be aspired to. The kings of these lands take refuge in it and place their treasuries there. Its longitude aligns with Zaranj, and latitude is thirty-one degrees. The river passes north of it westward until it pours into Lake Sijistan. The length of this lake from West to East is three days, and width is half that. South of Sijistan are the domains of the Khalaj, who are Turks. They have gallantry (and tested well) in the conquests of India, conquering what bordered them and owning the city of Uch and the city of Nahawar on the River Mehran. North of Sijistan is the land of Tukharistan; its capital is Tirmidh in the Fifth Clime on the River Jayhun. East of it is the land of Khatan with obscure names. At its edges are rivers and meadows inhabited by Turkish races; they fight over them with the Indians, for they neighbor them from the South. Part Seven: The first thing you meet in it is the Indian land of Qandabar; its capital was previously mentioned at the end of the Third Clime's line. Muslims had conquered it and made it a frontier for what is east of it. Then they conquered in its east the land of Uch on the east of Mehran descending to the land of Sindh, where longitude is one hundred and twenty degrees fifty-five minutes and latitude thirty-three degrees. East of it is the land of Nahawar, also conquered by Muslims from the Turks. Its capital is the city of Nahawar, also on the east of Mehran, where longitude is one hundred and sixty-five degrees and latitude thirty-four degrees twelve minutes.

Part Eight: The first thing you meet in it is Hindustan. It is what the Ghurids conquered of India. Its capital is Delhi, which is large. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-eight degrees fifty minutes and latitude thirty-five degrees fifty minutes. It has three ponds of rainwater: one for the Sultan, one for the soldiers, and one for the commoners. The ruler of Delhi in our time is one of the Mamluks of the Ghurids. His army consists of Muslim Turks, and the subjects are disbelieving Indians. The Tatars could not overcome his land due to the brave men (Lions of Men) and many elephants he has. Located in this part among the capitals of Hindustan, each having a king, is Hasi (Hansi): It is at the beginning of the part, where longitude is one hundred and twenty-six degrees eight minutes and latitude thirty-one degrees. East of it by a stage is the city of Barawar. It is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-nine degrees and latitude thirty-one degrees thirty-five minutes. East of it and east of Delhi are the mountains of Kashmir, inhabited by a race generated between India and Sindh. The Turks are of utmost beauty. The Tatars could not overcome them due to their impregnability in the mountains surrounding them in this Fifth Clime. The River Ganges, venerated by Indians, passes through their lands. They also venerate it and drown themselves in it because they share the error with them. East of them is Tamghaj, the land of Khita (Cathay). Travelers claim the wall surrounds its cities, estates, and all settlements for about twenty-three days in length from West to East. Its western border is the land of Kashmir, and its eastern border is the land of the Tatars. Its length and width take up this part and the next part of the Fifth Clime. Famous among its cities is the city of Tamghaj. The city of Khanbaliq (Beijing) has taken its place in this era of ours. They mention regarding the size of this city what only an eyewitness would believe. Its ruler is a Muslim called Lwaja (?), originally from Khwarizm; he carries monies to the Tatars. The subjects are disbelievers from the races of Khita, most of whom have entered Islam. Silk is abundant in their lands. It is said they have many silver mines. South of their lands is the land of Ballhara, King of Kings of India. The city of Khanbaliq is located where longitude is one hundred and forty degrees and latitude thirty-five degrees twenty-five minutes. The city of Tamghaj is in the Fifth Clime. Part Nine: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Kharaq (Karakorum?), one of the ancient capitals of the Tatars. It is where longitude is forty-six degrees [sic, likely 146] and latitude thirty-five degrees forty-five minutes. East of it is the city of Yanbu'a (?), which was the capital of the Tatars in ancient times. It is on a river descending from the Great Mountain extending over the lands of India and China. It is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-two degrees and latitude thirty degrees five minutes. East of it is a river descending from the River of the Port to the River of Yajooj (Gog). East of that is the capital of the Tatars in our time, Karakorum. It is where longitude is one hundred and fifty degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty degrees thirty-six minutes. In its regions are the lands of the Mughals, the elite of the Tatars; their Khans are from there. They have in this part and the next Lake Kawarith. South of it is Mount Kawarith from which the river of the Lake [...] descends and the river of the lake which will be mentioned. Part Ten: Contains the rest of the land of the Mughals and the rest of the lake of the land of Kawarith. East of it is Lake Sukam; its length is four stages and width two stages. No river descends to it; rather, springs are inside it, and rainwater seeps to it from the directions. East of it is the land of Turghay (?), a bird that hunts two birds in one rise; it strikes the first leaving it to fall then hunts the second. It is also called the land of Sunqur (Falcon). South of them and east of the Mughal land is the land of Samighli. They are brothers of the Mughals, but leadership belongs to the Mughals. They have the city of Samighli on a lake where longitude is one hundred and seventy-seven degrees twenty-two minutes and latitude thirty-two degrees minus minutes. They have a mountain winding on the east of their lands from Sin-Sin and entering the Surrounding Ocean. Two rivers descend to them from it into two lakes, the overflow of which descends to the sea at the end of the inhabited world. North of them is the River Manjar the Great, descending from the Great Mountain of China forming a medium lake at its end, then a river exits it forming a small lake, then its overflow pours into the Surrounding Ocean. North of this river are the Mountains of Qarqar, circling the lands of these people. Travelers claim their eyes are in their chests. They have the city of Qarqar at the end of habitation. South of it is a lake from which a river exits to a second lake. Fifth Clime

The whiteness of its people is mixed with redness. Blondness and blue eyes are common among them, especially in what borders the Sixth. The latitude at its end from the Equator is forty-one degrees thirty-one minutes, and its width is five degrees. Part One: The first thing you meet in it in the sea are three of the Islands of Happiness, as drawn. And the Island of Cadiz (Qadis); it is small, part in the Fourth Clime and part in the Fifth. Between it and the mainland is a strait of small width. Longitude is eight degrees twenty-one minutes. From that place, the Surrounding Ocean begins to decline to the West with North. The mouth of the River of Seville (Guadalquivir) and Cordoba is where longitude is eight degrees fifteen minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees forty-five minutes. Then to the Island of Saltes (Shaltish) thirty-six degrees [sic - distance/degrees confusion], where longitude is seven degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-seven degrees twelve minutes. Then to the mouth of the Great River Guadiana (Yana), passing Merida and Badajoz, nine miles. Then to the city of Tavira (Tawirah) twenty-three miles. It is on the River Guadiana and north of it. Then to the mouth of the River Santa Maria eighteen miles. Then to the mouth of the River Silves (Shalb) twenty-eight miles. Then to Hawz al-Rayhan fifteen miles. Then to Cape St. Vincent (Tarf al-'Urf) eighty miles. It enters the sea from this Cape twenty-two miles; it is the end of the latitude of the Fifth Clime. The longitude there is six degrees. The longitude of the city of Seville, east and south of the river, is nine degrees ten minutes, and latitude thirty-seven degrees thirty minutes. Longitude of the city of Badajoz on the south of Guadiana is nine degrees, and latitude thirty-eight degrees fifty minutes. Longitude of the city of Merida south of the mentioned river is ten degrees minus minutes, and latitude thirty-nine degrees. Longitude of Cordoba, capital of Andalusia in the time of the Umayyads, is ten degrees, and its latitude thirty-eight and a half degrees. It is west of the Great River on which Seville lies. This river only beautifies its sides at Seville. The tide ascends in it from the Surrounding Ocean seventy-two miles. Frankish ships ascend with their cargo to Seville. Longitude of the city of Granada is eleven degrees forty minutes, and latitude thirty-seven degrees thirty minutes. South of it is Mount Sierra Nevada (Shulayr), which snow never leaves. Ibn al-Yashi' recounted that over twenty rivers descend from it, including the River Darro (Hadarro/River of Gold) which splits Granada, and River Genil (Masil?) which passes its wall; both have mills and orchards. This city in our time is the capital of Ibn al-Ahmar, king of those remaining Muslims in Andalusia. Longitude of the city of Jaen is like the longitude of Granada, and latitude thirty-nine degrees minus minutes. Longitude of the city of Murcia is eighteen degrees. Latitude is thirty-nine degrees and minutes. It is north of a beautiful river having waterwheels and orchards. It is the end of the River of Seville whose source is from Mount Segura (Shaqurah), where longitude is fifteen degrees and latitude thirty-eight degrees forty minutes. It exits from a single spring, flows east past Murcia and pours into the Sea of the Romans, while the River of Seville flows west and pours into the Surrounding Ocean.

Part Two: The first thing you meet in it on the Sea of the Romans is the city of Denia where longitude is nineteen degrees ten minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees six minutes. East of it is Valencia, famous for beauty, called the Garden of Andalusia. It is on a lake into which a river pours north of the city. It is where longitude is twenty degrees and latitude thirty-eight degrees six minutes. East of it is the city of Tortosa east of the Great River (Ebro) passing Zaragoza; its mouth in the Sea of the Romans is about twenty miles from Tortosa. It is where longitude is twenty-two and a half degrees and latitude forty degrees. East of it in the Sea of the Romans is the Island of Majorca (Mayurqa), famous for fertility. Its city is where longitude is twenty-four degrees seven minutes and latitude thirty-eight degrees thirty minutes. The island's distance is sixty miles, stretching from North to South. Between it and Barcelona is a course and a third. East of it is the Island of Minorca (Manurqa). Nothing remains for Muslims in those islands except it; Sa'id bin al-Hakam, famous for good conduct, manages it under a pact with [...]. Its city is where longitude is twenty-five degrees minus minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees forty minutes. Its distance is forty miles from North to South with a tilt to the East. From it to the coast is three courses. West of Majorca is the Island of Ibiza (Yabisah). Its city is where longitude is twenty degrees four minutes. It stretches from West to East, its distance thirty-one miles. Between it and Valencia is a course. East of Minorca is the Island of Sardinia. Its city is where longitude is thirty-one degrees twelve minutes. In its west, coral comes out. The length of this island from North to South is two and a half courses. The narrow part towards Marsa al-Kharaz is one hundred miles and a little. North of it is the Island of Corsica opposite Genoa. Its length from North to South is a course and a half. The narrow part towards Genoa and the width in the middle is sixty miles. The strait between it and Sardinia is about ten miles. East of it is the famous Island of Sicily, possessing cities, mountains, and rivers. It became pure for Muslims then pure for Franks. Its length is two courses and width a course and a little. The capital Palermo lies where longitude is thirty-five degrees and latitude thirty-six degrees thirty minutes; it is on the sea. Messina, facing the land of the Franks at the strait, lies where longitude is thirty-six degrees minus twenty minutes and latitude thirty-eight degrees fifteen minutes. It has the famous Volcano (Etna/Vulcano?) in a small island in the direction of Messina. Between it and Tripoli is three courses. Between its western tail and the capital Tunis is a course and sixty minutes. Sicily is to the East, from South to North twenty miles. At Messina is a breakwater said to be made by Alexander, carved in stone. North of Sicily is the land of Calabria at the end of Part Two of the Fifth Clime. Located is the city of Naples famous on that coast, where longitude is thirty-four degrees thirty minutes. Near it is Salerno from which large hazelnuts are brought. West of Naples is the city of Rome, capital of the Pope. It is on both sides of the River Tiber. Its sides were reinforced because it collapses. Ships enter it from the sea to between the shops, so people buy what they need. It comes from a mountain in its north. It is very large. In its center is a fortified castle on a cut-off hill. The location of this city is where longitude is thirty-three degrees and latitude with the end of the Fifth Clime forty-one degrees thirty-one minutes. So said Ibn Fatimah, and he is the verifier. Al-Khwarizmi said: Longitude thirty-five degrees thirty minutes and latitude forty-three degrees fifty minutes, so it enters the Sixth Clime. West of it is Pisa, famous among ports of the Franks frequenting Islamic lands. It is where longitude is thirty-three and a half degrees and latitude forty-one degrees. Between it and the sea is miles; a river described with beauty splits it. West of it is the famous city of Genoa. It is on the west of a large bay, where longitude is thirty-one degrees minus minutes and latitude forty-one degrees twenty minutes. The sea between it and Andalusia enters to the North, narrowing what is on it of the Sixth Clime. Above Genoa is Mount Lombardy; in it, linen (?) is made and gold smelted. It has a harbor made by its people with stones; it is round, a person anchors his ship at his house.

Part Three: The first thing you meet in it in the Sea of the Strait (Mediterranean) is the land of Puglia (Apulia), from which Franks bring oil to Alexandria and elsewhere. From there, the sea goes to the famous Island of Crete (Iqritish), which the Muslims, the people of the Rabad of Cordoba, conquered in the time of Al-Ma'mun and ruled for a period. Then the Kharayita (Greeks/Byzantines?) regained it, so it is now in their hands. Its length is three hundred and fifty miles from West to East. Its city is where longitude is forty-seven degrees seven minutes and latitude [offset by] one and a half degrees. Cheese and honey are brought from it to Alexandria. East of it is the Island of Rhodes. Muawiyah had conquered it and placed a garrison there to raid the Gulf of Constantinople. Then Yazid withheld their pay, so they fled to the Levant and evacuated it, and the Romans possessed it. It is now among the islands of the Kharayita. The length of this island slanted from North to South is about fifty miles, and the width half that. Between it and the mainland of the Kharayita from the direction of its city is about fifteen miles. Between it and the tail of Crete is a course; Crete is West by South. Between Rhodes and Antioch is three courses. East of it is the Island of Cyprus, conquered by Muslims in the time of Muawiyah. Its city is in its center, where longitude enters Part Four at fifty-five and a half degrees and latitude thirty degrees and minutes. The length of this island from West to East is two hundred miles. It has a thin tail looking East to the coast of the Levant. Its wide breadth is one hundred miles and narrow is miles. Between the island and the mainland of Karak of the land of Sis is half a course. Lac, which is a gum, is brought from it. Al-Bakri mentioned it has a copper mine.

Part Four: The first thing you meet in it on the Levantine mainland is the coast of the land of al-Durub (Mountain Passes/Cilicia). Famous Antioch lies where longitude is fifty-two and a half degrees and latitude thirty-eight degrees. Its harbor is not safe in storms. It has the fleet of the ruler of al-Durub. It belonged to the Romans, then Muslims seized it in our time. North of it is the Lake of Torches (Buhayrat al-Masha'il); if a person climbs the mountains north of Antioch at night, he sees in its directions as if torches are burning. East of it is Alanya (al-'Alaya), built by Ala al-Din Kayqubad, ruler of Konya in our time. Between the two ports is one hundred miles. It is inside a bay, and slightly wider (higher latitude) than Konya. East of it, among famous ports, is Sis (Sikin/Silifke?) at one hundred miles also. Aksar (Akhisar?), famous for many fruits, lies between Alanya and Sikin in longitude, its latitude forty and a half degrees. Aksaray, also famous for fruits, lies where it exceeds Aksar in longitude by a degree and is at its latitude. Sis, capital of the Northern Frontier lands, lies north of its river and west of the mountain surrounding it, where longitude is sixty-three degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-eight degrees. North of the mountain is the city of Malatya, capital of the Jazira Frontiers. It is where longitude is fifty-three degrees and latitude forty degrees fifty minutes. Thus mentioned in the geography of Ibn Fatimah. Al-Khwarizmi said: Longitude sixty-one degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees. [...] lies on the east of the Euphrates, where longitude is sixty-five degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees forty minutes. It is now the frontier of Islam facing the Tatars. Its castle is in a rock of a single piece. Mayyafariqin, capital of Diyar Bakr of the land of Jazira, lies where longitude is sixty-six degrees and latitude thirty-eight and a half degrees. It is like Nusaybin in being surrounded by waters and orchards. Its people showed entry (heroism?) in their siege by the Tatars for two full years until they perished and the Tatars desisted from them, so whoever remained fled. In it is the grave of Sayf al-Dawla ibn Hamdan. Amid (Diyarbakir), capital of Banu Artuq in Diyar Bakr west of the Tigris, lies where longitude is sixty-five degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees fifty minutes. Its ruler is called Shah Armen. It is famous for rich merchants and abundance of amusements and jokes. East of it is Lake Van (Arjish). Its length from West to East with a tilt to the South is four stages, and width about a stage. Tarikh (fish) is found in it, salted and carried to regions. Large ships travel in it from Arjish to Ahlat and others. The source of the Tigris, according to what is reported from Ptolemy, is located where longitude is sixty-four degrees forty minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees. That is east of Qaliqala (Erzurum) and west of Ahlat, in a mountain called al-Qaras. The spring is called Tigris. Many rivers join it, so it widens below Amid. Keleks (rafts) descend on it from there; they are logs with inflated skins underneath. The city of Arzan lies where longitude is sixty-six degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees ten minutes. The River Arzan descends to the Tigris and increases it. In this part lies Mardin, known as the Ash-grey Falcon for its height, where longitude is sixty-six degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-seven degrees fifty minutes. And the city of Ras al-Ayn is with the beginning of the Fifth Clime, longitude sixty-six degrees. From its waters descends the River Khabur. East of the Tigris is Mount Judi mentioned in the Quran; snow never leaves it. It appears from afar due to its height. On it is the village of Thamanin (Eighty), being the number saved with Noah peace be upon him in the Ark. East of that from the land of Azerbaijan is Khoy, where longitude is seventy degrees and latitude forty degrees. Aligned with it in latitude is Salmas. Salmas is a degree longer. North of Salmas is Urmia, Persians call it Urmi, where longitude is seventy-one degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees. North of these lands with a tilt to the West is the land of Shirvan; its city is in the Sixth Clime.

Part Five: At its beginning and the end of Part Four is the Lake of Azerbaijan (Lake Urmia). Its center is where longitude is seventy-two degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees thirty minutes. Its length from West to East with a tilt to the South is about one hundred and thirty miles, and its width is about half that. In its center is an island, which is a cut-off mountain enough to make a fortress named Bala (Shahi Island?), where the son of Hulagu placed his family and treasures. At the northeastern head of this lake by a stage is the city of Maragha, which was the capital of Azerbaijan, then destroyed by the Tatars. It is where longitude is seventy-two degrees fifty minutes and latitude forty degrees thirty minutes. East of the Lake is the city of Tabriz (Turiz), capital of Azerbaijan in our time. It is where longitude is seventy-three degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees ten minutes. Its name in books is Tabriz. Its buildings are beautiful with gypsum and lime, and it has fine madrasas. It has a lovely Ghouta (oasis). Among its leaders were those who managed it with the Tatars, so what happened to Maragha and others did not happen to it. North of it is the city of Ardabil, one of the ancient capitals of Azerbaijan. It is where longitude is sixty-four degrees [sic, likely 74] and latitude forty-one degrees minus seven minutes. East of that is the land of Daylam and its mountains. Its city which is aspired to (conquered?) is named al-Tuzm, where longitude is seventy-five and a half degrees and latitude thirty-eight degrees forty-two minutes. North of it is the land of al-Jabal (Jibal); they are brothers of Daylam. They have on Tabaristan the port of Salus (Chalus), from which ships travel. It is where longitude is seventy-seven degrees forty-six minutes and latitude forty degrees. East of that is the land of Tabaristan. Its capital is Amol, where longitude is seventy-seven degrees eighteen minutes and latitude thirty-eight degrees fifty minutes. On its coast is the port of 'Ayn al-Hum (?), where longitude is seventy-seven degrees fifteen minutes and latitude thirty-nine and a half degrees. East of it is Rayy, famous on the main road; between them is about eighty miles. East of it is Semnan, capital of the land of Qumis, where longitude is seventy-seven degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees. Among the cities of Qumis are Bistam and Damghan. East and north of that is the city of Jurjan (Gorgan), capital of the lands attributed to it. It is where longitude is eighty and a half degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees ten minutes. On the Sea of Tabaristan (Caspian) is the port of Jurjan, Abaskun, where longitude is seventy-nine degrees [sic] forty minutes. In the southeast corner of the sea is the city of Firaq, port of Dehistan, where longitude is eighty-two degrees twelve minutes and latitude forty degrees twenty minutes. North of it is the Ribat of Dehistan on the sea at the end of the latitude of the Fifth Clime; between it and Firaq is two stages. East and south of Jurjan is the city of Nishapur, capital of Khurasan in the days of Banu Tahir. Persians call it Shawur. It was a destination for merchants. It is where longitude is eighty-one degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees. East and north of it, among the famous cities of Khurasan, is the city of Nisa, where longitude is eighty-two degrees thirty minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees. East of it is the city of Merv, capital of Khurasan in the days of the Seljuks and in early Islam. It is on the Murghab River, where longitude is eighty-four degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-seven degrees forty minutes. In its land is abundant cotton; Mervian clothes are made there. It is called Merv al-Shahijan to distinguish it from Merv al-Rudh. East of it is the city of Balkh, capital of Khurasan in the period of the Chosroes, where their worshipped fire was, which the Barmakids served. It was also the capital of the Saffarids in Islam. It is where longitude is eighty-eight degrees thirty-five minutes. East and south of it is the famous city of Tirmidh on the east of Jayhun (Oxus). It is the capital of Tukharistan, where longitude is ninety degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees thirty minutes. Part Six: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Bukhara. It is the capital of Transoxiana (Ma Wara' al-Nahr). The River Sogd irrigates it, and what exceeds the irrigation of its land descends to Jayhun.

Its location is where longitude is ninety degrees twenty minutes and latitude thirty-nine degrees minus eighteen minutes. East and south of it is the city of Samarkand, capital of Sogdiana (al-Sughd) south of the River Sogd, where longitude is ninety-one degrees fifty-two minutes and latitude thirty-six degrees thirty minutes. Its river descends from the Buttam Mountains south of it in the Fourth Clime. East of that are many obscure cities west and east of the River Sayhun (Jaxartes). South of it is the land of Farghana; it has many obscure cities. North of it is the land of Shash (Tashkent), famous for waters and orchards; it has many obscure cities. East of it is the city of al-Tarran (Otrar?), where longitude is one hundred degrees and latitude forty degrees minus minutes. It is east of a river descending from Sayhun. It is called the City of Merchants (Madinat al-Tujjar - referring to 'Bahhar' implies seas, likely error for Tujjar or similar). It has many obscure cities. Part Seven: The first thing you meet in it is the Gate (Bab) placed by Al-Fadl bin Yahya in the face of the Turks who used to raid the lands of Islam from the East. There is a wall extending from North to South. The location of that place is where longitude is one hundred and eleven degrees. East of that is Turkestan, a long wide region having a western capital, Kashgar. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and fourteen degrees and latitude thirty-seven degrees twenty minutes. The second is eastern, Barsjan, located where longitude is one hundred and eighteen degrees forty minutes and latitude forty degrees sixty minutes. These belonged to the disbelieving Turks in the time of Al-Fadl bin Yahya al-Barmaki, then they converted to Islam afterwards and entered the obedience of the Seljuks. Islam extended through them to the land of Tibet. They have obscure cities and domains for tent dwellers. East of them is the Castle of al-Dahhak, located on a mountain like the letter Dal. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-five degrees seventeen minutes and latitude thirty-seven degrees thirty-four minutes. Below the mountain under the castle is a pond; its southwestern quarter is in this part, its southeastern quarter in this second part, and the northern half in the Sixth Clime. Its center is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-six degrees and latitude forty-one degrees and a minute. Its extension from North to South is about six stages, and its width about three and a half stages. Mount Sunbul encircles it like a ring; musk gazelles graze in it and drink from its waters, which are of utmost sweetness, descending from all its sides into this pond. Part Eight: The first thing you meet in it after the Lake of Tibet is the city of Tibeta, the capital of the lands, where longitude is one hundred and thirty degrees and latitude forty degrees twenty minutes. East of it are the mountains of Kashmir, which the Tatars could not overcome due to their difficulty. In this part are the mentioned mountains with the River Ganges, venerated by Indians, which pours into their sea. It is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-three degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees. Water descends to it from latitude forty-one degrees. East of it to the end of the part is the land of Tamghaj where the cities of Khita and their domains are. Most of what is in their lands is silk. Their currency is Dinars made by their kings from paper bearing their inscriptions. In this part lies the ancient capital named Tamghaj. That is where longitude is one hundred and thirty-four degrees and latitude forty-one degrees. Part Nine: The first thing you meet in it is the source of the River of Gog (Yajooj), where longitude is one hundred and forty-five degrees and latitude thirty-nine degrees twenty-four minutes. North of it is the Lake of Demons (Buhayrat al-Shayatin) surrounded by a mountain in the drawn image. Half of it is in this part, and the other half in the Sixth Clime. It is rumored in those regions that demons protected it; if anyone swims in it, they harm him. On the mountain connected to it extending to Gog and Magog is the Idol of Lesser Marble, a temple to which many people of those regions make pilgrimage. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and twenty degrees twelve minutes, and latitude with the end of the Fifth Clime. In an arc south of it, the River of Gog descends until it enters the Sixth Clime. East of this river is Lake Aghri, surrounded by a mountain. East of it is Lake Nihamah; a river exits it falling into the River of Gog, and a river enters it from the Mountain of Gog. The length of this lake from West to East is four stages, and its width two stages. South of it is Lake Ghaghan; its length from South to North is five stages and its width three stages. East of it is Kimakiyah, the city of the Kimak Turks. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-nine degrees and latitude thirty-six degrees twenty minutes.

Part Ten: The first thing you meet in it is the Fortress of Dhul-Qarnayn, which he made to guard the Dam, where longitude is one hundred and sixty-three degrees and latitude forty degrees. North of it is the Gate of the Dam. The Dam extends from North to South, connected to the mountain surrounding Gog and Magog from the mountain transversing from the head of the Dam to the Surrounding Ocean, where longitude is one hundred and sixty-five degrees four minutes and latitude sixty-seven degrees twelve minutes. Along it are the settlements of Gog until it pours into the sea in the Sixth Clime. Located in this part to the end of habitation is the land of Zardaqiya. No sect of the Turks has established a standing other than them. God has busied them with fighting in the lands of the Kimak River, descending from the Fourth Clime from the edge of the mountain of Gog and Magog. From its branching forms an island containing the city of Zardaqiya, where longitude is one hundred and seventy degrees and latitude thirty-eight degrees. They have in the west of their lands a large lake into which two rivers pour from the mentioned mountain, and a smaller lake in its east. Sixth Clime: The whiteness of their people intensifies until it spreads to their hair. Blue eyes and blondness deepen in them, and freckles are often among them. No condition works for them in winter except with braziers in which they light fires in their houses; this increases further north. The latitude at its end from the Equator is forty-five degrees, and its width is four degrees minus twenty-one minutes.

Part One: The first thing you meet in it on the Surrounding Ocean is the Church of the Raven (Kanisat al-Ghurab - Cape St. Vincent region), famous among sailors. Between it and the Cape of the Mane (Tarf al-'Urf - Cape St. Vincent), mentioned at the end of the latitude of the First Part of the Fifth Clime, is seven miles. The longitude there from the direction of the Eternal Islands is six degrees. From there to where River Abu Danis (Vadiana/Guadiana mouth area?) is forty miles. On it is the castle attributed to it. The worshippers of the Cross had a famous war on it in our time with the Muslims; it was the last frontier of Islam in that direction. From it to the mouth of the Great River of Lisbon (Tagus) is forty miles. From the sea to Lisbon is thirty miles. It is on the southern side of the river, where longitude is seven degrees minus minutes and latitude forty-two minutes. In front of it to the North is a salty lake, and to its west another. Travelers mentioned that the width of the river mouth widens to become ten miles. North of this mouth at thirty miles is the city of Sintra (Shantrah), where herbs are found abundantly on its coast. It was the furthest frontier of Islam on the coast before the Blind Strife. North of it is the edge of the great Mount al-Sharah (Sierra de Guadarrama/Central System) which divides Andalusia into two rows. North of it is the city of Montemor (?) of the land of Galicia from which the volcano exits. It is on the north of a river pouring from the mentioned mountain into the Ocean. North of that is the mouth of the River Coimbra (Mondego). North of it is the city of Salamanca (Samalanqah), famous in the land of Portugal. It is the end of the latitude of the Sixth Clime, where longitude is seven degrees twenty minutes and latitude forty-five degrees. Between it and the city of Coimbra, capital of Galicia, is two stages; it is east of it. North of the river and on Mount al-Sharah extending from east Andalusia to its west are many obscure fortresses. Among them in this part is the Fortress of the Table (Hisn al-Ma'idah), where it is said the Table of Solomon peace be upon him was preserved. Tariq bin Ziyad took it from there when he conquered Toledo. Between them is two stages, and the fortress is in the North. South of Mount al-Sharah is the city of Coria (Quriyah), which was a Muslim frontier in the period of the Kings of Taifas. Its location is where longitude is eight degrees thirty minutes and latitude forty-four degrees minus minutes. South of it and south of the River of Toledo (Tagus) is the city of Santarem (Shantarin), where longitude is eight degrees ten minutes and latitude forty-two degrees thirty-five minutes. In its direction to the East on the south of the river is the Fortress of the Sword Bridge (Qantarat al-Sayf - Alcantara); between them is eighty miles. East of that on the north of the river is the city of Valladolid (Walid?), one of the beautiful cities where the Alfons (Al-Fansh) stays most of his times. It has many orchards and has three rivers other than the Great River. Its location is where longitude is eleven degrees fifty-two minutes and latitude forty-three degrees three minutes. East of it is the capital of Andalusia, Toledo (Tulaytulah), where longitude is fifteen and a half degrees and latitude forty-three degrees eighteen minutes. It is one of the most impregnable lands on a high mountain. The river surrounds most of it. Its river descends from Mount al-Sharah at a fortress called Tajah, and is named after it (Tagus). Muslims entered the Island of Andalusia when its Sultan was of the Goths called Roderic, and his capital was Toledo. The Christians regained it and all mentioned in this part and to be mentioned, after the departure of the Marwanid state. East of the River Tagus is the source of the River Guadiana (Yana), passing by Ptolemy (?). It is large; the tide ascends in it about sixty miles at the end of the latitude of the Sixth Clime. On the River Sintra is the city of Avila (Iblah), famous in raids. Its location is where longitude is thirteen degrees minus nine minutes. East of Toledo is the City of Joy (Madinat al-Faraj - Guadalajara), and its river is called Wadi al-Hajara. It is where longitude is seventeen degrees minus minutes and latitude forty-three degrees twenty minutes. East of it is Medinaceli (Madinat Salim), capital of the Middle Frontier. It is where longitude is eighteen degrees and latitude forty-three degrees.

Part Two: The first thing you meet in it is the source of the River Jucar (Shuqar) from Mount al-Sharah. It passes the Island of Sumar (Jazirat Shuqar - Alcira?), famous for beauty, and pours into the sea between Valencia and Denia. Near it is the source of the Great River of Zaragoza (Ebro), passing first Mount Mutalla (?), then south of Zaragoza, then west of Tortosa, pouring into the sea below it. The city of Tudela (Tutilah) lies south of Mount al-Sharah where longitude is twenty and a half degrees and latitude forty-three degrees fifty-five minutes. Zaragoza (Saraqusta), capital of the Upper Frontier, lies where longitude is twenty-one degrees thirty minutes. East of it is the city of Lleida (Laridah), the furthest frontier of Andalusia, where longitude is twenty-two degrees forty minutes. It is east of a river descending into the River of Zaragoza. East of it is Mount Albert (Pyrenees) separating the Island of Andalusia from the Big Land. When the seas surrounded Andalusia and only this entrance remained—its distance four stages—it was named an Island. In this mountain are the gates dug by the Queen of Greece to facilitate her entry to Andalusia. In the middle of the mountain is the Temple of Venus worshipped by the people of those mountains before Christianity. It is where longitude is twenty-four degrees and latitude forty-three degrees. At the edge of this mountain with the Sea of the Strait is Tarragona (Tarqunah), the last coastal city of Andalusia to its east and south. Its location is where longitude is twenty-three degrees twenty minutes, and latitude with the first of the Sixth Clime. At the northern tip of furthest Andalusia, facing the tip of Tarragona on the Surrounding Ocean, is the city of Bayonne (Bayunah), port of the Kingdom of Navarre (al-Nabri), from which Carracks exit. Its location is where longitude is twenty-three degrees forty minutes and latitude forty-four degrees. West of it behind Mount al-Sharah is the capital of Navarre, Pamplona (Banbuluna), where longitude is twenty-two degrees fifteen minutes and latitude forty-four degrees. West of it, in the latitude of Castile, is the city of Burgos (Barghash), the arsenal of weapons made in the land of the Alfons. Its location is where longitude north of the Great Mountain is nineteen degrees forty-five minutes. Outside the lands of Andalusia is the city of Barcelona (Barshiluna), capital of the Barceloni, King of the Catalans. He traces his lineage to Jabalah bin al-Ayham, King of Ghassan who converted to Christianity in the Caliphate of Umar bin al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him. It is on the Sea of the Strait where longitude is twenty-four and a half degrees and latitude forty-two degrees eighteen minutes. It has waters and orchards. It was from the conquests of Muslims, then the Mila (Christians) regained it. East of it is Castello (Qastalyun - Castello d'Empuries?), a stronghold of pirates. Its location is where longitude is twenty-five degrees twenty-seven minutes and latitude forty-three degrees. North of Barcelona is the city of Bordeaux (Bardal? context suggests Southern France but Bordeaux is west), to which Bardalian swords are attributed. It is where longitude is twenty-five degrees and latitude forty-four degrees. It is east of a sweet lake into which a river pours and which pours into the sea. East of Bordeaux is the city of Toulouse (Tuluzah). It is said its Frankish ruler has over a thousand fortresses in the mountains to his north and east; he is close to the ruler of France. Its location is where longitude is twenty-seven degrees and latitude forty-four degrees. From the river in its south, ships ascend from the Surrounding Ocean with tin and copper brought from the Island of England and the Island of Ireland, carried on backs to Narbonne, and from there carried in ships to Alexandria. The city of Narbonne (Narbuna) lies where longitude is twenty-seven degrees and latitude forty-three degrees twenty minutes. South of it is a lake connecting to the Sea of the Strait. Musa bin Nusayr reached it in the conquest of Andalusia and placed the idol in its east, on which was: O Sons of Ishmael, return. It was said that happened by a trick of the soldiers so he would return, so he returned. Narbonne remained the furthest frontier of Muslims in east Andalusia until the Franks regained it during the Strife. East of it by miles from a bay is the city of Montpellier (Munbulir), famous for wealthy merchants. Its location is where longitude is twenty-eight degrees and latitude forty-three degrees fifty minutes. Towards the South is the city of Marseille (Marsiliyah), one of the ports of the Franks frequenting the lands of Islam.

Its location is where longitude is twenty-nine degrees and latitude forty-three degrees. East of it is Lombardy (al-Inkbardiyah), mountains surrounding it up to the border of Genoa. It consists of cities and settlements penetrated by rivers where ships sail with sails. Its capital is the city of Milan (Malan), where longitude is thirty degrees thirty-seven minutes and latitude forty-three degrees. East of it is the city of Venice (al-Bunduqiyah) at the end of the Gulf of the Venetians, where longitude is thirty-two degrees and latitude forty-four degrees four minutes. It is on an island; its buildings are of wood, and boats travel in it from house to house. A person's ship anchors at his house. They have no place to walk except the courtyard containing the exchange market, made for their rest if they need to walk. Their king from among themselves is called the Doge (al-Duj). In a river of his land is gold inclining to green. He has many great timbers. On the shore of the Venetian Sea is Mount Askhufuniyah (Slavonia/Dalmatia coast?), containing timbers, falcons, and brave men with whom the people of Genoa are defeated at sea. They have many small islands in this part and the next. On the shore of its sea are many settlements for the worshippers of the Cross. South of this sea is the city of Rome, capital of the Pope; according to Al-Khwarizmi's view, mentioned in the Fifth Clime. Located in this part is the city of Lucera (Lushirah), where the Emperor settled the Muslims he expelled from Sicily. It is where longitude is thirty-five degrees twenty-seven minutes and latitude forty-two degrees.

Part Three: The first thing you meet in it, north of the Gulf of the Venetians, is the city of Sibiniqu (Sebenico/Šibenik), belonging to the Hungarians (al-Hunkar), who are Turks following the Christian religion. Its location is where longitude is thirty-seven degrees forty minutes and latitude forty-five degrees. The Tatars reached it, so the Hungarians, Bashqirs, and Germans gathered against them there and defeated them a defeat that made them despair of returning to those lands. West of this city on the Gulf is Mount Askhufuniyah, previously mentioned. At the beginning of the Gulf from the southern side is Brindisi (Barandis). It is on the western side at the mouth of the Gulf. It is narrow there then widens after this city to about a course and a half, remaining so to its end. Brindisi is famous among sailors; it is where longitude is forty degrees eleven minutes and latitude forty-four degrees. On the north of the Gulf where longitude is forty degrees fifteen minutes is the city of Athens (Athina), the city of Aristotle the Wise. The authority of the Ashkari (Laskaris), ruler of Constantinople, reaches it. North and west of it is the city of Barshan (Presian?), which was a capital for a nation that the Germans took over, leaving no mention of them. It is where longitude is forty degrees and latitude forty-five degrees. From this city to Constantinople, from the lands inhabited by the Kharayita—who are the remnants of the Greeks—is a large number; they have obscure names and are undistinguished among Muslims. In this part lies the Island of Lamriya (Morea), known in books as the Island of Peloponnese. It has cities and settlements and is the largest of the Roman islands. Its circumference is precisely seven hundred miles. It has bays, curves, and a mouth to the land miles wide. On it from the west and south is the city of Korit (Coron/Koroni?), where longitude is forty-six degrees twenty minutes and latitude forty degrees. In its center is the city of Lamriya (Lacedaemonia/Sparta?), where the ruler of the island resides. It is where longitude is forty-five degrees fifty-two minutes and latitude forty-three degrees twenty-five minutes. Between this island and the Island of Crete is the strait from which one enters the many Roman islands; its size is sixty miles, and it is necessary for entering them. North of this island is the Island of Negropont (al-Naghrib - Euboea), one of the largest Roman islands. Its length from West to East deviating South is one hundred and fifty miles, and its width from twenty miles to thereabouts. Its eastern end is where longitude is forty-eight degrees fifty minutes and latitude forty-three degrees minus minutes. It is famous for ships and galleys exiting from it. East of it among Roman islands is the Island of Mastic (Chios), from which it is brought to regions; it is tree gum. Its length from North to South is about sixty miles. Between it and Negropont is about thirty miles. North of it is the Gulf of Constantinople. East of it is the city of Abzu (Abydos), by which the Mouth of Abzu is known. It belongs to the Kharayita, who are Christians who do not shave their beards. Its location is where longitude is forty-nine degrees forty-nine minutes. The width of this gulf is a bowshot. Its length likewise from the Sea of the Strait (Mediterranean/Aegean) to the city of Abzu is about fifty miles. Then it starts widening until after thirty miles from it, it approximates sixty miles. It passes like that for about a course. On it are cities of the Kharayita under the obedience of the ruler of Constantinople, built by Constantine the founder of the Christian religion. Its place was meadows in the land of the King of Barshan (Persians?), so he asked him to graze his horses. Then when his news was cut off by rains and mud, he built this city and made it the capital of the Caesars. The King of Barshan could not overcome him, then the Barshan perished. Constantinople is where longitude is forty-nine degrees fifty minutes, and latitude at the end of the Sixth Clime is forty-five degrees. The sea is on its three sides; the land is only from the western side. The narrow gulf passes by force, extending about eighty miles. At its end is the city of Nicomedia, which was the capital of the Greeks. In geography (Ptolemy's), its longitude is fifty-one degrees and latitude forty-four degrees fifteen minutes. South of it among famous lands to the people of those countries is the city of Asmara (Smyrna/Izmir?) on an inlet of the sea, where longitude is fifty degrees forty minutes and latitude forty-three degrees twenty-three minutes. South of it on an inlet of the sea is the city of Elia (Ilium/Troy?), one of the cities of the wise men mentioned in their books. Its location is where longitude is fifty degrees fifty-five minutes. East of these lands are the mountains of the Turkomans and their lands. They are a great multitude from the descendants of the Turks who conquered the lands of Rum (Anatolia) in the time of the Seljuks. They are accustomed to raiding the inhabitants of the coast from the Kharayita, taking their children and selling them to...

...Muslims. Nothing stops them from them except the support of the truce and the coercion of the Sultan. Turkoman rugs brought to the lands are made among them. On their coast is a gulf called the Gulf of Makri (Fethiye), famous among travelers; wood is brought from it to Alexandria and elsewhere. The River of al-Battal pours into it. It is deep and has a bridge; if there is a truce it is erected, and if war occurs it is lifted. It is a border between Muslims and Christians. Al-Battal, to whom it is attributed, is the one who frequently raided the Romans in the Umayyad state, whose name is mentioned in books of night tales; his grave is there. North of Antioch mentioned before are the Mountains of Taghurla (Taurus?). It is said in it and its directions are about two hundred thousand Turkoman tents; they are the ones called the Uj (Oghuz/Uch). There is the city of Taghurla. Between it and the fortress of Khiyas, where fine bows are made, is two farsakhs. The mountains of the Turkomans connect from the Gate of Taghurla to the King al-Ashkari, ruler of Constantinople. Between Taghurla and the bridge to its west is thirty miles. East of that is the River Heraclea (Harqalah) descending from the Mountain of Alanya to the end of Sinop. On it is Heraclea near the sea, which Al-Rashid destroyed. East of it is the Mountain of the Cave (Jabal al-Kahf) according to the Romans (Rum). It is said the Cave (of the Seven Sleepers) is there; that is mentioned in the history of Al-Wathiq when he sent someone to investigate the matter from the ruler of Constantinople. East of that are the famous meadows where Al-Mu'tasim was eager to graze his horses from Iraq. There are large springs there. The Romans call that place Qaranbuk. In that direction is the city of Ankuriyah (Ankara). It is said to be Amorium ('Ammuriyah) which Al-Mu'tasim conquered. It now belongs to Muslims. [Note: Repetition of text from "Muslims..." to "Muslims." in the source].

Its location is where longitude is fifty-three degrees and latitude forty-three and a third degrees. It is on a large river passing its west. In its regions is [...] which are mountains containing about thirty thousand Turkoman tents. West of Ankara at eight farsakhs is the city of Sultan Buli. The road between them is farms and springs. In this city are two baths whose water is like the water of thermal springs (Hamma), needing no heating; it flows constantly, intensely hot. From Ankara to the capital of the lands, the city of Konya, is four days. The location of Konya is where longitude is fifty-five degrees and latitude forty-one and a half degrees. It has a river descending from the mountain south of it, irrigating it from its west, forming a lake and meadows. Mountains surround it from every side, distancing from it on the north side. On its gate facing north is an image of the Wise Man who ordered its placement there, pointing to the north, as if saying: The mountains here are far, so no harm comes to you from them. Its buildings are of mud; the houses of chiefs and the wealthy are whitened. In the houses of kings and notables are slabs of white marble. Lemons, grapes, and fruits are abundant in it and other lands of Rum. Large good pistachios are brought from some of its regions. There is the large apricot known as Qamar al-Din; it is almond-like, preferred over the apricot of Damascus. Its Sultan is from the lineage of the Seljuks, Turks who believed and ruled from the lands of Turkestan to the Sea of the Levant, and conquered these lands now known as the lands of Rum. This Sultan is called the Owner of the Dome and the Bird. He is today appeasing the Tatars with money, and his lands are entering into theirs. It is said his sultanate contains twenty-four large cities, having governors, judges, officials, mosques, cloth merchants, and baths. As for the villages (estates), it is said they are four hundred thousand estates, of which thirty-six thousand have been ruined. It has silver mines whose workers never cease, and iron mines. East of Konya is Aqshar (Akşehir). It is longer (in longitude) than Konya by a degree and a half. Konya is wider (in latitude) by a quarter degree. This city is one of the beautiful cities with many inhabitants and waters. Most of what is in it is dyed beautiful apples, large pears, preferred quince, and high-quality peaches. East of it is the city of Aksaray, where beautiful rugs are made. It is at the latitude of Aqshar and longer than it by a degree. It also has many fruits carried on carts to Konya across a plain entirely of farms and valleys. The people of those lands say the distance of this road is forty-eight farsakhs. Likewise from Aksaray to the city of Kayseri (Caesarea). It is attributed to Caesar and called in our time Qaysariyah. It is a majestic city where the Sultan of the lands stays, moving from it to Konya and from Konya to it. It is where longitude is fifty-six and a half degrees and latitude forty-two degrees forty minutes. The road between it and Aksaray is all farms and valleys in a plain where wagons travel with oxen. East of Kayseri is the city of Sivas (Sebastia), one of the mother cities of the lands, famous among merchants. It is in a plain where longitude is fifty-seven and a half degrees and latitude forty-one degrees forty minutes. Travelers cut off on this road say they find in it twenty-four Khans containing everything they need, especially in days of snow.
