East of it is the city of Erzurum (Arzan al-Rum), the last of the lands of al-Durub from the East. Its location is where longitude is sixty-four degrees and latitude forty-two degrees thirty minutes. East and north of it is the source of the Euphrates from springs, meadows, thickets, and violets where longitude is sixty-four degrees thirty minutes and latitude forty-three and a half degrees. The people of those lands say that Erzurum is among the highest of lands. Some exaggerated saying it is higher than all the earth by forty cubits. In it is a great spring from which two parts exit; one part is the Euphrates, and a part passes east, which is the large river pouring into the Sea of the Gate (Caspian). Around that large spring are many springs, and violet grows between them. Ibn Fatimah mentioned that the Euphrates is supplied by a river extending from a mountain where longitude is sixty-eight and a half degrees and latitude forty-one degrees twenty minutes. From here Ptolemy placed the source of the Euphrates. From the mentioned mountain is the source of the River Aras (Araxes), which splits the lands of Azerbaijan and pours towards the Gate (Derbent/Caspian). That is where longitude is seventy degrees and latitude forty-two degrees twenty-two minutes. The people of Rum say that between Sivas and Erzurum is the famous city of Erzincan; between it and each of them is sixty farsakhs. The road between...

Erzurum and Erzincan are entirely springs, farms, valleys, and plains. They said: Travelers carry their goods from Turiz (Tabriz) in wagons pulled by oxen to Konya, covering that long distance which is about forty days. South of the river supplying the Euphrates from the East lies the city of Shirvan, which is the capital of its lands and mountains annexed to the Sultanate of Azerbaijan. Its location is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees fifty-six minutes, and latitude forty-one degrees forty-three minutes. Ibn Fatimah said: In this part lies the Great River Kur (Kura), which splits the land of Arran and pours into the Sea of Tabaristan (Caspian Sea). Its origin is from a spring where longitude is sixty-three degrees, and latitude forty-four degrees forty minutes. On it is the capital of the Georgians (al-Kurj), the city of Tiflis (Tbilisi), situated on its bank where longitude is sixty-seven degrees and latitude forty-four degrees. Muslims had conquered it and inhabited it for a long time, and scholars emerged from it. Then the Georgians regained it; they are Christians known to the people of their religion. Their land is called Abkhazia. Before Abkhazia is a fortress for their king in the long mountain which cannot be aspired to (is impregnable). East of it, on the south of the river, among the cities of Arran mentioned in books, is Shamkur (Shamkir), where longitude is sixty-nine and a half degrees, and latitude forty-four degrees. East of it, among the cities of Arran mentioned in relation to it, is the city of Ganja (Khanzah), where longitude is seventy-one degrees, and latitude forty-three degrees thirty-seven minutes. It is south of the River Kur; the Tatars played the worst havoc in it. [Note: The source text repeats the preceding paragraph.]

Part Five: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Barda (Bardha'ah), the capital of the Sultanate of Arran. It is on an island between two rivers exiting from the River Kur. Its location is where longitude is seventy-three degrees minus twenty minutes, and latitude forty-four degrees minus fifteen minutes. It is between the River Aras and the River Kur. Between the two rivers along the length of the island land, there is abundant mulberry. Its people are fond of sycamore figs, which are carried from there to other regions. North of the River Kur is the city of Nakhchivan (Naqjuwan), one of the mentioned cities in eastern Arran; the Tatars destroyed it and killed all its inhabitants. It is where longitude is seventy-three degrees seventeen minutes. East and north of it is the City of the Gate (Madinat al-Bab / Derbent), the capital of the Sultanate of the Gate. It consists of three sections on the Great River Atil (Volga/Terek?) at its mouth in the Sea of Tabaristan. The southern section was for Muslims, the northern section for Jews, Christians, and Zoroastrians, and the section in the island was for the Khagan of the Khazars, who was Jewish. Then the Rus destroyed it and removed the Khazar sultanate from it. It was populated thereafter by Muslims, then the Tatars destroyed it. Its location is where longitude is seventy-five degrees and latitude forty-five degrees. East of it in the Sea of Tabaristan is the Island of the Gate (Jazirat al-Bab), which has many meadows where the people of the Gate graze their livestock. East of it is the Island of the Volcano (Jazirat al-Burkan); in it is a mountain where fire never ceases burning night and day, and smoke rises from it like the volcano of Sicily and the volcano of India. It is said that the flying naphtha possessed by kings is found in this island. North of it is the Island of Shiyaku (Sia-Kuh?), which Ala al-Din Khwarizm Shah entered when fleeing before the Tatars; he died in the ship before reaching it. East of the Sea of Tabaristan is Mount Shiyaku, occupying the width of the Sixth Clime and the width of the Seventh Clime, then circling with the sea to the north of the City of the Gate; there is no good or harm in it. East of it are the domains of the 'Arabah (Arb?) from the Turkish races up to the sides of the Lake of Khwarizm (Aral Sea). The River Jayhun (Oxus) pours into this lake in this part, and the River Sayhun (Jaxartes) pours into it in the Seventh Clime. After this, its water is not good, and merchants do not penetrate it. It is said its circumference is six hundred miles. Ibn Fatimah said—and it is the verified view—that its eastern edge is with the end of the Seventh Part. Part Six: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Khwarizm (Urgench); this is how the common Persians know it, and it is its name in the Jurjanian books. It is on both sides of the Jayhun where longitude is ninety-one degrees fifty minutes, and latitude forty-two degrees ten minutes. It has obscure cities and settlements between the Jayhun and Sayhun. The River Sayhun occupies this part and passes through it. East of it is the River Shash, descending from a mountain at the beginning of the latitude of the Seventh Clime, occupying the width of this part and passing from its direction in the Fifth Clime until it pours into the River Sayhun. On it are the many settlements of Shash (Tashkent), possessing orchards and waters; they are obscure and unrenowned. There is no famous city in all that is east of it; most of those lands are domains for the Turkomans. At the end of the part from the northern corner, the River Sayhun twists to the South and to the West. Part Seven: It is entirely devoid of a famous city. At the end of its latitude passes the Sayhun, and on it are domains of the Turkomans; east of it is the land of Tibet. Part Eight: The first thing you meet in it are the mountains of Sahrujiya. They are a people born between the Kashmiris and the Turks. The city of Sahruj is their capital, surrounded by a sweet lake fed by springs gushing inside it. The location of the city is where longitude is thirty-four degrees [sic, likely 134] and latitude forty-five degrees. East of this lake is Lake Kharman; factions of Turks settle around it, and its center is where longitude is one hundred and forty degrees. Extending from its east is Mount Farghan, which is high and long from West to East, famous among the Turks. Part Nine: The mentioned mountain extends in it to longitude one hundred and forty-nine degrees, then extends in a circle around Lake al-Bali'ah (The Swallowing Lake), which swallows everything that falls into it. East of it is the Red Mountain, also called the Mountain of Rats (Jabal al-Jurz), because rats emerge from its holes whose skins are competed for in clothing by the kings of those regions. East of that is the city of Baghburia, one of the cities of the Adhkash, a Turkish race. It is large, and its location is where longitude is one hundred and fifty-eight degrees and latitude forty-two degrees fifty-three minutes. A river passes east of it. East and south of it is Adhkashiya, the capital of the Adhkash who are near the Dam of Gog and Magog. Its location is where longitude is one hundred and sixty degrees and latitude forty-one degrees thirty-eight minutes.

Part Ten: The first thing you meet in it is the Dam of Gog and Magog (Sadd Yajooj wa Majooj), built by the Two-Horned One (Dhul-Qarnayn) between the two mountains. The Gate was previously mentioned in the Fifth Clime. East of it are their lands, mostly on the Great River of Gog. Near its mouth in the Surrounding Ocean to its south is the city of Gog (Yajooj), where longitude is one hundred and forty-one minutes [sic, likely degrees], according to Ptolemy's geography. East and south of it is the city of Magog (Majooj), north of their river, where longitude is one hundred and seventy-one degrees, and latitude forty-two degrees. East of the two cities is the Surrounding Ocean, in which there is no habitation. Seventh Clime: The latitude at its end is forty-eight degrees, and its width is three degrees. Part One: The first thing you meet in it on the Surrounding Ocean is the mouth of the Great River Zamora (Douro? or a confusion with Somme/Garonne?), where longitude from the direction of the Eternal Islands (Canary Islands) is five and a half degrees, and latitude forty-six degrees. The city of Zamora (Samurah), capital of Galicia (Ghalisiya) and the largest city of the Alfons (Castilians/Leonese), lies on an island between two branches of this river, where longitude is ten degrees and latitude forty-six degrees. It is mentioned in the raids of Al-Nasir the Marwanid and Al-Mansur bin Abi Amir. Muslims had possessed it, then the Christians regained it during the strife. North of it, with a deviation to the East, is the impregnable city of Leon (Liyun), whose great wall was destroyed by Al-Mansur bin Abi Amir. It is on a river pouring into the Zamora, where longitude is ten degrees thirty minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees fifty-five minutes. In the North and West is Santiago (Shant Yaqu), containing James the Disciple; it has great significance to the Christians. It is on the Surrounding Ocean, surrounded by rivers descending from Mount Fakhira to its east. It is where longitude is nine degrees, and latitude forty-nine degrees. North of it is the city of [...], the last northern corner of Andalusia. From it, the sea turns to the East. It is on the last line of the Seventh Clime, where longitude is ten degrees ten minutes, and latitude forty-eight degrees. Located in this part on the Sea of Britain (Bay of Biscay?), entering the East from the Surrounding Ocean, is the city of Santarem (Shantarin - misplaced here, likely Santander or Saint-Jean-de-Luz?). It is one of the famous villages of Galicia from which Carracks (ships) exit, where longitude is thirteen degrees, and latitude forty-seven degrees fifty-four minutes. East of it is Larmad (?), one of the ports of Gascony (Qansala?) from which Carrack ships exit, where longitude is sixteen degrees thirty-three minutes, and latitude is close to the end of the Seventh Clime. East of it, among the ports of Gascony, is Ardalis (?), where longitude is seventeen degrees twenty-one minutes, and latitude forty-seven degrees twenty-eight minutes. East of it by a stage is the end of the Gulf of Britain. Remaining between it and the Surrounding Ocean is the amount of a stage.

Part Two: The first thing you meet in it is the city of Sansibin (Saint-Sever? San Sebastian?), which has many Carracks in an inlet on the Surrounding Ocean, where longitude is nineteen degrees and latitude forty-seven degrees minus eight minutes. East of it is a coast, then the Surrounding Ocean enters the Sixth Clime. The Seventh Clime returns, so on its coast is the land of Poitou (Bitu), and its inhabitants are the free Franks. From it, kings are chosen for France if they are lacking in France; this is a continuous custom. North of Poitou is the mouth of the River Seine (Sin) where longitude is twenty-six degrees thirty minutes. In the middle of this river and its side is the city of Paris (Baris), capital of France. It consists of three pieces as mentioned in the explanation of the City of the Gate. The middle in the island belongs to Francis (The King of France), the Sultan of the Franks. The southern is for the soldiers, and the northern for the rest of their merchants and subjects. This river descends from the Great Mount Danbus (Alps?), called in the North Mount Maliha. From its east is the source of the River Danbus (Danube), said to be larger than the Nile and the Jayhun. It is famous as the River Danuba, and the Turks call it Tana (Don - confusion in text). On its two sides in an island up to its mouth in the Sea of Constantinople are many cities and settlements, but they have obscure names and are unrenowned among us. South and north of this river is the Long Land of Germany (Almaniya), said to have forty kings. Its Sultan is known as the Imperator, meaning King of Kings; the commoners say al-Anbarur. Its ancient capital mentioned in books is Pisa (Bisah - possibly Regensburg/Ratisbon or similar?), where longitude is thirty-two degrees and latitude forty-six degrees twenty-seven minutes. North of it is the Great Mount Kharwasiya (Carpathians/Croatia?), connecting to the mountains of Lombardy and mountains of Askhufuniyah. On it are many districts and fortresses, and from it descend many rivers whose names are obscure to us. North of this mountain is the city of Siqlu (?), where famous German swords are made; it has an iron mine from which they are brought. It is said that in a place in it, there is a mine of poisonous iron from which swords and daggers are made; kings do not allow its discovery to others. This city is where longitude is thirty-three degrees fifty-four minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees fifty-two minutes. East of it and at its latitude is the city of Baqsin (?), distinguished for its scholars and wise men. It is where longitude is forty-four and a half degrees. Part Three: The first thing you meet in it is the land of the Bashqird (Bashkirs/Hungarians). They are Turks who neighbored the Germans by inherited pact. They are Muslims through a Turkoman jurist who enlightened them with the laws of Islam. Most of their settlements are on the Great River Danuba. On its south is their capital, where longitude is thirty-nine degrees twenty-eight minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees forty-eight minutes. It is among what the Tatars entered, destroyed, and whose people they annihilated. East of it is the land of the Hunkar (Hungarians), who are Turks, brothers of the Bashqird, who became Christians by neighboring the Germans. They have cities and settlements on the Great River with foreign names. Their capital is the city of Tarnbu (Tarnovo? Tyrnau?), where longitude is forty-two degrees and latitude forty-six degrees. This is also among what the Tatars entered. East of them are many cities and settlements belonging to the Kingdom of the Ashkari (Laskaris), ruler of Constantinople, with obscure names up to the border of their sea. On the sea to the end of the Third Part is the coast of al-Durub (Byzantine Frontier), belonging to the Christians. The most famous place there is Zaghan, a fortress on the sea and on the mouth of the River Battal; the Romans call it now River Zaghan. That is where longitude is fifty-three degrees, and latitude forty-five degrees forty-one minutes.

Part Four: The first thing you meet in it is the ancient city of Heraclea (Harqalah), which Al-Rashid destroyed. It is where longitude is fifty-four degrees three minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees thirty-five minutes. East of the river descending from the Mountain of Alanya (Alaya) is the River of Poplars (Nahr al-Hawr), named for the trees upon it. East of it, among the famous ports of Rum (Anatolia), is the city of Kastamonu (Kastimuniyah). It belongs to the Muslims, where longitude is fifty-five and a half degrees, and latitude forty-six degrees forty-three minutes. It is said that in its regions are one hundred thousand tents of the Turkomans; horses, hacks (workhorses), mules, and slaves are brought from them. Between it and Sinop (Sinub), the famous port to its east in whose sea is the fleet of the Sultan of Konya, is three days. It is where longitude is fifty-seven degrees, and latitude forty-six degrees forty minutes. East of it with a tilt to the South is the city of Amasya, one of the cities of the wise men. It is famous for beauty and abundance of waters, vineyards, and orchards. Between it and Sinop is six days. The road to it is in the Pine Mountains; all are timbers and waters descending from these mountains. Construction timber is cut for the arsenal of Sinop. The River of Amasya passes the city of Amasya and pours into the Sea of Sinop. East of it is Samsun (Simsun), one of the famous ports of Rum; a river with many mills cuts through it. It is where longitude is fifty-nine degrees twenty minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees thirty-eight minutes. East of it, extending from West to East along the coast of the sea, are the Jatik Mountains (Pontic Mountains?). In them are rebellious barefoot people professing Christianity. South of these mountains is Erzurum (Arzan al-Rum), mentioned in the Sixth Clime. From Amasya, mentioned previously, to the city of Niksar in the South and East, is eight farsakhs, all mountains with timbers, flowing springs, and valleys. From Niksar to Comana (Kamnah) is eight farsakhs. From Comana to Tokat (Tuqat), one of the famous lands of the Sultan of al-Durub, is five farsakhs. From this castle to Sivas, mentioned previously, is six farsakhs. East of the Jatik Mountains on the River of Sinop is the city of Trebizond (Atrabzand). It is a famous port intended by the novelties of the non-Arabs for its markets from various regions. Most of its inhabitants are from the Kabkaz (Caucasus). South of it, extending to the East, is the Great Mount Kabkaz; it is called the Mountain of Tongues due to the many languages therein. It is a mountain connected to Mount al-Bab. Most of the Kabkaz are Muslims who perform Hajj, and among them are Christians. The location of their city Trebizond is on the sea where longitude is sixty-four and a half degrees, and latitude forty-six degrees sixty minutes. East of it is the city of Alkasa (?). They are a race of Turks who converted to Christianity and became urbanized. Its location is on the sea, where longitude is sixty-six degrees, and latitude forty-six degrees fifty-three minutes. East of it is the city of Adhkashiya, inhabited by a people of the Adhkash; they are of Turkish races who became insightful (Christianized/civilized?) by neighborliness. It is on the sea, where longitude is sixty-seven degrees thirteen minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees forty minutes. East of it on the sea is Abkhazia (al-Abkhaz), the port of the Georgians (al-Kurj), who are Christians. Its location is where longitude is sixty-eight degrees eighty minutes [sic], and latitude forty-six degrees. East of it on the sea is Alania (Alaniyah), a city inhabited by people of the Alans, who are Turks that converted to Christianity. Its location is where longitude is sixty-nine degrees and minutes, and latitude forty-six degrees. The Alans are a large multitude in that direction and behind Bab al-Abwab (Derbent). Neighboring them are a people of the Turks called the As (Alans/Ossetians), of similar manner and religion. East of Alania, on a bay at the end of the Sea of Sinop, is the city of Khazaria, attributed to those whom the Rus annihilated. This sea may be called the Sea of the Khazar (Caspian) in relation to it. It is where longitude is seventy-one degrees, and latitude forty-five degrees thirty minutes. It is on a river pouring into the sea from its north.

Part Five: The first thing you meet in it is Mount Qabaq (Caucasus). In it, where one can penetrate to the North, is the Wall built by Anushirwan, King of the Persians, between the Sea of Tabaristan (Caspian) and the Sea of Sinop (Black Sea). In this Wall, gates were built, said to be seven, for every nation of the nations north of this Wall. On it is a fortress with guards who used to prevent the nation adjacent to that gate from entering the lands of the Chosroes. The greatest of these gates is the Iron Gate (Bab al-Hadid), known as such until now. On the turn of the mountain beside it is the Fortress of the Alans, one of the fortresses of the world, veiled by clouds. It is where longitude is seventy-three degrees twenty-four minutes, and latitude forty-five degrees forty minutes. It is said the Tatars suffered hardship against it and did not take it except by trickery after a time. What is north of this Wall today is in the domain of Ibn Barkah (Berke Khan) of the Muslim Tatars. What is south of it belongs to Ibn Hulawun (Hulagu), Sultan of the disbelieving Tatars. The capital of these Gates and their sultanate is the city of al-Bab (Derbent), previously mentioned at the end of the latitude of the Sixth Clime. The River Atil (Volga), which splits the city of al-Bab, occupies the width of this Seventh Clime. East of it is the Sea of Tabaristan. Located in this part is the Island of [...]; they are four islands in this sea, length about one hundred miles. Its eastern end is where longitude is eighty-one degrees, and its width about fifty miles. East of this sea are domains of the 'Arabah of the Turks. East of them in this part is half of the Lake of Khwarizm (Aral Sea) previously mentioned. The mouth of the Sayhun falls into it at a third of the Clime's width. Part Six: The first thing you meet in it is Mount Asgharun, long and high, from which snow never leaves. It extends to occupy the length of this part. Rivers descend from it to the great River Atil, flowing in its north with the end of the Seventh Clime's width and outside it. South of it is the Wall known as [...] built by Muslims in the face of the disbelieving Turks in the North. It extends from the bend of the Sayhun to the Mountain of the Gate of Al-Fadl bin Yahya, about twenty-seven days. It has three fortresses at its end and middle. Part Seven: Has no mentioned city; it is merely domains for types of Turks on the River Sayhun from its south and River Atil from its north. Part Eight: The first thing you meet in it is the source of the Sayhun, exiting from a lake, part of which is outside the Seventh Clime to what is behind it in the North. The source is from the east of the lake where longitude is one hundred and thirty degrees. The lake is round, its length like its width about a degree. East of it is the source of the Atil from the Sahrujiya Mountains, where longitude is one hundred and thirty-two degrees, and latitude with the end of the Seventh Clime. Then it arcs to what is behind it, then straightens passing through it, having inlets and outlets until it pours into the Sea of Tabaristan. East of it are the Sahrujiya Mountains, connected to the Mountain of Kashmir. From there it tilts to the Great Mountain called the Chain of the Earth (Silsilat al-Ard), until it occupies the length of this part winding in it from the southern corner to the northern corner, until connecting with Mount Quqaya. Part Nine: Has no habitation; rather, it occupies entirely the lands destroyed by Gog and Magog before the building of the Dam. At its end is the mountain surrounding them. Part Ten: Entirely behind the mountain in the land of Gog and Magog. At its eastern end, the Great River of Gog pours into the Ocean in the East. The Inhabited World North of the Seven Climes. The latitude at its end from the beginning of habitation in the South is eighty degrees, and from the Equator sixty-four degrees. Its width is sixteen degrees. Habitation is not possible after it in the North because the sun does not rise on that side. Part One of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: The first thing you meet in it in the Surrounding Ocean, in the West, is the Island of Britain (Britaniya). Its beginning from the South and West is where longitude is nine degrees from the direction of the Eternal Islands, and latitude with the end of the Seventh Clime. Then the sea enters it about a degree and a third, then returns to the line of the Seventh Clime. This sea exiting from the Surrounding Ocean is called the Sea of Britain. It surrounds this island from its south, and the Surrounding Ocean from the rest of its sides. It has an entrance left to the land of Andalusia from the southeastern side at the end of this part. The distance of this island in length is eighteen days from the southern side, and its width about eleven days in the middle. It has no waters except from rain. It has a separate king; his capital is the city of Bristol (Bristal), where longitude is thirteen degrees, and latitude forty-nine degrees forty-two minutes.

Part Two of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: The first thing you meet in it is the Island of Ballah (?). It is small and inhabited; war occurs over it between the Ruler of England and Britain, because it is between the borders. Its length from North to South, deviating to the East, is about one hundred miles. It is said there are trees in it from which birds like chickens emerge; this is widespread among the Franks, like the widespread talk of sheep emerging from gourds among the Turks. East of this island is the Island of England (Inkalitrah). Its ruler is the Inkitar (King of England), mentioned in the history of Salah al-Din during the wars of Acre. His capital is the city of London (Landras), where longitude is twenty-two degrees twenty minutes, and latitude forty-eight degrees fifteen minutes. Part of the island falls inside the Seventh Clime. It has large cities and obscure settlements unmentioned among us. The length of this island from South to North, deviating West and East, is about four hundred and thirty miles. Its width in the middle is about two hundred miles. In this island are gold, silver, copper, and tin. It has no vineyards due to severe frost. Its people carry the essence of these minerals by sea, enter France with them, and exchange that for wine. The Ruler of France has abundant gold and silver only from that. Among them, high-quality scarlet cloth (al-Iskarlat) is made. In this island are sheep with fine wool like silk; they place coverings on them to protect them from rain and dust. Despite the wealth of the Inkitar and the extent of his kingdom, he acknowledges the Sultanate to the French King (al-Fransis). If there is a gathering assembly, he serves him by placing a bowl of food before him; it is an inherited custom. North of England and some of northern Britain is the Island of Ireland (Irlandah). It enters Part One and Part Two. Its length distance is about twelve days, and width in the middle about four days. It is famous for many seditions. Its people were Majus (Vikings/Pagans), then converted to Christianity following their neighbors. Much copper and tin are also brought from it. In the North of this Second Part is the Island of Jirmuniyah (?). Its length is twelve days, and width in the middle about four days. Good falcons are brought from it. West of it is the Island of White Falcons (Iceland/Greenland?). Its length from West to East is about seven days, and width about four days. From it and the small northern islands, falcons are brought which are carried from there to the Sultan of Egypt. The fee for one emerging from his treasury is one thousand dinars, and if they bring it dead, he pays them five hundred dinars. They have the White Bear; it enters the sea, hunts fish, and snatches what remains or what these falcons neglect. That is their livelihood, as they (falcons) do not fly there due to intense frost. The skins of these bears are soft. On the Surrounding Ocean in this part is Ghuraz (?), capital of one of the Kings of the Slavs (Saqalibah) towards the West. The Germans, Hungarians, and Bashqirs have taken over all the lands of the Slavs. This city is famous, fortified in the middle of a large salt lake; it is only entered via a constructed bridge. It is where longitude is thirty-four and a half degrees, and latitude behind the Clime is eight and a half degrees. East of it, among the capitals that belonged to the Slavs then were taken by the aforementioned, is Kuwiyatiyah (Kuyavia/Kiev?). It is said it belonged to the greatest of the Slavic kings described with greatness. Its harbor in the Surrounding Ocean is intended; large ships gather in it. It is the best harbor of that direction. It is said it has twelve gates. East of it, among the capitals of their kingdom, is Sasin (Szczecin?), on the Surrounding Ocean. Part Three of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes:

Ten days east of Sasin is the city of Mashqah (Moscow?). Its ruler was of the Slavs, with a vast kingdom and huge army. It is where longitude is forty-three degrees, and latitude eight degrees from the Seventh Clime. Located in this part is the City of Women. Deserts surround it. It is where longitude is forty-four degrees, and latitude nine degrees from the Seventh Clime. No king rules them but a woman. They have slaves (Mamluks) in those deserts. When it is night, every slave knocks on his mistress's door and spends the night with her. At dawn, he returns to his place. If the woman gives birth to a boy, she kills him; if she gives birth to a girl, she keeps her alive. No man appears in their land at all. In the Surrounding Ocean in this northern direction is the Island of Women. Its length from East to West deviating South is about two hundred and fifty miles, and its width in the middle about one hundred and twenty miles. Its center is where longitude is thirty-eight degrees and latitude sixty degrees from the Equator. East of it is the Island of Men. Between the two islands is a strait ten miles wide. The length of the Island of Men from West to East is about two hundred and seventy miles, and width in the middle about one hundred and seventy miles. The men do not meet with the mentioned women except one month in the year, which is their time of equinox. The men ride in boats to the Island of Women; each man knows his woman. He lives with her for the duration of the month, then returns to the Island of Men. If the woman bears a male, she raises him until he reaches the age of men, then sends him to their island. If she bears a female, she settles her with the women. East of these two islands is the Great Island of the Slavs. There is no habitation in the Surrounding Ocean behind its east or north. Its length is about seven hundred miles, and its width in the middle Ocean about three hundred and thirty miles. It contains mountains, rivers, cities, settlements, and many people. It is said they remain on Majusiyya (Paganism) and fire worship; they see nothing of greater benefit than it, especially when frost descends upon them. Crops in this island and the like are not reached by the sun; rather, they grow by smoke and proximity to fires. The author of the Geography of Ajar mentioned that there are people in it whose heads are fused to their shoulders, and they mostly live in trees, hollowing them out and entering them. The capital of this island is the city of Barghadna (Novgorod?), by which the Barghar (Bulghars?) are named; it is said their origin is from this city. It is on the Surrounding Ocean where longitude is forty-five and a half degrees, and latitude fifty-seven degrees. The last point the Surrounding Ocean appears is the end of this part in the East; that is at the end of habitation in the North. There is the city of the Barus (Prussians?), a fierce nation more ignorant than the Rus. The Rus are east and south of them. In books, their faces are like dogs, which is proof of bravery. It is said one of them goes out to the army and fights alone until killed, out of recklessness and daring towards death. In this part are many obscure lands on the bank of the River Danast (Dniester), one of the world's great rivers. Its source is from the Great Mountain of the Slavs winding with the Surrounding Ocean until connecting with the Greatest Mountain known as Quqaya. The first island in this river is where longitude is forty-two and a half degrees and latitude fifty-four degrees thirty minutes. It passes west about a month, then twists east. Between the two arms remains a long wide island containing many settlements and cities. It continues east until it pours into the Sea of Sudak (Sea of Azov/Black Sea), about one hundred miles remaining between it and the completion of this part. As for the River Danbus (Danube), which the Turks call Tana, it divides when approaching the Sea of Sudak into six branches. All pour into close places where longitude is forty-eight degrees thirty-seven minutes. The last of them pours to the North, where longitude there is forty-nine and a half degrees. The Danast pours into the north of the mentioned sea where longitude is fifty-two degrees and latitude fifty degrees. After that, it goes west to where longitude is twenty-eight degrees, then goes east. Part Four of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes:

The first thing you meet in it among famous ports is the city of Sudak (Sudak). Its people are a mix of nations and religions, but authority there returns to Christianity. It is on the Sea of Nitish (Pontus/Black Sea), in which merchants travel from it to the Gulf of Constantinople. In its direction from the southern side is the city of Sinop, the famous port. The width of the sea between them is about two and a third courses. The location of Sudak is where longitude is fifty-six degrees and latitude fifty-one degrees. East of it is the entrance of the Sea of Manitish (Maeotis/Sea of Azov) from the Sea of Nitish mentioned before. Its width is about thirty miles, and its extension from South to North is about sixty miles. Then the sea widens, becoming about two and a third courses wide from West to East, and about one hundred and sixty miles from South to North. In it are islands inhabited by the Rus; thus it is called the Sea of the Rus. They are now on the Christian religion. A river exiting from the large Lake Tana pours into the north of this sea. On the side of this river, on the western bank, is Rusiya (Russia), the capital of the Rus. They are a large multitude, and there is length in their faces. This city is where longitude is fifty-seven degrees thirty-two minutes, and latitude fifty-six degrees. It has many obscure cities on the Sea of Nitish and Manitish. East of it is the large Lake Tuma. Its length from West to East is about six hundred and thirty miles, and its width in the eastern land is about three hundred miles. In its center is the Island of Alis, about one hundred and fifty miles long and seventy miles wide. In it is a formidable fortress on a mountain containing the treasuries of the Sultan of the land of the Tuman. In it today are the monies of the son of Berke. It is where longitude is sixty-six and a half degrees and latitude fifty-six degrees thirty-eight minutes. This island was attributed to [...] because it is found in it; it is an animal resembling the lion in strength. Many rivers descend into this lake; Al-Bayhaqi mentioned they exceed one hundred rivers. The largest is River Tanabris (Dnieper), long with a large flow, on which are many settlements of the Bulghars and Turks. On this lake are many cities and abundant settlements. Most of its inhabitants are Bulghars (Volga Bulgars), most of whom are Muslims, and among them are Christians. The famous capital in this region is Tuma, to which the lake is attributed. It is where longitude is sixty-nine degrees and latitude fifty-three degrees twenty-seven minutes. South of it towards the Sea of Nitish are the Boxwood Forests (Shi'ra' al-Baqs); from it, it is brought to all regions of the world. It is amazing that it is small in distance, width and length, yet supplies the lands of East and West due to the growth and speed of regeneration God Almighty placed in it. East of these forests on the sea is the city of Matrakha (Tmutarakan). It has lands and a king independent by himself. It is on the eastern corner of the sea in the North, where longitude is fifty-one degrees. Located in the north of this Fourth Part is the famous city of Saqsin, where longitude is sixty-seven degrees and latitude fifty-three degrees. East of it is the city of Sud, also famous and added to it. East of Saqsin is the city of Qaraghat, where longitude is seventy-eight degrees and latitude fifty-three degrees. East of it is Bulghar (Bolghar), a city of wood, where longitude is eighty-two and a half degrees and latitude fifty-three and a half degrees. Part Five of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes:

The first thing you meet in its south is the City of the Throne (Madinat al-Sarir), capital of the land of the Throne (Sarir - Avar Kingdom). One of the Chosroes had placed a throne there for one of his relatives and made him deputy in that direction, so it was known as the Land of the Throne. Its people are a mix of Arabs and Turks. It is where longitude is seventy-four degrees and latitude fifty degrees thirty-one minutes. It is on a mountain connecting to the Mountain of Tongues (Caucasus) where the Gates are. From this mountain descends the River of Sheep (Nahr al-Ghanam), pouring into the Sea of Khazaria (Caspian) east of the city of Matrakha. It is large, bearing loads in winter, and animals cross over it (when frozen). South of it pours the Small River Atil, coming from towards the Great Atil, passing south of the River of Sheep. Between them remains an island about three stages wide. The army of Hulagu had crossed these two rivers to fight the army of Berke. Berke's army defeated them, and they drowned upon their return in the first River of Sheep. Then those who survived drowned in the other river; they crossed it on ice, and it collapsed with them. It is said that armor and helmets are brought out from these two rivers to this day. East of the City of the Throne is the city of Burtas, capital of this race of Turks, where longitude is seventy-six degrees and latitude fifty degrees fifty-two minutes. It is on the edge of the great Mount Qarmaniya, circling from its north about thirty-eight days to the side of the River Tanabris. From it, many rivers descend to Lake Tuma. Burtas has many domains on the River Atil east and south of them. East of Burtas is a large inlet from the Sea of Tabaristan. East of it is Lake Mazgha; its circumference is about eight days. Many rivers descend to it from the great Mount Asgharun curving over it from the Seventh Clime. The great River Mazgha exits from it (the mountain) and pours into it (the lake), and a river exits from it pouring into the long River Atil. On this mountain in this part is the Fortress of Dandara; in it, the King of Burtas keeps his stores, and from it, he raids the 'Arabah and those Turkish races camped around this lake. It is where longitude is forty-seven and a half degrees and latitude fifty-one degrees. Also on this mountain is the Fortress of Darmu; in it, the King of the 'Arabah keeps his stores, and from it, he raids the Burtas and others. It is at the end of the longitude of Part Five, and latitude fifty degrees fifty-two minutes. In the north of this part is the course of the great River Tanabris. On it is the city of Saqsin previously mentioned; in it now is the son of Berke, King of the Muslim Tatars, and it has madrasas and mosques. Part Six of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: Has no mentioned town nor famous landmark. In its south is the long River Atil. In its north passes the River Tanabris, which pours into Lake Tuma from the high Humpbacked Mountain connected to the Great Mountain extending with the end of habitation in the North. That is where longitude is one hundred and seven and a half degrees and latitude sixty-one degrees. South of this mountain is Mount Arstana (?), extending from East to West; two large rivers descend from it to the River Atil. Part Seven of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: The first thing you meet in it is Mount Asqasiya, extending from North to South. Three rivers descend from it to the long River Atil. In the directions of this mountain is the land of Qumaniya (Cumans). They are of the Turkish races; they have interest in stars and occupation with their judgments, and they worship them. They have in this part Lake 'Unqur (?). Its length from East to West deviating South is eleven days, and its width four days. Mount Taghura, capital of the Qumaniya, surrounds it from the West. It is where longitude is one hundred and sixteen degrees and latitude fifty-five degrees. It has cities on the rivers descending from this mountain and on the lake, with obscure names. Part Eight of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes:

The first thing you meet in it is the Mountain of the Pechenegs (Bajnak). It traverses from North to South. Two rivers exit from it; the northern one goes west forming a lake about one hundred miles in circumference. On its western side is Bajnakiyah, the capital of the Khagan of the Pechenegs. They are a nation of Turks who burn themselves and burn whoever falls to them. This city is where longitude is one hundred and twenty-five degrees and latitude fifty-five degrees. It is located at the end of the previous part. The Pechenegs have a second mountain curving from the Seventh Clime, passing connected to the Sahrujiya Mountain. A river descends from it to a lake; its width is one hundred miles, and likewise its length. On it and on the mentioned river are cities of the Pechenegs with obscure names. From this lake exits a river passing west to another lake at the city of Tayghuwa (?). It belongs to a king of the Pechenegs; the ruler of Bajnakiyah fights him, although the Khaganate among them is hereditary in his offspring. It is where longitude is one hundred and thirty degrees and latitude fifty-two and a half degrees. East of the Pechenegs is the Stinking Land (al-Ard al-Muntinah); no one can traverse it except with good scents, and it is empty. North of it is the land of Sahrat; they are disbelievers, no one enters them except they kill him. Part Nine of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: The first thing you meet in its south is the Excavated Land (al-Ard al-Mahfurah). It is round; its width is four days and likewise its length. They claimed it is inhabited by people who cannot ascend, and no one can descend to them due to its depth. The Great Mountain known as the Chain of the Earth (Silsilat al-Ard) splits it. Its eastern limit in longitude is one hundred and forty-seven and a half degrees, and its southern limit is at the end of the latitude of the Seventh Clime. North of it is the land of the Kipchak (Khafshaq). Al-Bayhaqi mentioned they are the ones who became known as the Naqjar (?) and diverted to the lands of Constantinople. They had many kings in the Maghreb (West). The Tatars scattered their unity and saw their bravery, so they made them ride with them. At the end of this part is the curve of the mountain surrounding Gog and Magog, and its connection to the mountain known as the Chain of the Earth. Part Ten of the Inhabited World Behind the Climes: All of it is inside the land of Gog and Magog, and its end is the Surrounding Ocean in the East. Its completion, and praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and blessings of Allah upon our Master Muhammad.
